column2: this story originally appeared on grist and is part of the climate desk collaboration in a remote region of antarctica known a pine island bay   mile from the tip of south america two glacier hold human civilization hostage stretching across a frozen plain more than  mile long these glacier named pine island and thwaites have marched steadily for millennium toward the amundsen sea part of the vast southern ocean further inland the glacier widen into a two mile thick reserve of ice covering an area the size of texas there s no doubt this ice will melt a the world warms the vital question is when the glacier of pine island bay are two of the largest and fastest melting in antarctica a rolling stone feature earlier this year dubbed thwaites the doomsday glacier together they act a a plug holding back enough ice to pour  foot of sea level rise into the world s ocean an amount that would submerge every coastal city on the planet for that reason finding out how fast these glacier will collapse is one of the most important scientific question in the world today to figure that out scientist have been looking back to the end of the last ice age about   year ago when global temperature stood at roughly their current level the bad news there s growing evidence that the pine island bay glacier collapsed rapidly back then flooding the world s coastline partially the result of something called marine ice cliff instability the ocean floor get deeper toward the center of this part of antarctica so each new iceberg that break away expose taller and taller cliff ice get so heavy that these taller cliff can t support their own weight once they start to crumble the destruction would be unstoppable ice is only so strong so it will collapse if these cliff reach a certain height explains kristin poinar a glaciologist at nasa s goddard space flight center we need to know how fast it s going to happen in the past few year scientist have identified marine ice cliff instability a a feedback loop that could kickstart the disintegration of the entire west antarctic ice sheet this century much more quickly than previously thought minute by minute huge skyscraper sized shard of ice cliff would crumble into the sea a tall a the statue of liberty and a deep underwater a the height of the empire state building the result a global catastrophe the like of which we ve never seen ice come in many form with different consequence when it melt floating ice like the kind that cover the arctic ocean in wintertime and comprises ice shelf doesn t raise sea level think of a melting ice cube which won t cause a drink to spill over land based ice on the other hand is much more troublesome when it fall into the ocean it add to the overall volume of liquid in the sea thus sea level rise antarctica is a giant landmass about half the size of africa and the ice that cover it average more than a mile thick before human burning of fossil fuel triggered global warming the continent s ice wa in relative balance the snow in the interior of the continent roughly matched the iceberg that broke away from glacier at it edge now a carbon dioxide trap more heat in the atmosphere and warms the planet the scale have tipped a wholesale collapse of pine island and thwaites would set off a catastrophe giant iceberg would stream away from antarctica like a parade of frozen soldier all over the world high tide would creep higher slowly burying every shoreline on the planet flooding coastal city and creating hundred of million of climate refugee all this could play out in a mere  to  year much too quickly for humanity to adapt with marine ice cliff instability sea level rise for the next century is potentially much larger than we thought it might be five or  year ago poinar say a lot of this newfound concern is driven by the research of two climatologist rob deconto at the university of massachusetts amherst and david pollard at penn state university a study they published last year wa the first to incorporate the latest understanding of marine ice cliff instability into a continent scale model of antarctica their result drove estimate for how high the sea could rise this century sharply higher antarctic model raise prospect of unstoppable ice collapse read the headline in the scientific journal nature a publication not known for hyperbole instead of a three foot increase in ocean level by the end of the century six foot wa more likely according to deconto and pollard s finding but if carbon emission continue to track on something resembling a worst case scenario the full  foot of ice locked in west antarctica might be freed up their study showed three foot of sea level rise would be bad leading to more frequent flooding of u city such a new orleans houston new york and miami pacific island nation like the marshall island would lose most of their territory unfortunately it now seems like three foot is possible only under the rosiest of scenario at six foot though around  million people in the united state would be displaced and the world s most vulnerable megacities like shanghai mumbai and ho chi minh city could be wiped off the map at  foot land currently inhabited by hundred of million of people worldwide would wind up underwater south florida would be largely uninhabitable flood on the scale of hurricane sandy would strike twice a month in new york and new jersey a the tug of the moon alone would be enough to send tidewater into home and building deconto and pollard s breakthrough came from trying to match observation of ancient sea level at shoreline around the world with current ice sheet behavior around  million year ago when global temperature were about a warm a they re expected to be later this century ocean were dozen of foot higher than today previous model suggested that it would take hundred or thousand of year for sea level rise of that magnitude to occur but once they accounted for marine ice cliff instability deconto and pollard s model pointed toward a catastrophe if the world maintains a business a usual path meaning we don t dramatically reduce carbon emission rapid cut in greenhouse gas however showed antarctica remaining almost completely intact for hundred of year pollard and deconto are the first to admit that their model is still crude but it result have pushed the entire scientific community into emergency mode it could happen faster or slower i don t think we really know yet say jeremy bassis a leading ice sheet scientist at the university of michigan but it s within the realm of possibility and that s kind of a scary thing scientist used to think that ice sheet could take millennium to respond to changing climate these are after all mile thick chunk of ice the new evidence though say that once a certain temperature threshold is reached ice shelf of glacier that extend into the sea like those near pine island bay will begin to melt from both above and below weakening their structure and hastening their demise and paving the way for ice cliff instability to kick in in a new study out last month in the journal nature a team of scientist from cambridge and sweden point to evidence from thousand of scratch left by ancient iceberg on the ocean floor indicating that pine island s glacier shattered in a relatively short amount of time at the end of the last ice age the only place in the world where you can see ice cliff instability in action today is at jakobshavn glacier in greenland one of the fastest collapsing glacier in the world deconto say that to construct their model they took the collapse rate of jakobshavn cut it in half to be extra conservative then applied it to thwaites and pine island but there s reason to think thwaites and pine island could go even faster than jakobshavn right now there s a floating ice shelf protecting the two glacier helping to hold back the flow of ice into the sea but recent example from other region like the rapidly collapsing larsen b ice shelf on the antarctic peninsula show that once ice shelf break apart a a result of warming their parent glacier start to flow faster toward the sea an effect that can weaken the stability of ice further inland too if you remove the ice shelf there s a potential that not just ice cliff instability will start occurring but a process called marine ice sheet instability say matthew wise a polar scientist at the university of cambridge this signal the possible rapid destabilization of the entire west antarctic ice sheet in this century once the stress exceed the strength of the ice wise say it just fall off and it s not just pine island bay on our current course other glacier around antarctica will be similarly vulnerable and then there s greenland which could contribute a much a  foot of sea level rise if it melt next to a meteor strike rapid sea level rise from collapsing ice cliff is one of the quickest way our world can remake itself this is about a fast a climate change get still some scientist aren t fully convinced the alarm is warranted ted scambos lead scientist at the national snow and ice data center in colorado say the new research by wise and his colleague which identified ice cliff instability in pine island bay   year ago is tantalizing evidence but he say that research doesn t establish how quickly it happened there s a whole lot more to understand if we re going to use this mechanism to predict how far thwaites glacier and the other glacier are going to retreat he say the question boil down to what are the brake on this process scambos think it is unlikely that thwaites or pine island would collapse all at once for one thing if rapid collapse did happen it would produce a pile of iceberg that could act like a temporary ice shelf slowing down the rate of retreat despite the difference of opinion however there s growing agreement within the scientific community that we need to do much more to determine the risk of rapid sea level rise in  the u and uk government began to plan a rare and urgent joint research program to study thwaites glacier called how much how fast the effort is set to begin early next year and run for five year seeing the two government pooling their resource is really a sign of the importance of research like this nasa s poinar say given what s at stake the research program at thwaites isn t enough but it might be the most researcher can get realistically it s probably all that can be done in the next five year in the current funding environment say pollard he s referring of course to the trump administration s disregard for science and adequate scientific funding the white house s  budget proposal includes the first ever cut to the national science foundation which typically fund research in antarctica it would be sensible to put a huge effort into this from my perspective pollard say structural engineer need to study antarctica s key glacier a though they were analyzing a building he say probing for weak spot and understanding how exactly they might fail if you vastly increase the research now the cost would still be trivial compared to the loss that might happen bassis the ice sheet scientist at the university of michigan first described the theoretical process of marine ice cliff instability in research published only a few year ago he s  year old but his field ha already changed enormously over the course of his career in  when bassis wa conducting his phd research in a different region of antarctica he wa shocked to return to his base camp and learn that the larsen b ice shelf had vanished practically overnight every revision to our understanding ha said that ice sheet can change faster than we thought he say we didn t predict that pine island wa going to retreat we didn t predict that larsen b wa going to disintegrate we tend to look at these thing after they ve happened there s a recurring theme throughout these scientist finding in antarctica what we do now will determine how quickly pine island and thwaites collapse a fast transition away from fossil fuel in the next few decade could be enough to put off rapid sea level rise for century that s a decision worth countless trillion of dollar and million of life the range of outcome bassis say is really going to depend on choice that people make

column2: flash flood can strike with almost no warning so it pay to be prepared it doesn t take much for rain to escalate from a light drizzle to a deadly emergency situation in the event the dry land around you transforms into a raging river these tip can keep you from being swept away in the video above we ll explain how to know when a flood is coming your way you ll also learn the difference between a flood watch and a flood warning and see why it s best to avoid any water during a flash flood even if you re in a car plus we ll explain the importance of seeking higher ground what to do if flood water reach your home and how to escape a car trapped in deep water and if you do get knocked off your foot by the mighty force of an impromptu river you ll be surprised how little water it take you ll learn how to float safely until you can grab something and wait for help flood water may not look all that threatening on tv especially if you re a skilled swimmer but read more read wherever you find yourself during a flash flood it s important to remember to get to higher ground wait for the water to subside then make your way to safety if you want to read more about navigating the danger of flash flood you can check out our survival guide here

column2: the flood underinsurance problem is arguably the largest unsolved problem in insurance over the last ten year an average of  bn per year of flood damage ha gone uncovered by insurance leaving people business and government to pay the bill it s estimated that there are  bn of loss caused by flood around the world currently only  bn of these are covered by insurance floodflash an insurtech startup that offer a way for customer to insure their property for flood risk even in high risk area by employing an internet connected water sensor ha raised  m in seed funding from localglobe pentech venture and insurtech gateway they previously secured a pre seed angel round in  hambro perk insurtech gateway and one private investor when a flood happens it trigger an internet connected water sensor and the payment is made immediately to the policy holder a floodflash policy pay out a pre agreed fixed sum a soon a a pre defined level of flooding occurs a slice of the premium go to floodflash in return for installing the sensor plus automated underwriting and claim service founder adam rimmer and ian bartholomew created the company after looking at parametric catastrophe bond these are typically used by large corporation or government to recover large sum in the event of a catastrophe but many of the benefit they confer were previously unavailable to small and medium sized enterprise rimmer say every year ten of thousand of business owner lose their livelihood because they have been unable to take out an affordable policy that protects their business in the immediate aftermath of a catastrophic flood people care le about dollar for dollar reimbursement for damage and more about whether their business will survive at all we believe floodflash s event based insurance is absolutely the best way for insurer to cover higher risk area floodflash is regulated by the fca and is currently carrying out a live pilot for it policy with a select group of smes in part of the uk with significant flood risk including carlisle insurance capacity for floodflash policy is provided by everest re through their syndicate at lloyd s of london the startup ha been working a part of the insurtech gateway the insurtech focused incubator since mid  tara reef partner at localglobe said climate change is leading to more extreme weather event but these are often hard to insure parametric insurance dramatically reduces underwriting and loss adjustment cost and those saving can be passed on to the consumer adam and ian s background in risk modelling and hydrology is uniquely suited to this challenge eddie anderson partner at pentech venture said floodflash is a business that ha global potential there is no country on the planet where severe or freak weather doe not cause havoc whether it is flood or hurricane we think market around the world will welcome this innovative cost effective way to sell insurance that ha been adapted to take into account the way we live today

column2: this story originally appeared on citylab and is part of the climate desk collaboration on a gray late winter day a converted chapel in the arsenal the city s medieval boatyard hummed with st century activity engineer were looking at screen that displayed table map and chart on the condition of the venetian lagoon this wa the mose control center the operational heart of a megaproject to protect venice one of the world s most beautiful city from threatening water for nearly seven year the engineer here have raised and lowered virtual door gathering a series of data to be conveyed into a sophisticated forecasting model spread across dozen of island and known a the floating city for it ubiquitous canal and bridge venice ha grappled with inundation for century but due to natural subsidence and the higher tide caused by global warming the city is more vulnerable to flooding than ever before so a flood barrier seemed like the obvious way to thwart future disaster mose an acronym for modulo sperimentale elettromeccanico or experimental electromechanical module is one of the world s largest and highest profile civil engineering work it consists of a series of retractable floodgate stretching across the mouth of the lagoon s three inlet these gate can be raised on command to create a temporary wall against the sea in the event of a high tide work on mose began in  but after countless delay caused by a corruption scandal and financial and structural issue the barrier ha yet to be completed the hard part is done however and most of the engineer at the control center were confident that the system will become fully operational soon since the final leg of construction ha been stalled for month though no one could say exactly when some said later this year others said  wa closer to reality whatever the date it still remains unclear whether mose will adequately protect the city and if so for how long mose operates on the principle of tidal gate in calm weather the gate fill with water and sit on the seabed but when a high tide threatens the water is pushed out by compressed air that s pumped in this allows the gate to surface and prevent the tide from entering the lagoon when the surge subsides the gate again fill with water and sink back to the bottom the idea is quite old said paola malanotte rizzoli a physical oceanographer at the massachusetts institute of technology who wa among the panel of expert enlisted by the italian government to come up with a solution we have evidence that venetian engineer drafted mechanical contraption to hold back the sea a long ago a in the th century nevertheless a barrage of criticism ha accompanied the project since it beginning environmental group said that construction of the barrier would jeopardize the marine ecosystem beyond repair while some politician opposed the idea stating that there were too many unknown and that a cheaper solution wa needed many expert agree however that when the sea rise there aren t many alternative to building a barrier to stop it especially in a one of a kind city like venice the concept behind mose is good said jrg imberger an environmental engineer who teach ocean science at the university of miami but it all depends on what is meant by protection according to imberger if everything go a planned mose will protect venice from flood like the catastrophic one in  for the next three decade or so but since the gate are raised only when the tide reach  centimeter roughly  inch mose won t avoid the flooding phenomenon that already take place in low lying site like saint mark s square which inundates when the tide get above  centimeter about  inch he said this could be potentially fixed by lifting the barrier at lower tide but that would have some adverse effect on the health of the lagoon the outlook get foggier when it come to the long run like much else in this world mose s effectiveness depends on how much carbon dioxide is pumped into the atmosphere over coming decade and hence how fast sea level rise during the barrier s  year lifespan furthermore conflicting statement on it engineering parameter do little to clarify according to a  unesco report three sea level rise scenario for  were considered during the planning phase  centimeter about  inch  centimeter about  inch and   centimeter approximately one foot planner suggested using the second one labeled a prudent but today even the third scenario seems over optimistic with climate change the mediterranean sea is projected to rise up to five foot before  meaning that mean water level could reach the critical threshold of  centimeter that would cause venice to suffer flooding twice a day at high tide malanotte rizzoli maintains that mose wa engineered to handle about  foot of sea level rise the new venice consortium the organization entrusted with building the barrier say the same but this reporter could find no evidence that this wa an official project goal the question of capability is crucial not only because sea level rise make higher storm surge more likely but because it will require the barrier to activate more often increasing wear and tear on a structure that ha already experienced structural problem according to georg umgiesser an oceanographer at the italian national research council s institute of marine science with  centimeter about  inch of sea level rise the barrier will be closed once a day whereas with  centimeter about  inch the gate will be closed more often than they are open more frequent closing doesn t only imply additional maintenance cost umgiesser said but an ever increasing dependence on the barrier to avert severe flooding a failure could be devastating over the year alternative to a seawall have been proposed some offered tweak to the system of mobile gate while others involved different technology still others were aimed only at making the flooding more bearable so far though none ha found wide support at any rate it seems clear that venice like many other coastal city around the world won t be saved by a barrier alone since the  flood the frequency of tide over  centimeter ha doubled each decade said giovanni cecconi head of the venice resilience lab and this trend is not going to stop anytime soon even if emission were curbed it s obvious that mose is not a magic wand he continued but rather something that will allow u to take time to figure out and implement new way to cope with a crisis more climate science

column2: scandal read the facebook post of mexican comedian and journalist jorge roberto avils on march th the government of venezuela ha confirmed on it television station venevision what we all already knew nicols maduro is behind andrs manuel lpez obrador s campaign accompanying the post wa a video that proved what opponent of lpez obrador a three time mexican presidential candidate had long claimed lpez obrador wa a crony of the venezuelan chavista regime and his latest presidential campaign which culminates with the upcoming july st presidential election wa propped up by a foreign regime the video feature the logo of venezuela s state backed television station venezolana de televisin vtv and depicts a newscaster saying with the triumph of this latin american leader on july  the bolivarian revolution will have a first rate ally in the continent to confront international attack venezuela ha become an aphorism for the fear of many mexican voter though lpez obrador ha consistently denied any formal tie to venezuela the video looked like proof of a connection the clip spread fast avils ha   million follower on facebook and by march th it had racked up more than   view the video looked like proof of a foreign connection but something wa off the logo weren t from vtv and the video timestamps read  pm a slot when vtv doesn t broadcast news for discerning observer all the sign were there the clip shared by avils wasn t a vtv clip but instead a strange amalgamation of video audio and fabricated graphic from three separate source it wa in other word a piece of fake news with mexico s election on the horizon weeding out fake news in the country of  million ha never been more pressing mexican have long distrusted the press and for good reason for decade the national news medium here consisted of two television network and a handful of newspaper all propped up financially by the controlling institutional revolutionary party pri coverage of the government wa favorable and negative story were buried when the government wanted to announce something it came out over televisa say esteban illades editor of the mexican magazine nexos and author of the recent book fake news una nueva realidad it wa very rare to find a version that contradicted the government line in these official news outlet government publicity continues to be an important line item in medium company budget a report by the mexican ngo fundar published in september  found that the government spent   billion between january  and june  on medium advertising and many outlet still report the official version of event without further investigation a bloomberg investigation last fall revealed that politician paid for package of positive story or to suppress negative report fact checking say illades is just starting to permeate mexican newsroom a a result a  poll suggested that more mexican trust the army and the catholic church than the medium social medium and digital outlet have emerged a an important counterbalance to government controlled medium but it also present the risk of mass misinformation mexico is a hub in the spanish speaking world for bot farm in the  presidential campaign now imprisoned colombian hacker andrs seplveda claim to have launched   twitter bot in support of pea nieto s campaign many mexican also get their news from messaging application like whatsapp and news outlet are hard pressed to catch up when chain message spread inaccurate information almost instantaneously a  poll suggested that more mexican trust the army and the catholic church than the medium july st will be the largest election in mexican history voter will be deciding on the makeup of the senate state and local race and voting for a president in term of managing the spread of fake news illades say  is a trial by fire when the video of maduro endorsing lpez obrador went viral verificado  a new mexican fact checking initiative wa just setting up it office in the condesa neighborhood of mexico city verificado  is the brainchild of tania montalvo the editor of the fact checking unit at digital medium outlet animal poltico with funding from google and facebook verificado  ha hired  journalist and data analyst to work full time for the duration of the presidential campaign they have a clear mission to confront two phenomenon on the one hand fake news and on the other the candidate impossible promise and unsubstantiated critique according to the website verificado  partner with local paper across the country ranging from el diario de yucatn in southeastern mexico to the national television and print behemoth milenio in the vein of electionland in the state the team fact check viral story and the candidate claim in debate and speech verificado  ha fact checked story ranging from pope francis speaking out against lpez obrador false to candidate ricardo anaya speaking in favor of the border wall false to the first lady of zacatecas praying for the country not to become a socialist dictatorship true a the maduro clip spread across facebook the verificado  team reached out to video expert and venezuelan television journalist to help analyze it jorge rams the audience editor at verificado  say that a few obvious error tipped them off that the video wa fake the logo wa placed wrong and in other technical aspect it didn t match up to what vtv broadcast he say venezuelan journalist noted that the broadcast supposedly aired at  pm a time slot when vtv doe not broadcast news it appears that the video wa fabricated by pasting an audio recording over video footage made in mexico combined with lifted vtv logo verificado  revealed that the pro lpez obrador subtitle and image of the candidate had been pasted onto an unrelated broadcast on march th verificado  published an explainer debunking the video the explainer wa then reprinted by numerous partner news outlet avils removed the video and a radio program that he appears on la maldita hora issued an apology saying they never intended to deliberately spread false information on our platform keeping up with the steady flow of fake news is a constant challenge in january another viral video spread across facebook supposedly depicting a russia today rt tv broadcaster announcing that the kremlin wa also supporting lpez obrador verificado  sought out a russian translator and subsequently revealed that the pro lpez obrador subtitle and image of the candidate had been pasted onto an unrelated broadcast which wa in fact from the channel rossiya  despite verificado  s best effort digital right activist warn that the threat of misinformation is only growing de escndalo esto no tiene nada de falso todo pic twitter com wjrmamo aj espaol ajplusespanol march   alberto escorcia ha tracked twitter trend in mexico since  on his website lo que sigue and he currently report on bot for buzzfeed mxico he say that like in the state organized network of paid social medium user amplify fake story these network are a tool to destabilize country and to change election he told the verge over skype he s lived outside mexico for a year due to violent threat for his work facebook and twitter have taken more proactive step to combat the spread of fake news since trump s election but escorcia say that their effort fall short in developing country in his experience the most robust troll and cyborg network exist in honduras and mexico the rule from twitter aren t enough escorcia say an attack must line up exactly with what the rule prohibit for them to take down the account he explains how politician enlist social medium in disinformation campaign a politician go to a middleman who then contract a public relation agency specialized in social network manipulation the agency offer different portfolio of social network profile to promote message in favor of the politician or one critical of his opponent payment are made in cash these interaction are semi clandestine so it s hard to find a paper trail he say the same structure ha been documented in investigative report by adn poltico and univisin escorcia say the group are effective because they have an eager low wage labor pool the condition in our country or a country like bangladesh or vietnam lead many jobless people to get involved in this business escorcia explains montalvo of verificado  say that facebook ha been just a integral to the spread of fake news with page disguised a news outlet publishing a mix of true and false story one such page diario de oaxaca ha over   follower even a fake story published on diario de oaxaca that is downgraded through facebook s third party fact checking of which verificado  is a part can reach thousand of people then there s whatsapp which allows user to create group with hundred of member chain message about the election are circulating over whatsapp group with no mechanism to trace the origin of the information the center for international medium assistance recently wrote that while facebook and twitter receive more attention private dark social messenger including signal telegram and whatsapp may be all the more to blame for the viral spread of disinformation which is nearly impossible to track or counter once it is being circulated the condition in our country or a country like bangladesh or vietnam lead many jobless people to get involved in this business verificado  ha opened a whatsapp account to receive report of election related chain message but it acknowledges that it s the hardest platform to track observer doubt that fake news will sway the election or upend lpez obrador s expected victory lpez obrador currently ha a double digit lead and mexico s presidential election is determined by plurality nonetheless fake news ha amplified the polarization between lpez obrador s supporter and his detractor escorcia worry that even if lpez obrador win by a significant percentage orchestrated social medium campaign could provoke violence during the post election period he point to an incident in january  during the gasolinazo when the government announced an increase in gas price a people took to the street in protest bot pushed the hashtag saqueaunwalmart loot a walmart which became a trending topic in mexico city on january rd the hashtag then circulated over whatsapp setting off fear of widespread looting hundred of business closed early and people took shelter but only a handful of store were actually looted escorcia considers this a combined operation where a fabricated story online provokes reaction in the street he envisions a similar situation playing out if lpez obrador is elected bot and human actor inciting panic during the inauguration for example i think it s going to get ugly on election day say escorcia bot aren t just used for political propaganda they can be used to repress and stop resistance

column2: ive watched my mother host  thanksgiving this roughly equates to a collective  guest a metric half ton of turkey and enough gravy to flood the chicago suburb anyone who can estimate the overall caloric intake deserves the nobel prize a midwestern thanksgiving is a special thing a so much of a host energy must be spent anticipating and accommodating a wide range of potentiality take the weather my own lifetime ha seen thanksgiving day range from  to  degree fahrenheit a spread that allows for both slushy boot and sunburn yes sunburnswere irish okay irish also mean accommodating a crowd thats ranged from  to  guest sometimes cousin bring date sometimes the baby are kept at home a differential of three table of diner and on any given year the crowd age range might span four generation and eight decade meaning that both accessibility and entertainment become heightened component of the operation ive watched my mother every year a she performs this seamless calculus and have absorbed what i hope is some secondhand prowess hosting a midwestern gathering is a deeply gratifying exercise you just have to think like a guest to do it right a a gift to the most entertaining averse among you here are some prized learning from my family hearth and home to yours  establish a debooting zone you never want to tell guest exactly what to do but a big rug on the front porch piled high with others snow caked uggs and wellies might send the message that youre not too jazzed on all that sludge tracking through the house besides who can get comfy while bound to wet heavy footwear which brings u to the next tenet  enact a b y o s policy thats bring your own slipper not a an enforced rule or anything just start the trend by showing up to family party with cozy footwear in tow it both a courtesy and a compliment you keep the host floor slush free and show them just how comfortable youre made by their hospitality the trend will gain traction among your cousin and youll be in fuzzy slipper all night everyone win  get creative with the overflow seating piano bench and ottoman not only fulfill their duty a extra chair but also seem to delight the younger kid who will all scramble to fill those seat first maybe forking up mashed potato from these tiny upholstered pouf throne provides a transgressive thrill  deploy every possible tactic for keeping guest out of the kitchen cooler full of beer water and soda back porch wine glassware and corkscrew on the sideboard appetizer living room coat on the bed in the guest bedroom trash recycling next to the sideboard or in the hallway or in the laundry room or out back brought a dish of your own the hostess will take that to the fridge for you you just worry about getting yourself some chicken dip which is far away in the living room guest seem preternaturally attracted to the kitchen and tend to drift toward it until the room is so packed that new arrival must fold into the paper thin crevice of free space that remain it both a nuisance and a fire code violation and if left unchecked these crowd will cause the kitchen to swell and burst into a shower of splintered wood smashed brick and stainless steel shrapnel if you want thanksgiving dinner to materialize you need room to open your oven and so youve got to keep everyone out of the kitchen by supplying almost no incentive to head there almost because of course theyre going to want to say hello to the head chef  embrace culinary cacophony there a debate that rage in the far corner of foodie internet should dinner party guest be invited to contribute dish of their own or will this disrupt the harmonious composition of the meal the host ha planned i bite my thumb at the latter camp at least when it come to thanksgiving dinner it a time for belly bursting comfort not culinary mastery there going to be an excess of everything salty side starchy main sickly sweet salad made primarily of marshmallow the dessert will be disproportionately chocolate and beverage offering include beer wine and bailey thanksgiving is a day for family whomever we embrace a such and there nothing you wouldnt do for familyeven if that mean forgoing an interesting new recipe because you know it wont play a well a the cranberry sauce youve made every year since   also enact a b y o t policy bring your own tupperware in the interest of letting not one spoonful go to waste guest should feel free to arrive armed with plastic tub aplenty to fill up with their favorite a they head out the door alternatively a host can take this opportunity to get rid of the many reusable thai container that have accumulated in their cabinet over the past year  then do it all over again my mom little stroke of genius the black friday meal invite family and friend to head over after any potential shopping spree for a lazy casual afternoon complete with platter of reheated leftover and a yet unsliced dessert because no holiday ought to last a single measly day there are many more trick up this midwestern sleeve serving hot appetizer in one of these placing a dining table directly in front of the couch so diehard neednt pull themselves away from football and so on but the only indispensable advice is this make thanksgiving what you want it to be cling to the tradition that delight you and not a single one that doesnt define family and dinner table and saying grace and side salad however loosely befits your holiday i promise your guest wont leave feeling burned by the discord of multiple cheesy potato side they likely love you too much to scrutinize and theyll drift off into a pleasant starchy slumber a soon a they cross their own threshold cheer to a party well thrown

column2: today march  is the spring equinox in the northern hemisphere day will start getting longer night shorter and warmth will flood the land to celebrate this shift go outside tonight and check out the supermoon which will coincidentally be lighting up the sky it a rare occurrence for a spring equinox to correspond with a supermoon according to national geographic it hasnt happened since  and wont again until  supermoons themselves arent so rare there have already been two this year space com explains that the supermoon is an optical illusion created by the moon orbit around earth which is more oval than circular a supermoon occurs when a full moon coincides with the moon perigee or the point in it elliptical orbit at which it is closest to earth this make the moon appear up to  percent larger and  percent brighter than usual however this is the last supermoon of  it also special because it a worm moon nbc news report that this moniker come from an old folklore story that a full moon during this time corresponds to the ground meltingand all the earthworm start moving around again the farmer almanac shared this story about the name a the temperature begin to warm and the ground begin to thaw earthworm cast appear heralding the return of the robin for this reason the march full moon is often known a the full worm moon you can look up the time that the moon will be rising in your area on time and date and with clear sky you should be able to bathe in the glow of a new season happy spring

column2: image copyright twitter realalexjones the u did not descend into a second civil war on  july why is this news because right wing u broadcaster and conspiracy theorist alex jones told his   twitter follower to expect exactly that with a dire warning issued three day before breaking democrat plan to launch civil war on july th according to jones anti republican element were massing to overthrow president trump on independence day the democratic party did not comment but on twitter jones claim inspired an explosion of parody letter from the front using the hashtag secondcivilwarletters my dear john began twitter user amanda blount the war isn t going a planned our supply truck are limited i m out of wine and sunscreen the enemy burned all the book and there is no place to recharge my kindle the only music is an old cd of justin bieber all is lost skip twitter post by amandablount my dear john the war isn t going a planned our supply truck are limited i m amandablount july   end of twitter post by amandablount others followed with report of the imaginary action my love i m unsure you will ever read this rued tweeter tschudidavai i wa captured at the battle of starbucks and have been forced to watch the duke of hazard for what feel like eternity when i asked for water i wa given budweiser when i asked for bread i wa given kfc dear heart today we took a captive we forced him to do hard labor so far he ha baked  gay wedding cake wrote amandadeibert while many tweet preserved the brave but dolorous tone of real letter from america s civil war others imagined a better fate for the democrat general rodham we have gained on the enemy by building a wall of your email which they can t get over crowed lhannich in a nod to the clinton email saga online war however raged on

column2: image copyright epa image caption local have been warned to expect more heavy rainfall a cyclone that wa predicted to wreak havoc across queensland ha been downgraded to a tropical low after unleashing cm  in of rain in two hour across the north of the state authority warn that cyclone owen could still reform offshore on monday severe weather and flood warning are in place owen hit land a a category  cyclone at around   on saturday   friday gmt km  mile from kowanyama we were right in the bullseye but then it dipped and went south the town s mayor michael yam said there s no structural damage a little debris we re all good and in one piece the cyclone s km h mph wind weakened a it moved south east queensland s emergency service received  call for help over friday night according to local outlet news com rescue service are warning that heavy rainfall and flash flood could still follow between now and tuesday please do not be complacent particularly in that northeast tropic area where the rain will continue queensland fire and emergency service commissioner katarina carroll said the weather system is expected to reach the north queensland town of ingham and innisfail by early sunday meteorologist predict it will move back out over water before tracking down the state s east coast australia frequently experience extreme weather with flash flood sandstorm and drought in some area last month queensland wa hit by destructive bushfires which forced the evacuation of thousand of people

column2: but m orlandersmith dig deep enough into each character and with such decency that no segment seems obligatory even the worst human among them a vile racist and homophobe called dougray is allowed his back story which help explain if in no way excuse him photo among the character portrayed by m orlandersmith is dougray a racist who fantasizes about gunning down ferguson s black men credit sara krulwich the new york time still dougray who fantasizes about lining up ferguson s black male and gunning them down in order to make the town clean white purified like it must have been once threw me out of the play for a moment m orlandersmith is so skilled at disappearing into her character that i had forgotten until then what her process involved theoretically this wa a man she had interviewed stood near faced the psychological violence of that encounter seemed almost like a replay of the literal violence it wa meant to investigate later i learned that many of the character m orlandersmith portrays are fictional composite i m not sure whether that make dougray more bearable or le the idea that there are many dougrays available for compositing seems terrible if all too believable still i think that if the play informed audience about m orlandersmith s method it might help them better understand her aim some of her earlier work like the autobiographical forever are clearly factual however poetically the fact are rendered others like the pulitzer prize finalist yellowman are clearly fiction or perhaps until the flood is more effective for leaving you uncertain about which genre it fall into the production directed by neel keller carefully split the difference between documentary objectivity and poetic license on a set by takeshi kata replicating the impromptu memorial of candle and stuffed animal that lined canfield avenue in the week after mr brown s death m orlandersmith move from character to character with minimal fuss adding or subtracting a simple costume piece by kaye voyce but otherwise not attempting anything but verbal verisimilitude moody projection by nicholas hussong establish the location just a the lovely interstitial music by justin ellington establishes the elegiac tone despite this evenhanded treatment i found myself crediting the black character more than the white one no doubt this wa in part because white racism however outright or covert is a familiar gargoyle stuck with it one leer m orlandersmith s black character are much more nuanced and able to explore theme that coming from white would seem taboo one of those is raised right from the start by a black retired schoolteacher named louisa hemphill acknowledging the damage done by racism she grew up heeding sign that said don t let the sun go down on you in this town if you re black she nevertheless concludes that mr brown wa not only set up to be a victim but also set himself up several other character echo this thought hassan describing the routine threat of death from police violence say there is a part of him that want to stand before a gun knowing that the redneck holding it would aim to shoot and not miss and when paul a  year old who life a mr brown did in the defeated canfield green apartment cry please god let me get out he mean get out alive those are two of the saddest line you are likely to hear from a stage today and therefore two of the most important composite or not they ring damningly true category off broadway play solo performance credit written and performed by dael orlandersmith directed by neel keller column2: not all the school being closed are in renewal among the school slated for closure is the urban assembly school for wildlife conservation in the bronx where this fall a high school student who said he felt bullied stabbed two other student killing one of them a student in the middle school said he tried to hang himself in february because he had been so tormented by his peer the  school that will begin their transition out of the renewal program will be called rise school the education department said these school each met at least  percent of the goal set for their improvement and a a group saw growth in measure like graduation rate attendance and college readiness among those school are the renaissance school of the art in manhattan and john adam high school in queen graduating school will remain in the city s community school program which creates partnership with social service organization to help with thing like the attendance and supporting the social and emotional need of student aaron pallas the chairman of the department of education policy at columbia university s teacher college said that many renewal school principal have been ambivalent about the program they ve been happy to have the extra resource that come with it but the label ha been somewhat stigmatizing so what will those school look like when the extra money go away that is an interesting longer term question about sustainability mr pallas said to what extent doe this program really hinge on the influx of dollar and if those dollar are removed what is going to happen agustin armendariz contributed research continue reading the main story

column2: shifting terrain a early a  the woodland filed a plan for a new subdivision on thousand of acre containing wooded area and a few rural home site according to document obtained from harris county but it wa not until the year leading up to  when the hughes corporation put together the final piece of it purchase of the woodland that the housing market caught up with the plan houston shook off the wreckage of the subprime mortgage crisis and encountered a very different problem a shortage of housing on the high end of the market touching off the surge in demand wa an announcement by exxon that it wa opening a new corporate campus in nearby spring exxon wa far from alone a a growing list of company relocated to the area so did ten of thousand of worker drawn by the boom in fracking technology that none other than mr mitchell and colleague had coaxed tweaked and perfected over nearly  year that influx would have all but saturated the existing home market said bill gilmer director of the institute for regional forecasting at the university of houston it drove a spike in land price allowing developer to consider new construction on relatively low cost lot that previously would have been too costly to improve this would just give you the opportunity to make those extensive improvement and still come out ahead mr gilmer said fema map of the woodland showed a tantalizing stretch of undeveloped land hard by a waterway called spring creek including acreage in the  plan building right along the creek would have been out of the question but farther south portion of the land were slightly above the  year flood plain according to the map those who knew the land and it history saw warning sign nick rife whose family owned land in the area said he used to hunt there when it wasn t flooded by bringing in thousand of dump truck load of dirt it would be possible to expand the acreage above the flood plain making the whole area suitable for construction that is exactly what the woodland decided to do document show the former edge of the flood plain run through what are now the lot of m martinez and mr hickey the longtime woodland resident who once worked for mr mitchell and had built a new home in the neighborhood on the strip of land containing wood drake place m martinez s street   cubic yard of dirt were laid down fema approved a map change for that area on feb   document show the large extrusion of development around lake reverie place mr hickey s street and the nearby sundown ridge place got   cubic yard of dirt on june   fema approved a map change for what would become lot for the  home in those area the result neighborhood that seemed safe from flooding when esteban and paola seaez moved into their home next to spring creek in  their mortgage company assured them that the plot wa high and dry when the couple asked about flood insurance they said you don t even have to purchase it m seaez recalled photo the view outside m martinez s second floor window this week credit ilana panich linsman for the new york time last year after water came within several foot of their door mr hickey s neighbor james and gayle soeder inquired about flood insurance initially the agent warned that the policy would be very expensive the house wa in a flood plain she said mr soeder who knew he had bought a home at the  year elevation asked her to check again we see that the flood plain wa revised recently the agent said so for a bargain rate of   per year the soeders became one of the family in the neighborhood to be covered by insurance when harvey struck a number of resident asked whether manager of the woodland since mr mitchell had been a careful a it predecessor in designing the newer development and pointed to what they called more aggressive policy since the howard hughes corporation a brand revived in  by the activist investor bill ackman took over mr hickey dug into damage statistic and found that his recently constructed neighborhood flooded at far higher rate than others in the woodland in older part of the community his research revealed about  out of   home flooded during harvey or le than  percent a far smaller percentage than many other community in the greater houston area yet among home built in more recent year in harris county  out of   flooded or more than  percent in the newest area of that harris county expansion including those where the soeder the hickey and the seaez family live  out of   home were affected a whopping  percent mr hickey questioned whether adequate measure had been taken in the fill project to provide water storage and drainage in big storm marc crudgington who bought his home the year after m martinez and her husband did voiced similar concern they ve filled in lake that have been around forever just so they can build on them and clear cut tree like nobody s business he said our name for it is not the woodland it s concrete land the company stated that the senior development team is essentially the same team that ha worked on the woodland for  year tim welbes co president of the woodland development company said the company had complied with fema standard for it home but that the neighborhood had been overwhelmed by the storm s water we met the standard he said this event exceeded the standard still at a recent meeting of the woodland storm drainage task force resident expressed anger at local official over the damage to home from hurricane harvey and for many of them from earlier flood this task force wa actually formed last year in response to previous flooding and little had been done to improve the situation before harvey continue reading the main story

column2: the record setting flood deluging the midwest are about to get a lot worse fueled by rapidly melting snowpack and a forecast of more rainstorm in the next few week federal official warn that  million people in  state face a risk through may floodwaters coursing through nebraska have already forced ten of thousand of people to flee and have caused   billion in damage the national oceanic and atmospheric administration issued it spring flood outlook thursday predicting that two third of the country is at risk of major to moderate flooding from fargo north dakota on the red river of the north down to nashville tennessee on the cumberland river the flood from the past two week have compromised  mile of levee in nebraska iowa missouri and kansa according to the u army corp of engineer the rain and flood are expected to continue through may and become more dire according to ed clark director of noaa national water center in tuscaloosa alabama this is shaping up to be a potentially unprecedented flood season clark said with more than  million people at risk for flooding in their community a combination of heavy snowfall in late february tropical rain and wet snow from the bomb cyclone that swept across the country a week ago and frozen or saturated ground surface have set the stage for the flood ice jam on top of frozen waterway are adding to the problem by diverting floodwaters out of river channel and sending them onto land it not looking like we are going to see any dry stretch anytime soon say thomas graziano director of the water prediction center at the national weather service official say the entire mississippi river basin ha received  time a much rainfall a in a normal year and it s not done falling yet more rainstorm are expected to hit the midwest over the next eight to  day that precipitation will be like water running over concrete graziano say graziano say he expects this year flood level to top the disastrous flood that hit the missouri river in may  and the red river in north dakota and minnesota in  this winter big snowpack is fueling the flood in the eastern dakota and minnesota more than  inch of snow remains on the ground the missouri ohio and mississippi river drain the central united state but it take several week for the water to travel downstream in the meantime emergency official are warning local resident to make an evacuation plan a well a purchase flood insurance in certain area climate scientist say it s too early to tell exactly to what degree human induced climate change ha affected this spring flood cycle but they note that the watery disaster is following a pattern of extreme weather event across the united state there s about  percent more moisture available in the environment a a result of global climate change say kevin trenberth a senior scientist at the national center for atmospheric research in boulder colorado under the right condition that extra moisture can be amplified into  percent more rainfall during an extreme weather event such a a hurricane bomb cyclone or the series of storm that ha hit the midwest trenberth explains the extra fuel from global warming is what keep a storm going he say and it s what turn it from a billion dollar disaster to a   to   billion disaster more great wired story
column8: police now have a final death toll for the grenfell tower fire

column2: you can see it on satellite imagery a chaotic blur of wind and water shaped like a giant alien starfish over australia extending a tentacle diagonally across the pacific and right into the golden gate it s called an atmospheric river over a thousand mile of water and wind this weekend is going to be a wet a an entire typical april on the official scale the storm will probably top out at strong it might have enough water vapor transport to rate a extreme but probably won t reach exceptional the real freak out level of flood danger that mean several inch of rain this is how california get most of it disastrous flood but also most of it drinking water it s a crazy way to do business but understanding these atmospheric river might be the key to making sure the human race doesn t die of thirst atmospheric river come ashore on nearly every west facing coastline on earth a few time a year one of them doe what this weekend s storm will do shotgun over hawaii and into northern california it tail all the way back into the tropic almost to the date line say michael anderson the california state climatologist it s going to come through pretty quick onshore the fast wet air from one of these so called pineapple express ricochet upward off the coastal mountain range like a tennis ball catching the top of the net the air rise the water fall that s called orographic enhancement and it s how you get massive burst of rain and flood somewhere between  and  percent of california s entire water supply come from atmospheric river storm and they are intense in one study of six year of california rainfall monitored hour by hour just   hour qualified a atmospheric river storm but that scant   percent of time accounted for over  percent of the rainfall the researcher measured california hoard more than half of that rain a snowfall on the top of the sierra the rest it try to save in reservoir a dozen big one and about  littler one scattered up and down the state in the rainy winter month the reservoir fill up ideally leaving space for the snowmelt to come in the summer ideally during the winter all the reservoir stay empty enough to absorb flood wave from storm but on april  that reserve space start being relaxed so they can capture snowmelt anderson say with a storm this time of year you still have that flood reserve space so there s room for the reservoir to catch that water the question will be a that reserve space is being relaxed can that water be kept for the conservation pool it s a balance hold onto water for a rain free summer and possible drought be ready to capture snowmelt but leave enough room to store a flood wave during the storm season every reservoir ha a rule curve that say how much water is too much but atmospheric river can make it tough to know when to apply those rule in november and december of  the lake mendocino reservoir absorbed water from two atmospheric river event enough so that the water encroached into the flood pool which is supposed to stay empty for emergency so the reservoir operator released the water it wa the prudent thing to do say f martin ralph a research meteorologist at uc san diego s scripps institution of oceanography but nobody knew that there would be no more atmospheric river basically for the rest of the year and that wa the beginning of the drought they never had a chance to refill the reservoir in the spring so ralph along with the sonoma county water agency which regulates the drinking water in lake mendocino the u army corp of engineer which operates the flood prevention aspect of the reservoir and the national oceanic and atmospheric administration which monitor the salmon fishery that s part of the lake s hydrology are all working on a finer grained system it s possible that with modern weather prediction we can see with some certainty these atmospheric river coming a few day ahead so hypothetically one could consider keeping some of that extra water temporarily and every day looking at the forecast to see if there s an atmospheric river ralph say if there s not the chance of there being a flood problem is essentially zero the idea s still in a planning stage ralph s group is now trying these forecast informed reservoir operation at mendocino and prado in southern california it s still status quo ante at other reservoir like like oroville where the people in charge will be trying out their new spillway rebuilt since the old one crumbled during last year s rain but if the new approach work and so far it seems like it may reservoir can keep the water for a not rainy day that day may be coming or it might not water in the american west wa variable and unpredictable even before human started pumping enough carbon into the atmosphere that it d change the climate a warmer atmosphere hold more water vapor that by itself would strengthen atmospheric river but a warmer atmosphere mean warmer pole which reduces the temperature difference between the middle of the planet and the end that mean weaker wind and weaker ar however there s a big asterisk on that it s inevitable that some storm will be just a strong in term of wind a they are today and they will have available to them more water vapor ralph say there could be a class of atmospheric river storm that are a lot stronger than we ve seen in the past ralph s idea for managing reservoir better might end up being a necessary adaptation to a changed climate and not just in california the northwestern u get a quarter to a third of it annual rainfall from atmospheric river and they cause flood there too arizona s and idaho s big winter flood are often due to atmospheric river a few year ago one even caused major flooding in nashville they are the column2: today in a press conference new york attorney general eric schneiderman elaborated on his office s effort to investigate the fcc s flood of fake anti net neutrality comment while calling for a delay of the agency s vital net neutrality vote until the source of the fraudulent comment is identified schneiderman joined a group of  senator who are also calling for a delay on the december  vote that is widely expected to repeal obama era net neutrality rule schneiderman wa joined on stage by democratic fcc commissioner jessica rosenworcel an obama era appointee who wa reappointed by the trump administration it is incumbent upon the fcc and all of my colleague to stand back figure out what s in this record before u and get to the bottom of these stolen identity said rosenworcel schneiderman added that the feedback system wa corrupted a fact that he accuses the fcc of being well aware of according to schneiderman the net neutrality feedback process generated more than  million total comment marking an unprecedented level of participation his office suspect that a many a a million of those comment are linked to stolen identity including a  year old who never submitted a comment a recently deceased woman and the office of the attorney general s own assistant press secretary he called on government official in other state that with resident that appear to have likely victim to get involved including california missouri texas ohio and pennsylvania schneiderman cited report that that half a million of the comment appear to have been filed from russian email address a fact that net neutrality advocate likely hope will stoke further public interest in the often dry proceeding of the communication regulatory body further schneiderman note that   consumer complaint are missing from the fcc record the new york attorney general s office ha been working on getting to the bottom of the fake fcc net neutrality comment controversy for month last month schneiderman criticized the fcc for it failure to cooperate in his office s ongoing investigation into the fake comment which it began in june making repeated contact to the fcc over the subsequent five month last week schneiderman set up a website that allows new yorkers to report if their name and identifying info wa misused to make a fraudulent net neutrality feedback comment appear legitimate last month a dataset analyzing the fcc s net neutrality comment between april and october of this year revealed that over a million anti net neutrality comment that flooded the fcc s system appear to have been sown by spambots while a many a  of the legitimate comment were voicing their support of net neutrality there s no way with this set of corrupted record we can have a vote based on what the american people really think schneiderman said featured image bryce durbin techcrunch

column2: finding setting that amplify an opera drama ha long been mr einhorns mission since  on site opera which he helped found ha put on production in unusual space including the bronx zoo shostakovich the tale of the silly baby mouse a church crypt gregg kallors the tell tale heart and madame tussaud rameau pygmalion but in telling the story of the crippled shepherd boy amahl and his life changing encounter with the three king drawn by the star of bethlehem mr einhorn decided to find not only the right place but also the right people speaking of the background of his amateur chorister who will share the stage with professional musician mr einhorn said he had taken care to be sensitive to who these people are and never to go into an exploitative territory in how we talk about them or how we fold their experience into the production itself printed program will reflect some of the biography of the singer but even without these audience member may pick up here and there on the sign of past deprivation that appear etched into face the four year she spent on the street of new york have certainly left their trace on laura oday  whose lined feature broke into a smile a she spoke about her participation in the opera in an interview

column2: storm can destroy your home and level your neighborhood but even after they pas flooding present unique danger you might not be aware of even walking through water it turn out can kill you it s grim to think about but on the other hand a little preparedness might save your life on subreddit lifeprotips user u daynanfighter explained why it s best to use a little boat to get from place to place even if it seems like the flooding is walkable for those in flooded area use extreme caution when walking on street and sidewalk manhole cover are often forced off by the flood and can be extremely dangerous a people can fall in get trapped and drown i m from new orleans where flooding is common rising water in sewer offen move manhole cover opening to the sewer creating a very dangerous situation especially when water is being pumped through the sewer a in during a flood it creates underground river and people fall in and drown use a boat whenever possible while crossing flooded urban area and use extreme caution when walking they also recommended bring not only food and water but an axe if you re fleeing to the top level of your home if the flooding is bad enough you could drown in your attic with no way to escape if you don t think you could hack through your own roof consider the potential that the water might get higher before going to an upper story in the comment people shared other hidden danger to be aware of when traversing a flooded neighborhood including snake user u how about no bitch gave a very in depth analysis of how dangerous waterlogged snake actually are and a reminder to be aware in general of wildlife they say snake are for the most part trying to escape a well so just stay out of their way here s how just be aware of your surroundings and watch where you put your finger and opening door be careful around thick brush or low hanging branch this is relevant to any flooding you are going to see a whole lot of animal you didn t realize were nearby also for fuck sake watch out for fire ant floating island they will be more likely to fuck up your day more than most other animal other important mention the flood is almost certainly not composed of fresh running rainwater it s a mix of water and sewage which mean you could easily make yourself very ill while wading in it also keep in mind downed power line several people wrote they knew of folk who had been electrocuted while trying to escape their home large body of water even brand new one created on your street often have current that could sweep you away there will also be sudden rising water at time so what seemed traversable will be suddenly much le so but if you must walk through use a probe ahead of you and cover up a much a possible to keep contaminated water out according to u noyzmaker don t walk in flood water at all unless you have boot or hip wader to keep all the water off your person most of that water is contaminated and a simple cut or scratch can easily get infected also always use a walking stick or other type of probe to test the stability of the space in front of you will keep you from getting stuck in sudden mud or open manhole cover like op mention since even something small like a water meter cover getting lifted can catch you off guard and twist your ankle the general message don t walk around unless you absolutely have to

column2: the amount the ground can soak up is limited because it is so wet but thats a lot better than having it frozen because frozen ground is like a parking lot mr pearson added water just flow right off over all he said the storm doe not seem a powerful at this point a the march tempest but it still ha a lot of moisture and lot of potential to cause a lot of problem he said it still going to pack a punch forecaster say that for a storm to officially qualify a a bomb cyclone the atmospheric pressure must drop at least  millibar in  hour creating a particularly strong and rapidly intensifying storm this one might not produce quite that steep a pressure drop they say but temperature are set to plunge quickly just the same a a low pressure system drawing in moisture to the midwest is displaced by a high pressure system full of colder air omaha for example is predicted to see it daytime high temperature fall from almost  degree on monday to about  degree on friday the bigger flood risk this time may center on the mississippi river and it swollen tributary rather than the missouri river where level have been receding said jeff berardelli a meteorologist it will be a more prolific snow producer and a more blinding blizzard than the bomb cyclone wa mr berardelli said of the new storm partly because it may idle over much of the midwest for a time it likely going to slow down and stall he said literally the storm will barely move but like mr pearson mr berardelli said that a higher proportion of snow than rain may be a good thing if it melt over a longer period of time that would be better he said we dont want it all happening in a day or two

column2: many of the levee usually earthen and topped with grass were built by farmer decade ago and are now managed by a patchwork of local government agency known a levee district that often do not coordinate or even follow the same rule with increased flooding in the past few year the levee are being tested more frequently than ever before straining the finance and expertise of some of those district the levee situation ha become so grave that the american society of civil engineer gave the country levee system a d grade in  suggesting   billion in investment over  year when the next one come along bigger they either fail or are overtopped again said nicholas pinter an expert on river and flooding at the university of california davis according to the united state army corp of engineer which oversees infrastructure on the missouri river and some of it tributary at least  levee had been breached or overtopped in the midwest in march and hundred of mile of levee had sustained damage when they run water over the top of them there not anything you can do said pat sheldon the president of a rural levee district in southwest iowa that wa still paying off repair from the  flood this time mr sheldon said the damage to the levee wa much worse perhaps in the hundred of million of dollar it terrible said mr sheldon whose farm wa also cut off by the water in missouri mr bullock pointed out a levee that last week had been split open and consumed by the river a large log swirled in the water near where the earthen berm should have been i dont know what were going to do this time he said the army corp of engineer which help determine water level by operating a series of dam on the missouri river try to balance the need of many who use the river it manages including farmer barge shipper endangered animal specie and people who use the water for recreation those interest are sometimes at odds and have been the subject of decade of litigation corp official say they are not allowed to change the congressionally authorized purpose of the reservoir though they had been most focused on limiting flood for the past year the corps no  priority in it operation is life safety said maj gen scott a spellmon the corps deputy commanding general for civil and emergency operation in a statement our current focus is to protect life mitigate risk to flooding event and repair damage due to the recent event in the basin

column2: a hundred of million of people flood social network tech company are struggling to weed out harassment on their platformsand so theyre turning to machine for help on tuesday instagram announced it wa doing just that while the majority of photo shared on instagram are positive and bring people joy occasionally a photo is shared that is unkind or unwelcome instagrams new lead adam mosseri wrote in a blog post we are now using machine learning technology to proactively detect bullying in photo and their caption and send them to our community operation team to review instagram allows user to report account that show the intent of bullying or harassment which are against it community guideline though it unclear a it stand how effectively and quickly such account are penalized or shut down mosseri noted in tuesday blog post that many people who experience or observe bullying dont report it and that rolling out these machine learning effort alongside human one will help the team identify and remove significantly more bullying this new tech ha already been deployed and will continue to roll out in the week ahead according to the company instagram will also add it bullying comment filterwhich hide comment containing attack on a person appearance or character a well a threat to a person well being or health to all live video it already available in instagrams feed explore and profile section the service also added a kindness camera effect to spread positivity this is mosseris first announcement for the photo sharing service since it original founder contentiously departed last month instagram which is owned by facebook ha hardly earned it parent company reputation for serving a a catalyst for psychological devastation violence and the destruction of democracy but it still ha it issue with bullying at the top of that list research from anti bullying non profit ditch the label last year found that of   respondent aged  to   percent said they had been bullied on instagram it ranked a the number one social network for cyberbullyingslightly higher than facebook itself while leaning on algorithm for help with issue at such a large scale isnt inherently a bad thing it also far from a sweeping solution algorithm arent free from bias and they currently lack the ability to understand the nuance and context of human language theyve screwed up in the past and they have yet to prove theyre equipped to flawlessly tackle an issue a expansive complex and sensitive a cyberbullying
