column2: conspiracy theory are dusted amid the violent video racist comment and death threat that facebook moderator face every day that putrid flood of information can be traumatic a the verge s casey newton found when he reported on the working condition endured by moderator in phoenix arizona some of the worker bombarded with conspiracy theory told newton that they were starting to believe the idea they were seeing what make people start believing that the earth is flat or that   wasn t a terrorist attack and in this case did the stressful working condition have anything to do with it to answer some of those question we turned to mike wood wood a psychologist at the university of winchester study conspiracy theory and how they spread from the fringe to the mainstream the verge spoke to wood about the current research into conspiracy theory and whether there s anything people can do to make themselves le susceptible to them this interview ha been lightly edited for clarity you ve done quite a bit of research into conspiracy theory can we start with the basic what exactly is a conspiracy theory i m not going to look into whether it s true or not that everybody in the government is a lizard person we re going to start off real complicated right off the bat nobody can agree on this if you ask different people in different academic field they re going to give you different answer a a psychologist i m not going to look into whether it s true or not that everybody in the government is a lizard person i m just interested in why people would accept or reject that idea so for me a conspiracy theory is a secret plot by powerful people or organization working together to advance some kind of sinister goal through deception if you ask other people they ll give you other definition like a philosopher would say that a conspiracy theory is any theory about a conspiracy which i think is probably too broad and doesn t fit how most people would use the term in the verge s recent article on facebook moderator the fact that these worker started believing in the conspiracy theory video that they were being asked to moderate really stood out to reader is that propagation by exposure something that you ve seen before in your conspiracy theory research how do these thing spread the exposure aspect is interesting in this case we ve got some data on this from   conspiracy theory showing that one of the big predictor of whether or not somebody will believe a particular conspiracy theory is how much they ve been exposed to it conspiracy theory can be appealing to people for a lot of reason the problem is that this is all cross sectional data we just have one point in time and we know that the people who believe these theory have more exposure to them than the people that don t we don t know if that s because they believe them and then they seek them out because they want to know more or if they saw this stuff and then that convinced them of it it sound like this might be a case where people were exposed to it for long period of time and that actually induced them to believe in it so there s a causal aspect to this that we haven t had in the research before but there are other study where people do these experiment where you get people to read a conspiracy theory passage a little passage about how princess diana wa secretly killed by queen elizabeth and you can see that that ha some influence on people it change how they think about the issue in the short term at least we certainly see those effect but this is an interesting sort of long term exposure effect that we saw in these moderator other research ha shown that being exposed to fact doesn t seem to change people s mind do we know why people being exposed to conspiracy theory in particular make people believe them exposing people to information is going to affect them in some way or another we all like to think that we re immune to this stuff but it doe have an effect i don t know that conspiracy theory have a uniquely powerful effect to them where conspiracy theory can seduce people is when you have a conspiracy theory that is very appealing to you on the basis of other thing that you believe we all like to think that we re immune to this stuff let s say that you re a huge supporter of donald trump and you come across a conspiracy theory that say all of the people who are his rival his political enemy people that he doesn t like are all super evil and are working together to engage in satanic child sacrifice this is something that perhaps would appeal to you because of the other thing that you believe it wouldn t appeal to somebody who doesn t like donald trump at all and is probably quite ok with his enemy just being normal people it ha to be congruent to some extent with the other thing you already believe but conspiracy theory can be appealing to people for a lot of reason it could be because it make sense of something that they had trouble to coming to grip with before it could be a way of dealing with some type of uncertainty feeling like they have lost control with what s happening to them or a rationalization of some failure they ve had or some defeat their side ha suffered in an election the other aspect of this story wa the mental health effect of watching horrific video all the time would stress play a role in this kind of thing if they re being exposed to stressful video and then have conspiracy video thrown in yeah there is some work on this conspiracy theory do associate with stress basically there s been some research that s showed that when people undergo a stressful life event something like death of a family member divorce major disruption to their life conspiracy theory are more likely in that circumstance so there is some indication that psychological stress can put people in this place where they re looking around for new answer or they re possibly trying to come to grip with the world in a new way we ve got other research showing that when someone doesn t feel in control of their life or in control of what s happening to them conspiracy theory seem more plausible and that might have been what s happening with these people i m not sure what their subjective psychological experience wa at the time but there is some data that suggests that can happen conspiracy theory have been around for a long time but social medium is a relatively new invention in the span of human history how ha it changed the way conspiracy theory spread it s made them a lot more visible for sure if you would read the local newspaper  year ago you wouldn t have the comment section at the bottom saying this is all lie and that s what they want you to think but if you read a lot of local news now or you go to social medium or your twitter feed you ll see that that s a big change i think the information doesn t spread in such a top down way a it did before there s always going to be a hierarchy of how information get out there but to an extent it s more democratized now given that we are online constantly whether for job or social life is there any way to combat or insulate yourself from these kind of misinformation or conspiracy theory or is it just part of the ecosystem now it s hard to not come across it at all i would say there are step that you can take to make sure that the information that you re getting is a good a it can be a lot of that is just finding reliable source of information and making sure that you re not classifying it a reliable just because it flatters what you already believe because again that s where a lot of conspiracy theory come from they play off preconception that people have and make them more vivid there are study showing that if you get people to think carefully about thing and not just go with their gut they re going to be le convinced of conspiracy theory conspiracy theory tend to have a much easier time finding purchase in your mind if you have a very intuitive approach to something if you just say ah that sound right that feel right to me that s when conspiracy theory are going to be most convincing to you it s really easy to believe crap because crap is appealing people can go with their gut feeling because they are distracted or preoccupied or don t have time to look into everything nobody ha enough time to look into everything you just have to find people who are good thinker and figure stuff out and try to do it yourself a much a you can and put in the effort how much effort doe it take for our brain to push back on our gut it take effort for sure it s really easy to believe crap because crap is appealing in a lot of way you can get into this default mode where you settle on your ideology or you settle on you belief and you don t critically reflect on it and that s very easy to do fighting against that is difficult and it feel terrible sometimes but it s what you have to do in order to make sense of the world and make good decision in term of what s true and what s not

column2: whoever thought we would leave telemarketing behind in this brave new smartphone world of ours lacked imagination robocalls are a menace growing in volume and even a massive   million fine leveled against a prominent source of them by the fcc likely won t stem the flood the fine wa announced today during the fcc s monthly open meeting a mr adrian abramovich wa responsible for nearly  million robocalls over a three month period and will almost certainly be bankrupted by this record forfteiture our decision sends a loud and clear message said fcc chairman ajit pai in a statement this fcc is an active cop on the beat and will throw the book at anyone who violates our spoofing and robocall rule and harm consumer that sound impressive until you hear that these call took place in  and meanwhile there were   billion robocalls made last month alone commissioner jessica rosenworcel applauds the fine but question the practicality of pursuing damage when action need to be taken to prevent the crime in the first place let s be honest she wrote in a statement going after a single bad actor is emptying the ocean with a teaspoon she point out that a set of rule designed to prevent robocalls wa overturned a couple month ago and that  petition to the fcc under those rule for legal exemption and such have yet to be addressed and a technology designed to prevent robocalls altogether recommended in a report more than a year ago and currently set to be implemented in canada in  ha no such date here in the state a someone who get these robocalls all the time i fully support both this fine and the more serious measure rosenworcel suggests and the faster the better i literally got one while writing this story

column2: in many way it s the best of time and the worst of time to be a venture capitalist while money continues to flood into silicon valley the math keep getting harder to square at what point do rising valuation stop making sense how much mental bandwidth doe one spend on blockchain technology can the world handle another softbank megafund these are among the many many question we have for a distinguished panel of top investor who are coming together at our giant disrupt sf show on september   to discus what s happening on the ground and how they stay above the fray among our guest megan quinn a general partner with the venture firm spark capital who over the year ha become a well known in startup circle for her wit a her insight about company building among her recent tweet any time a late stage company tell me and we ve never done any marketing it ha the opposite of the desired effect marketing whether acquisition brand performance etc is a core competency at pretty much every company of consequence building for the long term quinn know a thing or two about what company need to grow having led a number of early stage and growth consumer investment for kleiner perkins prior to joining spark and before that spending year in product development at both square and google she s also a straight shooter when it come to talking trend asked about softbank s   billion vision fund at a smaller event in san francisco last year quinn wa candid about the impact it is having on later stage fund like the one she is leading readily noting startup that have met with spark and other firm about a sub   million round before softbank ha entered the picture and is like here s   million do these baby buyout a she d characterized them at the time make sense we ll ask her we re also excited to welcome sarah tavel a harvard philosophy major turned longtime venture capitalist whose star in the venture industry ha been on the rise for year first at bessemer venture partner then greylock partner and most recently at benchmark the storied venture firm which convinced tavel to join it rank last year she became it first and currently only female venture partner in between her venture stint tavel wa also among the first product manager at the digital scrapbook pinterest after falling in love with the platform when it wa run by five people and joining the company after convincing her colleague at bessemer to lead it series b round that turned out to be a pretty fantastic move for bessemer and for tavel who wa hired back out of the company by greylock now tavel ha fallen in to love with crypto recently making her first bet on the sector with chainanalysis which work with law enforcement agency on virtual currency crime among other thing can benchmark which ha seemingly approached crypto at arm s length stomach much more we ll ask her last but not least we re thrilled to welcome aileen lee the longtime kleiner perkins investor who left in  to form her own venture firm cowboy venture and who helped inspire a new generation of woman led venture firm in the process lee who ha worked with bloom energy on the cusp of going public dollar shave club acquired by unilever for  billion in  and accompany acquired in may by cisco ha more recently helped pioneered something perhaps even more powerful than any individual firm a network of female vcs who quietly began coming together last year to help elevate other woman investor and entrepreneur their express mission doubling the percentage of woman in vc partner role over the next decade and increasing total funding to female founder by  percent within five year called all raise the community which started with  woman and grows by the day is actually hosting a three part workshop for woman founder over two day of disrupt you can learn more about that here in the meantime we ll be talking with lee about what she s seeing at the early stage consumer and enterprise company with which cowboy venture meet are valuation up or down ha the market cooled a is widely believed can silicon valley firm ignore what s happening elsewhere especially in china we ll ask her if you re looking to better understand what s happening behind the scene in venture capital you won t want to miss this conversation taking place on september th the first day of disrupt the full agenda is here pass for the show are available at the early bird rate until july  here

column2: the worst disaster in california s history wasn t an earthquake or a fire or a drought it wa a flood that killed thousand wiped out mine and ranch and submerged the state capital sacramento for  day starting in december  california wa inundated today hardly anyone think about the floodwaters that turned california s central valley into a vast lake but it will happen again it s not a question of if but when writes seismologist and disaster expert lucy jones in her new book the big one how natural disaster h ave shaped u and what we can do about them that s why it s key for u to know about the disaster in our history so that we re not doomed to repeat them on what will certainly be a much larger scale after all more than  time a many people now live in california a did during that deluge jones writes what s at risk in disaster is not our individual life it s the future of our community while natural hazard are inevitable the destruction they wreak is not jones say in an interview with the verge we can make choice about how we handle that but we have to think ahead she say working at the u geological survey jones led a team of scientist who investigated the potential catastrophe in california s future one of them wa a flood and the team discovered that our existing flood control strategy would be no match for a deluge nearly the size of the one that started in  the disaster would cause more devastation than an earthquake on the infamous san andreas fault after  year at the usgs jones retired and opened the dr lucy jones center for science and society which aim to boost community resilience using science in her book she lay out catastrophic disaster in human history from the volcanic eruption that destroyed pompeii to hurricane katrina to the tohoku quake in japan in  she tell both the scientific story of how disaster unfolded and the human story of the community they struck we have to think ahead her goal is to teach reader about disaster by drawing them in with narrative and to address the way human nature can make it harder to prepare for the future most of u assume a big disaster is going to be similar to smaller one we ve experienced which can make u overconfident in our ability to deal with catastrophe something expert call normalization bias our tendency to focus on more immediate threat can also come at the expense of preparing for more distant one which make sense jones say if you worry about the  year flood and not about the wolf that s about to eat your child your dna doe not get passed down she draw on her experience a a scientist and a a communicator who helped the public make sense of the destruction in the aftermath of earthquake the verge spoke with jones about natural hazard risk assessment and the disaster that haunt her this interview ha been edited for clarity and brevity i grew up in california and only learned about the   flood last year how do you keep the memory of such a major disaster fresh and make sure that people don t forget that this could happen again photo by helen berger dr lucy jones it s very difficult to do in a natural world if we hadn t built all of our flood control system we would have smaller flood much more often when you have the smaller one at least you know that flooding is a risk but you do tend to believe that the risk is what you ve already dealt with so paradoxically the flood manager who were fully aware of the  flood seemed more willing to say we ve got it covered that isn t really going to happen again and like with earthquake i find that the people were actually part of a response to northridge a quake that hit part of the los angeles area in  are much more overconfident about their ability to handle the really big one because they feel like they dealt with the really big one and that that wasn t the really big one doesn t get through hundred of year ago we didn t have the information to be able to think ahead now we have more information and yet we still struggle with the emotional aspect of it because it doesn t seem real to u and that right there is the challenge of natural disaster we know what they re going to do we know how to build to avoid the damage but everything about human nature keep u from looking forward for that really long term planning so it requires much more rational logical thought and reasoned discourse so how do we now wrestle with the human inability to think ahead and also to remember the past around the world people are more concerned about tsunami risk than they were before because of globalization and improved telecommunication we now have a situation where a flood or a big disaster somewhere else in the world is something we can experience in real time one of the most striking example of that wa the tohoku earthquake in northern japan in  i m sitting in my living room in california and i can turn on the tv and watch in real time the tsunami wave and we see the people fleeing from it from the air we don t have enough to save them at this point but we watch them in real time suffer through this now around the world people are more concerned about tsunami risk than they were before i would say fifteen year ago it wa rare to find a person who knew what a tsunami wa but between the indian ocean event in  and japan in  and the really direct emotional experience with the power of telecommunication we have a really different understanding and experience of it and that is allowing u to overcome that normalization bias and it s part of the reason that we ve been able to make progress here in southern california with getting people to take the risk seriously and doing something about it for u it isn t about tsunami it s mostly about earthquake the book is divided by chapter into case study of different disaster through history which one kept you up at night which one haunted you the  mississippi flood the greatest flood disaster in american history mississippi is a huge river system that drain the majority of american state a huge rainfall starting in the fall of  through winter and spring led to failure of the levee protecting the land around the mississippi river and   square mile were flooded and over  million people were flooded out of their home over   people were living in refugee camp what really haunted me wa seeing how awful we were to our fellow citizen but what really haunted me about it and made it by far the most difficult chapter to research and write wa seeing how awful we were to our fellow citizen what happened to african american victim of the flood wa appalling and just the inhumanity of how they were treated the kanto earthquake which wa only four year before that wa also in japan an equally horrible turning on neighbor and it wa recognizing that part of the human experience is the need to find a reason why it wa the victim s fault to blame the victim because if it wa the victim s fault then i can protect myself by not making those same mistake it s a subconscious response to fear i don t want that to be able to happen to me so you find reason that it s the victim s fault and at the worst level you then punish the victim of the situation so when you ask what haunted me i m an earth scientist so the physical part of it wa all what i understood and expected going in what haunted me and inspired wa sometimes the horribleness of human response and sometimes the real inspiration of human response and you see both in those story the book talk about the disconnect between the language scientist use and the language the public use s to talk about disaster scientist have their wind speed for hurricane magnitude for earthquake probability for flood then the public asks wa it the big one how do we bridge that gap and do we need to i just see people talking past each other so much the stuff i put in this book none of it is really hard to understand a high schooler could easily read the book and understand it maybe even somebody younger and yet we don t teach it and therefore the public doesn t have a context within which to be getting the information or having the discussion so we need better education in science which doe not mean learning a bunch of fact the other part is to understand how to think about science the fundamental of science a a process for learning what s really true we don t teach that but then we also need to help the scientist understand that people are looking for a mix they want the science but they also want the human side of it and we need to help the scientist do a better job of being to answer the human question i just see people talking past each other so much you write about how being a seismologist give you an unusual perspective on time and that a forecast that a disaster will happen sometime in the next millennium sound not like an evasion but like a threat how ha this perspective shaped your own relationship with risk are you resigned to it or have you bought every kind of disaster insurance there is the earthquake s absolutely inevitable but chance of it in my lifetime the earthquake s absolutely inevitable but the chance of it in my lifetime well the san andreas is probably going to have an earthquake in my lifetime but the fault i live near probably isn t so yes it s a possibility but i just have to keep it balanced because it s a relatively low possibility compared to other thing people assume that where i live must be a place that s really safe from earthquake but we moved to a community with really good school sitting right on top of a significant fault we were basically gambling that an earthquake wouldn t happen before the kid got out of high school and it worked climate change is going to make meteorological disaster more frequent and more devastating right what do we need to do to make sure that we re prepared it s going to be very difficult people do not sufficiently understand what we are doing to ourselves with this we need to do everything we can to stop adding carbon to the atmosphere and reduce what s already there if it s at all possible because more heat in the atmosphere doesn t just mean it s warmer and oh i guess i can handle that that mean more energy to drive storm and they are going to be getting worse that doesn t stop the hurricane from getting stronger so first off we ve got to admit it we can t talk about nuisance flooding because high tide is bringing it into your house without thinking about what that mean when the hurricane come through one of the big issue in america is that we have a pretty strong tradition of individual land right nobody get to tell you what to do with your own land we are really struggling a a society to be able to make those big scale decision we need to be changing our attitude about community how much we share to accept that we re dependent on the decision of others we don t like to do that a american either we so prize our independence so we philosophically oppose that but that doesn t change what s going to happen that doesn t stop the hurricane from getting stronger if there were one thing you wanted your reader to take home about this book what is it you have choice that hazard are inevitable and the disaster is not we a a society have choice both what we do individually but also a choice to work together the thing that came out of it for me is that what s at risk in disaster is not our individual life it s the future of our community and we can change that if we can work together a a community

column2: in the state appeal titled a is the other indiana case box v planned parenthood of indiana and kentucky indiana complains that the appeal court said nothing about the ultrasound utility in helping woman to come to a better more informed abortion decision the state claim that planned parenthood which operates the four abortion clinic could mitigate this burden by equipping it other reproductive health center around the state with ultrasound equipment while the state defends the ultrasound requirement a protecting fetal life and dignity a well a maternal mental health it doesnt explain how the new  hour requirement improves on the old law no matter it not hard to envision five justice using this case to whittle down the undue burden standard a the supreme court applied it before justice anthony kennedy retirement last year and a the seventh circuit ha been applying it in recent month the court will consider this case in april after it receives planned parenthood response to the state petition of all the recent ruling the decision that took me most by surprise and give me the most concern wa handed down two week ago by the united state court of appeal for the sixth circuit the court upheld an ohio law that bar state public health money from going to any organization that performs abortion for any organization read planned parenthood which receives no public money for abortion but that for year ha administered government grant for six public health program including h i v testing cancer screening and sexual violence prevention planned parenthood is the largest provider of h i v testing in cleveland akron and canton it performs abortion at three of it  clinic in the state after then gov john kasich signed the law in  planned parenthood sued on the ground that the state wa imposing an unconstitutional condition by requiring it to forfeit it right to provide abortion in order to remain eligible for the unrelated public health grant a federal district court barred the law from taking effect in a decision upheld by a three judge panel of the appeal court but fortified by the addition of four trump appointed judge the full court reheard the case and voted  to  to reverse the panel and uphold the law with all the new judge in the majority i found judge jeffrey suttons opinion for the court astonishing he wrote that planned parenthood had no right to invoke the doctrine of unconstitutional condition because while woman have a right to obtain abortion neither planned parenthood nor any other abortion provider ha the right to perform them a he explained if there no right there no unconstitutional condition and the provider have no such constitutional right judge sutton named to the appeal court by president george w bush is a thoughtful conservative whom ive long respected ive struggled to understand what led him to his conclusion since the earliest year of the supreme court abortion jurisprudence both the supreme court and the lower court have regarded doctor and clinic a standing in the shoe of their abortion patient entitled to assert right that individual woman are highly unlikely to be in a position to assert the precedent are clear on this crucial point in case after case court after court a judge helene white wrote in dissent an abortion provider constitutional right may be derivative of the patient right but it is a right nonetheless she continued the majority reasoning contorts a doctrine that aim to prevent the government from manipulating right out of existence to permit the state to leverage it funding to launch a thinly veiled attack on woman right so long a it camouflage it unconstitutional condition in provider focused verbiage on monday of this week a federal district judge in north carolina william l osteen jr struck down that state ban on abortion after  week of pregnancy finding that doctor themselves had standing to bring the case because of their plausible fear of prosecution if they interpreted the statute health exception too generously in the view of state prosecutor i dont know whether planned parenthood will appeal the ohio decision planned parenthood v hodges it received little attention not surprisingly a framed by the appeal court it not the kind of issue that sends culture warrior to the barricade but there no chance that the justice will miss it significance is it the small target case they have been waiting for could be a my favorite poet edna st vincent millay wrote in an obviously different context ti not love going that hurt my day but that it went in little way the time is committed to publishing a diversity of letter to the editor wed like to hear what you think about this or any of our article here are some tip and here our email letter nytimes com follow the new york time opinion section on facebook twitter nytopinion and instagram

column2: like the initial hq plan today news that amazon will no longer be setting up shop in queen ha been met with a flood of mixed reaction business advocacy and real estate are decrying the retail giant decision to pack up and leave i know ive been flooded with response from various corner all afternoon local politician on the other hand appear to be placing the news squarely at the foot of amazon in a statement provided to techcrunch mayor bill de blasio took amazon to task for the move in a customary bit of new york saltiness you have to be tough to make it in new york city we gave amazon the opportunity to be a good neighbor and do business in the greatest city in the world the mayor stated instead of working with the community amazon threw away that opportunity we have the best talent in the world and every day we are growing a stronger and fairer economy for everyone if amazon cant recognize what thats worth it competitor will of course de blasio wa key in amazon initial decision the mayor wa condemned by many quarter for what wa regarded by many a closed door dealing involving among other thing massive tax break for the company a mere three day ago he called the plan mission critical the mayor current take appears to be something more along the line of yeah well we didnt really want you here anyway speaker corey johnson on the other hand wa one of the deal most vocal opponent from the outset happily grilling amazon rep at city council meeting over concern around tax break infrastructure and the company longstanding opposition to employee union i look forward to working with company that understand that if youre willing to engage with new yorkers and work through challenging issue new york city is the world best place to do business he said in a statement provided to i hope this is the start of a conversation about vulture capitalism and where our tax dollar are best spent i know id choose mass transit over helipads any day predictable the city s wing of the dsa wa similarly in a celebratory mood the impending amazon deal wa far from the only way capitalism is oppressing working class queen resident and new yorkers it said in a statement million of new yorkers still lack any basic tenant right and live with the threat of rent hike displacement and eviction every day

column2: google is hosting it annual cloud next developer conference in san francisco this week while the event is still in full swing with a mystery concert capping off most of the programming tonight the flood of news ha now subsided so here is our list of the most important announcement from the event anthos what is it anthos is the new name of the google cloud service platform google s managed service for allowing enterprise to run application in their private data center and in google s cloud google decided to give the service a new name anthos but also expanded support to aws and azure it competitor cloud platform this will allow enterprise to use a single platform running on google s cloud to deploy and manage their application on any cloud enterprise will get a single bill and have a single dashboard to manage their application all of this unsurprisingly is powered by container and kubernetes why doe it matter it s still highly unusual for the big cloud competitor to launch a product that allows user to run application on other platform the money after all is in charging fee for compute time and storage allocation google argues that this is something it customer want and that it solves a real problem google however is also chasing it competitor and looking for way to differentiate it approach from them i don t think we ll see aws and azure react with similar tool but if they do it s a good thing for their customer open source integration into the google cloud console what is it google announced that it would deeply integrate the product of a number of open source company into it cloud and essentially make them first party service these partner are confluent datastax elastic influxdata mongodb neoj and redis lab with others likely to follow over time why doe it matter these integration are a boon for google cloud customer who are likely already using some of these service they ll get a single bill and access to support from these company all while managing the service from a single console the subtext here though is a bit more complicated and reveals google s approach to open source and put it into contrast with aws many of the company that are participating here are highly critical of aws s treatment of open source and quite public about it google is working with them while the perception is that aws simply us the code and doesn t give back google s ai platform what is it google see it ai prowess a one of it main differentiator in it fight against aws azure and co the company already offered a wide range of ai tool ranging from developer tool and service for advanced data scientist to automl a service that can automatically train model and doesn t require a phd the new ai platform offer an end to end solution for more advanced developer that allows them to go from ingesting data to training and testing their model to putting them into production the platform can also use pre built model why doe it matter ai and machine learning is the major focus for all big cloud provider but the developer experience leaf lot of room for improvement having an end to end solution is obviously a major step forward here and open up the promise of machine learning to a wider range of potential user your android phone is now a security key what is it instead of using a physical security key to enable two factor authentication you ll now be able to use any android  phone a a security key too you set it up in your google account and your phone will then use bluetooth but without the hassle of creating a bluetooth connection to provide your second factor for now this only work with chrome but google hope to turn this into a standard that other browser and mobile operating system vendor will also support google also recommends you still use a regular key a a backup for that inevitable day when you lose your phone why it matter two factor authentication is inherently safer than just using a login and password system that use sm and push notification are still vulnerable to phishing attack while security key and this new android based system us the same standard a existing key prevent this by ensuring that you are on a legitimate site this new system take the hassle out of using a physical key and may just convince more people to use two factor authentication google cloud code what is it cloud code is a set of plugins and extension for popular ide s like intellij and v code the general idea here is to provide developer with all of the necessary tool to build cloud native application all without having to deal with any of the plumbing work and configuration that come with that using cloud code developer can simply write their application like before but then package them a cloud native apps and ship them to a kubernetes cluster for testing or production why doe it matter writing cloud native apps is complicated and usually involves writing complex configuration file cloud code ideally make all of this so easy that it ll be far easier for developer and the company that employ them to make this move to a modern infrastructure google cloud aim at retailer what is it the news here is that google is launching a vertical solution that s squarely aimed at retailer that doesn t sound all that earth shattering doe it but google cloud plan to offer more of these specialized solution over time why doe it matter google cloud ceo thomas kurian told u that customer are asking for these kind of integrated solution that package some of the company existing tool into integrated solution that these enterprise can deploy this is essentially the first time it is doing so with maybe the exception of healthcare but it ll likely offer more of these over time and they could become a major factor in growing the platform s user base bonus we also got a chance to sit down with google cloud s new ceo thomas kurian to put some of the announcement into context and talk about his vision for google cloud going forward

column2: whether it s by flood fire or the fury of a storm climate related catastrophe are now impacting most city and town across the country a these natural disaster increase in frequency and severity city and the business that reside in them are mobilizing to understand how best to prepare for the climatological challenge they re going to face and increasingly they re turning to company like jupiter intelligence for information from office in san mateo calif boulder colo and new york jupiter intelligence ha made a business selling data from satellite imagery and advanced computer model to city like new york and miami along with the federal government and big insurance and real estate customer with it new financing jupiter plan to take it show on the global road and is bringing it service to client in rotterdam london and singapore it s a story that ha it root in over two decade of work from founder rich sorkin eric wun josh hacker and alan blumberg wun and sorkin met in  in the early day of the development of mapping and weather prediction technology and got their start in the business co founding zeus a weather prediction technology developer that wa pitching it service to commodity trader zeus wa way too early from a technology platform perspective say hacker we put zeus on the shelf eight year ago then when we came up with the idea for jupiter most of the early idea were already there in the interim hacker served a the president of kaggle a company google acquired back in  by that point hacker had already left to launch jupiter which he started in  while zeus predicted the thirty day weather for commodity trader jupiter is a more powerful toolkit that predicts the possibility of damage from severe weather and climate change for a much broader set of customer hacker say wun and sorkin were on board immediately and the next person to join the fledgling team wa hacker who had run satellite operation for skybox another google acquisition following the merger of skybox with planet lab hacker took a job at the national oceanic and atmospheric administration within the department of commerce one of the pre eminent organization focused on climate change the final recruit wa blumberg who wa approached because of his role in developing the princeton ocean model which is used by over  research and operational group in  country and his leadership position in developing  hour and  day flood prediction for port authority of new york and new jersey storm surge from hurricane sandy in new york city after it launch the company wa able to land three big insurance company qbe mistui and nephila which all agreed to throw cash into the company s new   million round jupiter s predictive and analytics technology have application far beyond insurance airport port power plant water facility hospital municipal and even the federal government are turning to the company for information according to sorkin jupiter raised  million in it seed round from dcvc data collective and then closed on   million more from ignition partner the latest   million wa led by energize venture a fund focused on infrastructure and climate related investment systemiq which wa co founded by mckinsey veteran jeremy oppenheim also invested in jupiter series b the architect of mckinseys sustainability and resource practice said in a statement for a decade the planet ha needed the kind of repeatable globally consistent insurance grade analytics jupiter now delivers photo courtesy of shutterstock the toolkit that the company pitch doe purport to offer new level of granularity and insight into the kind of threat climate and weather related disaster post to government and private asset we predict probabilistically at the asset level at the loading dock of a warehouse or a transmission box or a hotel on the beach we determine the actual expected risk in a form that the insurance industry or the risk manager at an organization can use and integrate into their plan say sorkin the company s process begin with global climate model and then drill down into a specific region which is used a the basis of predicting peril like event according to sorkin that go into a statistical model which translate the prediction into a form that quantifies the uncertainty and in a way that s tailored to decision maker he said using apis from mapbox the company can also provide a mapping interface that give customer visualization along with a product that let user see what damage can look like inside of a building through virtual reality and a collaboration with oculus the strategy wa to start with one peril in one place in one market so we started with flooding in carolina for the real estate say sorkin we have expanded into much broader peril and geography and market segment for all of the time that sorkin spends modeling out how city will meet their doom in one form of cataclysm or another jupiter s chief executive is fairly positive about the prospect for society to withstand the climate threat it currently face even with all the bad thing that could happen we dont think the apocalypse is inevitable sorkin say the extent of damage is a function of how much people invest in avoiding it over the next decade

column2: resident and local press in maryland posted frightening footage of destructive flash flooding on sunday following heavy rain across the state particularly affected wa ellicott city located about  mile west of baltimore which suffered intense flash flooding along it main street the very same street that wa turned into a raging river amidst a torrential flood in  which killed at least two people see also fighting climate change could save the world trillion of dollar the video and image are quite devastating especially for a community that endured this only two year ago developing column2: image copyright afp image caption the zoicu canyon is near soccia a mountain village a flash flood in a canyon ha killed a father his seven year old daughter and two other people on the french island of corsica a fifth person in the french hiking group a woman is still missing rescuer resumed a search for her near soccia on thursday seven tourist were canyoning with a guide when a wave about m ft high hit them a corsican prosecutor said the guide wa among those killed two were rescued from the torrent image copyright afp image caption firefighter resumed a search for the missing woman early on thursday french medium report that the seven were abseiling rappelling into the zoicu canyon a famous beauty spot part of which are only accessible with rope the canyon is at an altitude of  m  ft in a mountainous area and is a popular spot for hiking kayaking and canyoning which can involve ropework technical climbing and swimming there wa a storm alert in place at the time of the flood on wednesday and five other hiker including the seven year old s mother had turned back earlier the french news website le point in french report that a guide from another hiking group threw a rope into the torrent to rescue two from the group in trouble afp news agency say it is france s worst canyoning tragedy since march  when four people died in an accident on the indian ocean isle of reunion

column2: when official will send high priority warning during tsunami blizzard tornado hurricane extreme wind condition storm surge snow squall and flash flood in new york flash flood warning are the most common said nelson vaz a warning coordination meteorologist for the weather service on day like today the weather service s forecaster are constantly monitoring rainfall rate and the affected environment if they feel the rainfall rate are going to exceed the ability of the ground to absorb that rainfall and you re going to see a threat to life and property from flooding that s when the forecaster will issue a flash flood warning mr vaz explained how the warning are issued from the national weather service s office in upton n y using computer software called warngen which allows the forecaster to create the text of the message describing the location and hazard for example and to target the geographic area where the flooding is expected to happen the technology called wireless emergency alert is the same tool that can push out amber alert or emergency warning from the president at   p m on oct  the trump administration is planning to send a test presidential alert

column2: the authority evacuated people in lahaina in west maui after a brush fire ignited and spread quickly on friday the cause of the fire wa not immediately known five tourist from california were rescued from a flooded vacation home in hilo on thursday according to the associated press a slow moving storm can lead to a lot more rain the fact that lane is moving slowly about five mile an hour mean that it is likely to dump large amount of rain in june our reporter kendra pierre louis looked at a study published in the journal nature that focused on what is known a translation speed which measure how quickly a storm is moving over an area say from miami to the florida panhandle between  and  tropical cyclone translation speed declined  percent worldwide the study say the storm in effect are sticking around for a longer period of time lingering hurricane can be a problem a texan learned last year when hurricane harvey stalled over the state causing devastating flooding and billion of dollar of damage the storm dropped more than  inch of rain in two day and nearly  inch over four day in some place a report released by harris county which includes houston found that harvey s rainfall exceeded every known flooding event in american history since  the storm wa approaching hawaii on wednesday read more about the danger of lingering hurricane here it s been a year filled with emergency for hawaii first came an errant alert that a ballistic missile wa headed for hawaii then  inch of rain were recorded in one day on kauai flooding part of the island next a slow motion eruption of the kilauea volcano ravaged part of the big island now the state is facing it latest potential calamity hurricane lane on thursday we spoke with hawaiian on the big island who were dealing with the deluge and those to the north a they prepared for their own lashing of strong wind heavy rain rough surf and rising water for many of the island resident it wa hard to believe that a hurricane would make a direct hit when they have been spared so many time in the past still some people prepared with a sense of urgency i m normally not a person that make sure my gas tank are full and everything is all settled and organized but i totally organized and brought everything in and my chicken are in the garage said heather nelson  who work in event production and life in volcano hawaii on the big island in kalapana suzette ridolfi a teacher who evacuated her home a kilauea wa spewing lava said the volcano wa may more scary with the volcano there wa no rest she said it wa intense intense intense and the intensity never slowed down a bit and with the hurricane passing there s big rain and heavy rain and we get really scared for a few minute but then it stop and it s peaceful it s calm photo employee of a honolulu hotel filled sandbag in preparation for the storm credit john locher associated press read more about the multiple threat faced by hawaiian this year here the storm put a damper on thousand of vacation the five california tourist rescued from a vacation home on thursday were a minuscule slice of the   tourist estimated to be on hawaii the state had a record year for tourism in  according to george szigeti the president and chief executive of the hawaii tourism authority who said thing had continued at a steady clip in  despite the drumbeat of bad news it s been a very active year mr szigeti said but i would tell you hawaii is a very resilient destination tourist who wanted to cut vacation short early may have found it difficult to do so mr szigeti said because so many flight were already full doug okada the general manager of the aston waikiki sunset a towering hotel in honolulu said his  unit were full this week since it wa high season some visitor had canceled incoming stay but others had extended them because they did not want to fly out during the storm we just have to do our best to get through this said mr okada who wa urging guest to shelter in place some guest have never been in a hurricane situation so it s a thrilling experience i m glad they are positive but they ve been warned not to go out in dangerous condition meghan miner murray barbara tanabe john schwartz kendra pierre louis and matt stevens contributed reporting continue reading the main story

column2: there is nothing wrong with this or with thinking about this it doesnt reveal a superficiality or lack of substance which is often the default fear when the topic of clothing come up on the contrary it acknowledges the truth that we all make snap judgment based first on appearance and then make a choice about how much time and brain space need to be devoted to influencing those judgment and how much can be delegated this should be something everyone can relate to given the current craziness around dress code in general be it the complete nonsense of event that request creative dress or dress to impress or the difficulty of corporate stricture on dressing appropriately in an office setting a word so vague that it is practically meaningless yes goldman sachs this mean you to a certain extent we are always in search of dress recommendation and instruction a the social and professional code of yesteryear have eroded under the increasing commingling of life and work putting an end to unspoken uniform thats why stylist and personal shopper have become such a booming business increasingly famous in their own right in many way politics ha been the most insulated of all profession but clearly even that is changing and really if there is such a thing a a courtroom stylist can a political stylist be far behind this is essentially the role meredith koop played for michelle obama though officially her job wa general aide and how herv pierre function for melania trump

warned of a race against time to rescue flood victim on sunday a emergency response team in the country s western region search for at least  missing after flood and landslide caused by torrential rain killed over  people see also california s wine country fire ha been brewing for year since the downpour started thursday evacuation had been ordered for up to   million people in  prefecture according to the japan time but this ha been scaled back to  million since the weekend the fire and disaster management agency is reported to have counted over   people accommodated in temporary evacuation centre a of sunday some of the affected area include kyoto yamaguchi ehime fukuoka kagoshima hyogo shiga gifu kochi and saga with the hiroshima and okayama prefecture among the hardest hit it s the worst weather related disaster in the country since  when nearly  people were killed by two typhoon in august and september the time report over   people in okayama found themselves trapped column2: after intensifying overnight hurricane michael is now pummeling the florida panhandle a a category  storm the strongest hurricane on record to ever strike the region hundred of thousand of people have been ordered to evacuate a michael s wind top speed of  mile per hour nbc news report storm surge is expected to bring flood water reaching  foot high and already there are life threatening storm surge and catastrophic wind moving on shore the national hurricane center say for those who stayed put it s time to seek shelter out of the way of wave and wind florida governor rick scott warned on twitter the time for evacuating along the coast ha come and gone an extreme wind warning is currently in effect for location between laguna beach and eastpoint until  pm et wind gust in excess of  mph are expected shelter in place immediately hurricanemichael pic twitter com jogpnwmwtv nw tallahassee nwstallahassee october   the storm is unusually strong because of a few thing warm water in the gulf favorable wind condition and humidity those are the perfect ingredient for a storm like this to really blossom say marshall shepherd director of the university of georgia s atmospheric science program and former president of the american meteorological society it s possible the storm could get stronger still before landfall the national hurricane center say and after hurricane michael hit shepherd doubt we ll see a hurricane with the same name again it s a life altering society altering situation he say storm of this magnitude and impact the name is typically retired and i fully expect this to be the case for michael the verge spoke with shepherd about hurricane michael s unprecedented strength this interview ha been edited for clarity and brevity how did hurricane michael get so strong overnight it s really blossomed into a category  and the primary reason are that it wa moving into very warm water which is somewhat unusual for this late in october it moved into a very favorable upper wind situation where there wa not very much wind shear and there s a lot of moisture in the eastern united state out ahead of a cold front that s coming from the west when michael wa further south it wa in a very difficult wind shear environment a you know hurricane don t like wind shear when the wind change direction or speed a you go up in altitude one of the thing that s really interesting about hurricane michael is that it wa very resilient it wa actually still intensifying even in an environment with a lot of wind shear which wa odd so i knew once it got into an environment with le wind shear and over warm gulf water the thing wa going to just explode and that s what we re seeing from space satellite from nasaearth noaa see hurricanemichael a a major hurricane in the gulf of mexico our latest space view http t co bvwmvayu latest storm weather from nw http t co qkxrndk be prepared fema resource http t co qcgbnvwh pic twitter com wfhovkgbu nasa nasa october   is there anything else that can explain how michael intensified so rapidly we ve been seeing these hot tower these tall thunderstorm that form in the eyewall of the hurricane i ve been talking about these since my day a a scientist at nasa because there are study that show that when you have these hot tower they re more likely to indicate that the storm will go through a rapid intensification phase because they re releasing so much heat that all that water vapor is condensing into cloud water in the storm when water vapor condenses to form cloud water it release this burst of heat called latent heat that s really the fuel supply for these hurricane heat engine when you have these hot tower they re like the supercharged piston in the engine if you will you ve got this ample warm water you ve got not a lot of wind shear overnight when the storm really intensified so you can have a very efficient engine where all this water vapor is being converted to energy what sort of hazard can we expect from the hurricane if it stay at this intensity and there s evidence that it s even still intensifying at this moment this is going to be the strongest storm at least on record to ever hit this part of florida i think a lot of time we can overemphasize or over play the wind threat in a hurricane i don t think that s the case with this one there s going to be significant wind impact not only at the landfall point and around the panhandle of florida because the storm is so large it s so strong and because of the pace that it s moving even inland in part of alabama and georgia there are going to be hurricane strength wind so the wind are going to be a significant impact the storm surge could be record breaking in the coastal region to the right of the storm we could be seeing record eight to  perhaps more foot of storm surge we can t downplay the rain it s not going to be a situation like harvey and florence where the thing stall out and dump three or four foot of rain but there still could be half a foot to a foot of rainfall and then of course to the right of the storm a it move into georgia and the carolina you ll get the tornado threat too it s a horrible situation is it late in the year to be seeing a hurricane in the gulf i thought we were past the peak of hurricane season keep in mind with water it take several month for the transition from cold to warm and warm to cold even though air temperature are starting to cool down the heat characteristic of water mean that the water ha residual warmth for a while that s why the peak of the hurricane season is typically in september even though the actual hurricane season start in june so there s this lag so the water are gradually starting to cool down from that peak in september but they re still typically warm enough to support hurricane we get hurricane all of the time in october that s not unprecedented and frankly when we do get october hurricane they form exactly where michael formed which is down in the southern caribbean and moving into the gulf this is exactly what we expect from an october hurricane i m just cautioning that there is nothing particularly unique about a hurricane in october that take this particular track but yes it certainly is interesting that it ha tapped into enough warm water to explosively develop how is climate change contributing to hurricane michael s intensification storm like this are undoubtedly pushing more water into the coast because sea level are higher so when we have these type of storm and storm surge the storm will be pushing a higher level of water than it would  or  year ago that is something that i m very comfortable saying but i think only the study over time will play out whether the warmer ocean because of our broader background climate change are fueling more higher octane storm physically we understand that that should be the case i want to clarify that we understand from a scientific standpoint that a warming climate is causing warmer ocean and you would think from a physic understanding of how these storm work that would lead to more intense storm whether i can say conclusively that that s why this particular storm is more intense i just think it would be irresponsible for me to speculate on that what s your advice to people in the area it s almost too late if you re in florida to do anything people should have been gone a day or two ago if they stayed in all we can do is pray and hope that they re okay a the storm move further inland i am concerned that people further inland in my state of georgia for example may not be really aware of the fact that they re going to experience strong tropical storm to weak hurricane force wind in some part well inland i think that might catch a few people off guard so hopefully they re prepared for long power outage perhaps tree falling down on their home or in their yard and for georgia i m even worried about crop damage that part of georgia is a very agriculturally intense region of our state it s harvest time for some crop so i even worry about that how fast are we expecting this storm to move through the region this storm is going to move quickly which won t mean four foot of rain like we saw in florence or harvey but the downside of a quick moving storm is that place further inland still feel the impact of a pretty powerful punch from the hurricane because it take a while to weaken this is a very different storm than a florence and a harvey but it carry it own unique threat because of the fact that place inland will see hurricane force wind or strong tropical storm force wind
column8: dead in avalanche outside aspen  sheriff

column2: the midwest flood continue to be a slow moving disaster town farm and infrastructure are still underwater in nebraska and water will take month to work through the vast network of river creek and stream that drain the upper midwest into the gulf of mexico the damage to the region could last much longer than that though it could require year to rebuild infrastructure but the real challenge will be restoring the region greatest resource the reason there are so many farm there in the first place it soil early estimate indicate the flood could be responsible for   million in crop loss in nebraska which sits at the epicenter of the flood that number could easily rise the longer floodwaters cut farmer off from field and prevent spring planting thats bad news for a state where one in four job are tied to or supported by farming according to the state department of agriculture state next door are dealing with their own varying level of crisis from river overtopping their bank even after the floodwater recedes the region farm and the soil theyre built on could face a long road to recovery spanning year or decade to understand why you have to understand how these flood happened after an extremely wet fall winter arrived with a fury repeated blast of cold froze the soil and heavy snow piled up on top of it then came the bomb cyclone a few week ago it unleashed a blizzard in western nebraska but the eastern portion of the state saw rain and lot of it nearly three quarter of nebraska weather station are seeing an increase in winter rain according to climate central full disclosure i helped with this analysis when i worked there a hallmark of the warming world soaked soil couldnt absorb the sudden influx of water and so it began to run off into river and stream scraping the earth away with it add in dam and levee failure and the torrent truly clawed away at the midwest most bountiful resource basically what it going to do is going to erode the most productive topsoil mahdi al kaisi a soil and water specialist with iowa state extension program told earther this is why we need to think about climate change more seriously thats become very destructive to this whole system and put a lot of stress on these surface it not even just the top layer of soil thats being ripped up and washed away where the floodwaters have receded huge block of soil have been gouged away the weight of the water ha also compacted soil in some location while others are covered in sand and silt thats been swept up by engorged river neither of which is a nutrient rich or structured a the soil that support the wheat soybean and corn crop you have the good stuff moving away and not a good stuff moving in andrea basche an agronomist and soil scientist at the university of nebraska told earther that put farmer who depend on growing these crop for their livelihood in a serious bind they can try to plant this year crop knowing productivity wont be a high a it wa or they can set about to the arduous task of restoring topsoil to a more productive state the first step is just letting field dry out something that could take week or even month farmer can ass how much sand theyre looking at though al kaisi warned that using heavy equipment to do those assessment could disturb or breakup any topsoil that is left for those lucky enough to be dealing with just a few inch of sand they can just churn it up into the soil but area with more than  inch of sand could be lost cause nebraska extension service suggests that farmer dealing with that situation c onsider the relative cost of moving the sand and of abandoning the crop area basche suggested that farmer could also use compost or restore wetland and prairie a other possible solution for rebuilding soil but it still could take decade to restore productivity if it is ever the same in our lifetime again that timeframe could mean many farmer and rancher end up walking away rather than deal with mounting cost or the specter of bankruptcy farm revenue in nebraska while important ha been declining and trump escalating trade war have sapped an estimated  billion from nebraska alone according to the american farm bureau though that number doesnt take into account program designed to offset loss the state of the soil only make the situation more dire all this reveals yet another way climate change is upending the system we rely on al kaisi said in the future farmer could focus on low or no till agriculture and planting cover crop could help mitigate some of the impact of flooding systemic change are also needed including rethinking flood protection a climate change ups the odds of heavy downpour and rain falling on snow it wa not designed to handle this john remus an army corp of engineer manager said in a new york time interview referring to the intricate series of levee and dam that normally hold back the missouri river and the system will only be further taxed in the coming month far from where the flood began this is shaping up to be a potentially unprecedented flood season with more than  million people at risk for flooding in their community ed clark director of national oceanic and atmospheric administration national water center said in a statement that went out with the agency spring flood outlook that outlook show that area all along the missouri and mississippi river face major flood risk through may meaning more field will face the scouring power of water we need to be really clear this is not just farmer problem al kaisi said this is society problem this post ha been updated to reflect basches expertise is in agronomy
column8: swiss alp avalanche leaf  dead   injured near glacier

column2: image copyrightaddy tritt several midwestern state are reeling from historic flooding which hit the area a few week ago thousand of people have been evacuated and vast swathe of farmland ha been destroyed for many in iowa nebraska wisconsin minnesota and south dakota the recovery effort ha been slow and painful a people return to their home a image of submerged farm were broadcast across the country many looked for way to help here are some of the act of kindness to emerge in the wake of the devastation any shoe are better than wet shoe when addy tritt  noticed her local discount shoe shop wa closing down she decided to buy out their entire stock m tritt then donated the  pair of shoe valued at     to family affected by the flood i wanted them to go to people who actually needed them m tritt told cbs news after spending two hour negotiating with the the shop s head office m tritt paid just    for the entire stock image copyrightaddy trittimage caption addy tritt donated  pair of shoe to nebraska flood victim of m tritt s haul  pair were baby shoe two were men s shoe and the rest were woman s according to the the associated press any shoe are better than wet shoe m tritt said if people feel lost they should try volunteering and donating it give me such fulfilment and i want others to feel the way i do the shoe were part of a shipment to nebraska farmer organised by a local student agricultural group nebraska governor pete ricketts said farmer were some of the worst affected by the most widespread destruction we have ever seen in our state s history island hopping in nebraska with many road in the region made impassable by floodwater some volunteer took to the sky to rescue stranded resident adam marshall ha been a private pilot for three year and when he started to receive call for help from people trapped in the nearby town of fremont he fired up his small propeller plane mr marshall told cnn that he ha made more than  trip and described it a island hopping in nebraska my phone just started blowing up and i told my wife i think i m going to be gone for a couple of day i transported the entire midland university dance team to omaha so they wouldn t miss their commercial flight and a woman named allie who ha five kid and had been cut off from her family he said surrounded by rising floodwaters gary fouraker wa rushed to hospital after doctor suspected he had blood clot in his lung however there wa no room for his wife marcia to travel with him in the helicopter i ve never been scared like i wa at that point m fouraker told cnn the road weren t open mr marshall came to her rescue delivering m fouraker to her husband s bedside an hour later i just really admire the way he and so many other pilot have really stepped up to help people m fouraker said most people had a look of relief when they got a ride mr marshall reflected i got a lot of hug the last few day i ve never escorted hay derek jilek from north dakota knew he wanted to help when he saw photo of flooded farm across the midwest he posted on facebook calling on his farm and ranch neighbour to donate a few hay bale to those who had been hit by the flood vast swathe of farmland wa destroyed by the floodwater and many farmer have struggled to feed their livestock what started a a small effort to collect donation turned into a nine truck convoy carrying thousand of dollar worth of farming supply and equipment i guess when you re helping or volunteering i always heard that you do what you know we know cow and we know trucking so that s what we did mr jilek told local news station wowt the convoy received a police escort for part of the  mile km journey with a new police department taking over a the truck crossed county boundary sgt dan kensinger from the stark county sheriff s department said this wa new to me we ve done funeral escort and various other thing i ve never escorted hay

column2: facebook which landed itself in the crosshairs after becoming one of the primary venue by which federal prosecutor allege a kremlin linked pro donald trump russian operation called the internet research agency tried to flood the u with disinformation and propaganda before the  election now say it will verify the identity of people who buy election related ad by mailing postcard per reuters facebook say the process will involve any advertising that mention a specific candidate but not general issue based ad the process of using postcard containing a specific code will be required for advertising that mention a specific candidate running for a federal office katie harbath facebook s global director of policy program said the requirement will not apply to issue based political ad she said if you run an ad mentioning a candidate we are going to mail you a postcard and you will have to use that code to prove you are in the united state harbath said at a weekend conference of the national association of secretary of state where executive from twitter inc and alphabet inc s google also spoke it won t solve everything harbath said in a brief interview with reuters following her remark according to reuters facebook say the mailer are the best solution they could come up with and that they would be in use before the  midterm election scheduled for november though russian group purchased around    in ad on facebook it also produced a much larger array of unpaid content for the site that eventually reached up to  million american on facebook and  million on subsidiary site instagram a number that sound large but is also a tiny share of the  trillion post american saw in their facebook news feed between  and  the washington post noted the share that were reached by the russian paid ad came in at just  million of that total federal law prohibits foreign entity from making any kind of expenditure or contribution towards any electoral campaign in the u a well a requires candidate committee party committee and political action committee to disclose how they spend money though growing amount of dark money spending by non profit group that don t have to disclose their donor is increasingly an issue according to the washington post however facebook s term of service stipulate that advertiser have responsibility for understanding and complying with all applicable law and regulation a news of the alleged russian operation ha alarmed legislator some commentator have characterized it response a intended to prevent any fix that could affect it highly profitable and largely automated targeted ad model for year bloomberg reported facebook ha long sought federal election commission exemption from political advertising disclosure and it policy of leaving compliance to ad buyer ha helped it generate hundred of million of dollar in political campaign spot since the new policy apparently only applies to ad directly mentioning candidate by name it would apply to many but not all of the ad purchased by the russian group during the election season news of the postcard announcement may have been briefly overshadowed however by trump s decision to retweet a facebook advertising executive who had tried to distance the russian operation from the outcome of the election reuters

column2: yellowstone national park is probably not about to erupt in an explosion that could wreck the immediate area and flood the state of wyoming with ash despite several unusual eruption at the world s largest active geyser over the course of the past few week per reuters scientist say that there is no sign the increased frequency of eruption at steamboat geyser is an indication the yellowstone caldera a massive volcanic crater formed by the last of three super eruption in the region from   million to   year ago is about to blow steamboat geyser which can shoot water a high a  foot  meter into the air erupted on march  april  and on friday the last time it erupted three time in a year wa in  the u s geological survey s yellowstone volcano observatory said the last time it erupted prior to march wa more than three year ago in september  there is nothing to indicate that any sort of volcanic eruption is imminent michael poland the scientist in charge for the observatory said in an email according to the bozeman daily chronicle the steamboat geyser eruption on friday wa reported by a park visitor and wa estimated to have begun at   am that person wa likely the only one who witnessed it firsthand since boardwalk leading to area are closed due to high snowfall poland told reuters the two april eruption were smaller than usual at the geyser but did eject approximately  time more water than old faithful the park s most famous geyser he added that geyser erupt sporadically and that the distribution of the latest event may simply reflect randomness a real indication of serious danger would be if the underground hydrothermal system beneath the park dried up which would indicate magma wa getting closer to the surface reuters added while it s been   year since the last major lava event in yellowstone the region is still very much active and pose the potential to erupt at some point in the future perhaps disastrously per the washington post an event in yellowstone could be thousand of time more powerful than the mount st helen explosion in  the united state geological survey predicts that a sufficiently powerful eruption while unlikely would leave much of the northern rockies buried in foot of ash lava flow could cover a radius up to  or  mile in diameter with disastrous accumulation of  or more centimeter in a radius of up to  mile that s a worst case scenario and scientist tend to emphasize that even a moderate volcanic eruption there is unlikely to happen in our lifetime recent computer model have shed some light on the structure of the magmatic system below yellowstone though scientist are still far away from predicting future eruption however yellowstone volcano observatory monitoring array would probably detect sudden or strong movement or shift in heat that would indicate increasing activity the national park service writes and that a catastrophic eruption would likely be preceded by week to year of warning sign reuters
