column2: the mid atlantic and northeast are in for a wild ride during the next few day a a nor easter rapidly intensifies off the east coast of the u s the storm will bring with it an array of life threatening hazard from record breaking coastal flooding and hurricane force wind to cement like wet snow that will bring down tree and power line the storm will undergo bombogenesis a process in which the minimum central air pressure will drop by at least  millibar in  hour in general the lower the pressure the stronger the storm the rapid drop in air pressure will kick up extremely strong wind which will help bring air travel to a halt in some of the biggest city in the country from boston to washington d c due to high wind and heavy precipitation see also dangerous storm target northeast mid atlantic with high wind coastal flooding inland snow along the massachusetts shoreline coastal flooding is likely to exceed all of the benchmark flood of the past including the blizzard of  and possibly the highest water level on record in boston which wa set earlier this winter up and down the coast of eastern massachusetts a  to  foot storm surge on top of high astronomical high tide coupled with angry sea with building wave will do significant damage to shoreline infrastructure including home and business a man walk through a flooded section of brant rock in marshfield mass on jan   a the afternoon high tide struck during the blizzard image john tlumacki the boston globe via getty image on jan  of this year boston saw it highest water level on record when the bomb cyclone hit the city that storm flooded a subway station and shut down portion of the city this event ha the potential to do even more damage in the low lying coastal city community to the north and south of boston will also see major coastal flooding on par with some of the biggest coastal storm on record cape cod look to be in line for some of the highest wind and wave and it beach are prone to erosion chart showing atmospheric spin at around   foot depicting a closed upper level low south of new england a telltale sign of an intense nor easter image tropicaltidbits com the overall weather pattern in which this nor easter is forming is going to prevent the storm from skipping east out to sea quickly this will heighten the storm s impact making coastal flooding last through multiple high tide a east to northeast wind drive water ashore in massachusetts part of long island new jersey new york connecticut and rhode island a sprawling intense area of high pressure parked over greenland is serving a a giant stop sign in the atmosphere pinning storm like this close to the u s coast such a high pressure area is known a a greenland block and it s a prerequisite for producing a severe winter weather event in the mid atlantic and northeast here s what to expect in the big city of the northeast along with more detail on the threat of heavy wet snow making it all the way to the coast which could spread power outage closer to highly populated area computer model projection showing sea level pressure and wind just above the earth s surface on march   image tropicaltidbits com washington d c baltimore and philadelphia in these city heavy rain on thursday night and friday along with extremely windy condition on friday will be the biggest impact from the storm some coastal flooding is possible in the philadelphia area a well wind gust could exceed  mile per hour on friday in the d c area a the region will be located between the deepening low pressure area offshore and high pressure to the west causing a wind tunnel effect new york city in new york the official forecast is for a sloppy messy windswept rainstorm the precipitation may mix with or change to snow at time but any accumulation are highly uncertain at this time it s possible that the storm will manufacture enough cold air through dynamical cooling to turn the rain to heavy snow late on friday into saturday morning which would create a host of problem in the city and nearby suburb but this is not a high confidence forecast scenario wind will gust to at least  to  mile per hour along the coast and moderate to major coastal flooding is possible at high tide which is also the case in coastal new jersey storm surge of   foot with big wave action is no joke take this storm very seriously if you are at the coast major flooding is expected and remember this flooding is for   straight tide cycle pic twitter com qvmxdprub eric fisher ericfisher march   hartford connecticut heavy rain and snow is expected from late thursday night through saturday in hartford snowfall amount however hinge on how much temperature cool down during the storm with anywhere from  to  inch of snow to a foot of heavy wet snow possible snowfall exceeding  inch could cause widespread power outage given the weight of the wet snow on tree and power line the halloween nor easter of  dumped about a foot of snow in hartford causing a weeklong power outage boston the strongest wind most severe storm surge and historic coastal flooding all appear to be focused on beantown and other location in eastern massachusetts wind could gust to hurricane force  mile per hour in the area and a combination of high astronomical tide a  to  foot storm surge and destructive wave are likely to produce historic coastal flooding in many area during multiple high tide coastal flood warning  am friday  am sunday severe damage to shoreline structure some home may be destroyed widespread inundation of coastal road basement life threatening situation many neighborhood may be at risk of being cut off for a time pic twitter com ieowceilh nw boston nwsboston march   like in new york city there is also a wild card of precipitation type in boston with some computer model suggesting that heavy rain will change to accumulating snow on friday night and saturday a the center of the storm drift further to the south the national weather service is using strong language to warn people about the likelihood of potentially historic coastal flooding from this nor easter calling it a life threatening situation a summary of talking point w the forecast high impact long duration coastal storm please take this storm seriously for those living along the coast this is a life amp death situation please heed the advice of local official pic twitter com joamnewsbl nw boston nwsboston march   it s not a coincidence that boston may set back to back record for it highest water level in the same year coastal flooding is an increasing hazard in the mid atlantic and northeast in part because of sea level rise caused by global warming higher background sea level make it easier for storm surge to break record and do more damage this is similar to basketball player competing on a court with a steadily rising floor making it easier for them to dunk over  foot significant wave height now forecast by ecmwf model for massive nor easter sea dramatically build in friday unfortunately with long duration component of direction perpendicular to the coast http t co xcmebejxko the worst wave look to impact bermuda too pic twitter com jsrogyqws ryan maue weather u ryanmaue march   other noteworthy aspect of this storm this nor easter will churn the water of the western atlantic creating wave higher than  foot across a vast swath of the ocean from nova scotia to massachusetts southward all the way to bermuda just off the massachusetts coast wave may tower up to  foot and some of the highest swell in year are likely well offshore any ship caught in it path could be in trouble a high wind and wave present a serious hazard cruise ship in particular have had a habit recently of sailing directly into powerful east coast storm hopefully that won t happen again this time

column2: advertising for the nun an upcoming horror film centered around the inexplicable suicide of a nun in s romania is predictably terrorizing but a youtube ad for the film ha seemingly crossed the line driving a flood of user to complain about it online and ultimately get it removed from the platform a tweet cautioning user about the ad had over   retweets a of tuesday morning last night youtube responded to the message stating that the ad violates our shocking content policy and it s no longer running a an ad asked for comment youtube confirmed to gizmodo the tweet wa accurate and the ad had been removed the ad in question is just a few second long and while horror is subjective it s easy to see why a lot of user would feel affronted by it the ad show an on screen volume indicator turning all the way down followed by a jump scare of a nun you can watch a re uplod of the ad here while the full trailer is longer and arguably more disturbing it s not served up to viewer who might just be browsing innocuous video online only to be interrupted by a screaming nun if i see the nun trailer pop up a another ad when im watching youtube imma throw hand im tired of getting scared in the middle of a james charles video one user wrote on twitter im literally shaking and tearing up right now i just wanted to play epiphany but why did youtube gave me a fucking the nun jusmpscare a an ad at  fucking am wrote another google youtube s parent company doe have an advertising policy that prohibits shocking content ad featuring violent language gruesome or disgusting imagery or graphic image or account of physical trauma a well a promotion that are likely to shock or scare are not allowed google list crime scene photo and execution video a case of the former and ad indicating that the viewer may be in danger be infected with a disease or be the victim of a conspiracy a example of the latter of course these are all real life horror not marketing campaign for a fictitious horror film but it s evident that content doesn t have to be nonfiction to appall it could just be a really fucked up ad this whole debacle is unsurprising given youtube s le than celebrated history of content moderation in june three parent reached out to the advertising standard authority asa a non statutory uk watchdog organization after their kid saw ad for a horror movie before kid aimed content like frozen song a lego tutorial and minecraft video one of the ad which were for insidious the last key allegedly showed a woman lying on a floor immobile bloodied and distressed while a humanoid creature crept towards her and then probed at her with claw like finger and pierced her skin according to the asa ultimately the asa told sony picture to ensure such ad weren t targeted at child in the future and aside from horror film youtube ha also spectacularly failed at moderating content related to suicide porn addiction and gun modification tutorial a well a disturbing content targeting child just to name a few polygon

column2: it becomes a kind of catch  said debbie walsh director of the center for american woman and politics at rutgers university one of their criterion is the issue of viability but without their endorsement viability becomes very tough because so many people use them a their barometer of oh doe this woman have a chance emily s list ha also faced criticism that it doe not do enough to lift up woman of color nina turner an african american former state senator from ohio who wa endorsed by emily s list when she ran for secretary of state in  said minority may face higher hurdle than white woman in raising money because they are le likely to come from wealthy circle i got the money late when i needed it early because they were judging my ability to fund raise more than where i stood on the issue m turner said adding i don t think they take into consideration the hurdle that black and hispanic woman have to jump when you judge viability m schriock said emily s list doe recognize the obstacle that are particularly in front of woman of color do we have to do more she asked absolutely a doe the party in the georgia governor s primary race and a chance to make history wa a big piece but not the only consideration in emily s list s decision to endorse m abrams who is african american m schriock said m abrams a former minority leader in the georgia house of representative ha a national profile and a longstanding relationship with emily s list which gave her it rising star award in  if elected she would become the nation s first black female governor she ha also outraised m evans reporting nearly   million in campaign contribution according to campaign filing in georgia compared with   million for m evans some political analyst say that m evans might have broader appeal with white moderate and thus a better chance of winning a georgia general election m schriock disagrees she say emily s list is counting on m abrams who is favored to win the primary to expand the democratic electorate by pulling in black and latino voter who might not otherwise go to the poll the georgia win list georgia s equivalent of emily s list ha remained neutral in the campaign for u to have chosen between the two it would have destroyed my organization said melita easter the group s chairwoman

column2: cnn a if one winter storm around the holiday wasn t enough a new one is taking shape for new year s eve bringing more heavy rain and a renewed flood threat it come on the heel of the deadly storm system that plagued much of the midwest south and east over christmas the worst is over a that storm push offshore into the atlantic but it killed at least six people in the midwest and south and brought blizzard condition a foot of snow and wind exceeding  mph to the great plain and upper midwest on thursday it then ripped across the east with heavy rainfall and wind on friday more than  million people were under the threat of flood with flood watch and warning stretching from the gulf coast to new jersey flash flooding affected southern mississippi and alabama triggering dangerous situation and high water rescue up to a foot of rain fell in le than a day the rough weather made holiday travel even more of a headache there were nearly   flight delay into within or out of the country friday according to flight tracking site flightaware a of saturday flood watch have been largely discontinued but there are still warning for some river in the south particularly across southern mississippi and alabama according to cnn meteorologist ivan cabrera i m not expecting the foot of rain some area in the southern u received cabrera said an additional  to  inch may renew flooding concern due to saturated soil some area in the south will in fact make a run for wettest year on record with the last few storm filling rain gauge to record level forecast radar image for saturday show rain persisting in coastal area of the southeast but it should clear out for inland city including atlanta and charlotte the letup won t last long however on sunday moisture emanating from the gulf of mexico will bring a band of shower to southeastern texas and then stretch across southern louisiana all the way up through the carolina then on the last day of  another storm will bring rain although le heavy to the north and east cabrera said condition will be wet but temperature will be mild in much of the southeast in the  and  and in the  in the northeast a new year s eve reveler welcome

column2: on wednesday san jose mercury news photojournalist karl mondon spotted a man in flooded guerneville california rowing through town in a blue dumpster a potent atmospheric river a long band of water vapor that often transport ample amount of moisture to the western u s like river in the sky deluged portion of northern california this week the russian river which wind through the sonoma county town of guerneville reached over  foot high and swamped the area prompting the sheriff to announce on twitter that the town had been surrounded by water with no way in or out while california relies heavily on these wintertime atmospheric river for it water scientist expect these storm to grow wetter a earth s climate heat up we re likely to see rain in increasingly intense burst daniel swain a climate scientist at the national center for atmospheric research said in an interview this really wa a firehose aimed at sonoma county swain added guerneville california feb  playland miniature golf course in guerneville california is enveloped in flood water before dawn from the rising russian river flood tuesday feb   photo by karl mondon medianews group the mercury news via getty image image medianews group via getty image the russian river flow under the old guerneville bridge image karl mondon medianews group the mercury news via getty image people gathered on a partially submerged rv in the flood water of the russian river image michael short ap rex shutterstock though it can be challenging to attribute any particular blast of rain to extreme weather stoked by climate change this destructive event doe have a telltale climate fingerprint it doe seem to be another data point suggesting individual atmospheric river are becoming wetter said paul ullrich a climate scientist at the university of california at davis flood water in sebastopol california on wednesday feb   image jane tyska medianews group the mercury news via getty image resident stand on the rooftop of a home in guerneville california preparing to evacuate after the russian river flooded the town image karl mondon medianews group the mercury news via getty image this year is exemplary said ullrich noting that atmospheric river dumped excessive amount of rain in california during january it very much support that hypothesis see also trump fails to block nasa s carbon sleuth from going to space generally scientist expect california s rainy season to become shorter and more contracted but still have about the same amount of rainfall a in the past that mean more extreme deluge once heavy rain repeatedly hit california they set the stage for flood the ground becomes oversaturated with water that set up the whole system to overflow said ullrich a submerged truck in forestville california image michael short ap rex shutterstock a submerged pickup truck in forestville california on feb   image michael short ap rex shutterstock future atmospheric river are expected to bring load of water from both the tropic and drier area over the ocean said swain due to simple physic a the atmosphere warms the air is able to hold more water vapor specifically for every  degree celsius   degree fahrenheit of warming the air can hold seven percent more water the forecast for the russian river at guerneville remains at  by tomorrow night thats a disastrous amount of water for the town thanks gdimeweather for building this inundation product to visualize the pending flood reach pic twitter com szmzgiuo jim cantore jimcantore february   in the last century earth ha warmed by  degree celsius and the warming trend is expected to continue a climate scientist around the world repeatedly underscore on tuesday a national weather service station in the california city of santa rosa broke it record for daily rainfall that s a pretty impressive statistic said swain

column2: but the mind set seemed to have fully changed local official used to regard hurricane response a something akin to major snow removal sporadic event that therefore warranted relatively little investment two year of these type of storm have really made u look internally at our own preparation mr sears said now that we have a better understanding of where people may be at risk we can better stage asset in that area matthew got me once florence got me twice mr sears said tuesday recounting what he told the city council this week the next hurricane won t get me closer to the coast in conway s c a few mile northwest of myrtle beach the weariness with the cycle of worry flood repeat wa palpable i grew up here said matt bruton  a moving and storage business operator who wa hanging out tuesday in his single story brick home in old sherwood country club an eclectic neighborhood of old and new house north of the waccamaw river the water had already risen through neighboring crabtree swamp to a level higher than resident had ever seen we had a record flood during floyd in  and it wasn t this high mr bruton said the hundred year flood they called it the last time and here we are again i d like to put my house in a different higher place but i call this the best neighborhood in conway we re all friend here

column2: a the tire fire that is theresa may s handling of brexit continues to burn a crowd pegged at around a million people flooded the street of london on saturday protesting the disastrous policy and calling on a new referendum see also john oliver share his thought on brexit and we honestly don t know whether to laugh or cry while the option of a second referendum on brexit wa once seen a highly unlikely there s now a semblance of hope for those backing the vote prime minister may ha bungled the process and is faced with a variety of dubious option including a yet again delayed exit or even a no deal brexit that would have serious ramification dubbed put it to the people saturday s march saw around a million people participate organizer said the event also included a rally in front of parliament london mayor sadiq khan wa among those marching and he wa scheduled to speak at the post march rally the swarm of people in london wa in direct contrast to the much smaller march to leave a two week trek of pro leave protester led by nigel farage walking from sunderland with the aim of arriving in london on friday march  the originally planned brexit date in london though the street were flooded with protester holding quippy sign and marching in costume all part of the growing movement to demand a new vote over leaving the eu even superheroes backed the second vote protest image getty image one of many many clever sign seen in london during saturday s protest image getty image the movement to remain in the eu got a big boost in visibility earlier in the week when an online petition calling for revoking article  the law that outline how country can exit the eu gained so many signature now at   million that it crashed the government s petition website organizer pegged the crowd at just over a million participant image getty image even dog joined the march image getty image to say the brexit process ha been a disaster is putting it mildly a can be seen by the fact that prime minister may is the target of both aforementioned protest that take opposing side it s reflective of the infighting that s taken place in parliament leaving that body of government in a deadlock with no plan in place for an exit despite saturday s enormous protest odds of a second referendum are still long thanks to the hurdle that need to be cleared including approval from that deadlocked parliament a decision on what exactly the referendum would be a vote on and negotiating a timetable on the vote madness is an understatement when it come to the brexit mess image getty image london wa flooded saturday with protester and their sign calling on a new brexit vote a teresa may flirt with disaster image getty image for now it s a wait and see situation for everyone the eu ha given may until april  to get a deal passed by parliament the protester were not kind to may image getty image failure to get a deal done will mean either a no deal brexit or may will have to propose yet another alternative before that deadline and with that yet another journey into the unknown for the uk

column2: when last week bomb cyclone hit the midwest it wa hard to imagine the inundation it could bring amid whiteout condition and more than a foot of snow but the warm weather that wrapped in behind it quickly melted out all that white stuff and unleashed historic flooding across part of nebraska iowa south dakota kansa and missouri floodwaters have worked their way down the river that run like artery through the region overtop the bank of the missouri platte elkhorn and more dam have been destroyed bridge and other infrastructure have been washed away and small town have been cut off from the outside world surrounded by moat of muddy water the flooding ha also paralyzed the various military base scattered across the region with water lapping up against fort leavenworth and offutt air force base home u s strategic command a task and purpose helpfully note that mean the base that oversees the pentagon nuclear strategic deterrence and global strike capability is largely underwater the situation also neatly illustrates how climate changewhich is leading to more intense precipitationis a threat multiplier a of monday nine flood gauge operated by the national oceanic and atmospheric administration remained at major flood stage with another  in moderate flood stage while the on the ground photo show the human toll of the flood satellite are the best way to get a handle on the full scope of whats happening in the midwest below are before and after image captured by the european space agency sentinel satellite where the missouri left and nishnabotna right river meet on the border of iowa nebraska and missouri gif sentinel hub the missouri river near camp ashland a nebraska national guard training center gif sentinel hub a view of kansa fort leavenworth lower and middle left an army installation on the bank of the missouri river gif sentinel hub the convergence of the elkhorn left and platte right river in nebraska gif sentinel hub the confluence of the missouri upper and niobrara lower left river near niobrara nebraska one of the bridge into town wa washed out by the floodwaters after a dam ruptured gif sentinel hub

column2: it sound like a b rated science fiction movie wallaby implanted with microchip opening their own personal pet door when they want to come home but this isn t an ill advised sequel to tank girl researcher in australia recently implanted a bridled nail tailed wallaby with a microchip and trained it to use a cat door to find food and escape predator the  day experiment wa designed to prove that such technology could be useful to help in the eventual wild release of captive bred animal bridled nail tailed wallaby are among the smallest wallaby themselves often described a smaller version of closely related kangaroo both are marsupial in the macropodidae family about a large a medium sized dog the wallaby s name refers to a small nail it ha on the end of it tail nobody ha yet figured out the nail s purpose the wallaby listed a vulnerable by the international union for conservation of nature are threatened in their native australian habitat by predator like feral dog and cat since these predator aren t native to the continent the wallaby have nary a notion of the threat they pose the iucn estimate that fewer than  bridled nail tail wallaby remain in the wild if we don t act now there won t be any left soon said julia hoy research manager at the university of queensland s hidden vale wildlife centre a research and teaching organization focused on wildlife management hoy admitted that wallaby aren t known for their intelligence but she and her colleague wanted to see whether they could train a captive nail tailed wallaby named flood to use a cat door to find food and escape from predator if we can do it with her we can do it with anyone said hoy flood wa born in captivity in  around the time of intense flooding that wiped out several town west of brisbane australia she is one of a number of wallaby and other native australian animal held by the wildlife center a insurance in case wild population drop to unsustainable level in the meantime the researcher are developing technique they could use to help captive raised animal survive if they are released in the future the team implanted flood with a microchip that allowed her to push open an otherwise locked pet door which led to a safe space with available food the door wa programmed to unlock when the microchip got near but flood wasn t exactly a quick learner the answer is do it very slowly and careful and do it in small stage hoy said adding that they first had to get the wallaby comfortable with pushing the door open eventually though flood got the hang of it and made use of her secure personal apartment their report on flood s training wa published in june in zoo biology she said that the result signal good news if wallaby like flood are released back into the wild door like these can help researcher do a type of soft release which involves partial feeding a well a giving the animal a safe place to hide from any feral dog intent on making a meal out of them at least until they learn to fend for themselves completely cautious step like this are necessary since it would be a waste of time resource and precious wallaby if the animal were released only to be immediately eaten by an invasive predator hoy and her colleague are busy training other animal including northern brown bandicoot to fear dog and cat while this is the first time that this type of setup ha been used on wallaby other research ha employed door opening tech for specie a varied a owl monkey and bird biology professor vladimir pravosudov and his colleague from the university of nevada reno placed electric band on the leg of chickadee that allowed them to access feeder a part of an effort to learn about their spatial memory performance and cognitive flexibility pravosudov said he s not surprised that the wallaby could learn to use such a device and suggested that the use of this technology will soon become common among wildlife researcher and manager it doesn t require handling animal in the wild so the technology is all over the place he said adding this allows for a way of monitoring wildlife behavior without the interference of human presence joshua rapp learn is an alberta expat based in washington d c who cover science and exploration find him on twitter joshualearn

column2: grand rapid mich grand rapid is better prepared to handled the higher water in the grand river than before the  flood a city official said tuesday with heavy rain this week the grand river downtown gauge is predicted to reach   foot on saturday feb  according to the national weather service the highest reading occurred on april   at   foot in a flood where hundred of home were evacuated in a state of emergency the record flooding wa a result of multiple factor said grand rapid city engineer mark de clercq we had a snow pack that year de clercq said we also had a series of small rain event that year that impacted the grand river water shed the city wa already in the process of updating it flood plain map with fema during the  flood and completed the improvement in  he said in  and  we went forth and delivered the construction or improvement to certain location along the flood protection system to raise the top of the flood wall to meet that  year base flood elevation de clercq said the city also raised some of the soil embankment to prevent flooding including by the ford museum and the wealthy street bridge with what is predicted this weekend compared to about   feed at the  year there s still definitely about five and a half foot of flood protection still available de clercq said the grand river won t look the same in a few year the city is working with grand rapid whitewater to restore the river s rapid construction is expected to begin in  and the restoration won t affect the city s flood control said richard bishop president of grand rapid whitewater the sixth street dam and the four low head dam they have no flood control capacity today at all bishop said they re not flood control dam so when you take it out that won t affect the flood plain flood wall are what contains it in the river the project he said is budgeted at   million make it easy to keep up to date with more story like this download the wzzm  app now have a news tip email news wzzm com visit our facebook page or twitter  wzzm tv

column2: historic flooding ha followed in the wake of the bomb cyclone that rammed into the central u s this week with usa today reporting that nebraska experienced what may be the worst flood in half a century flooding ha continued in swathe of iowa missouri and nebraska according to cnn a bomb cyclone occurs whenas happened last week when a storm that began to form in the southwest swept across the central u s pressure drop dramatically in a short period of time a phenomenon known a explosive bombogenesis it rare for one to happen in the inland u s and this week storm resulted in severe weather across a massive stretch of the country nebraska governor pete ricketts characterized the situation on friday a historic flooding and extreme weather in nearly every region of the state flood team throughout nebraska have been rescuing stranded civilian since thursday cnn wrote cnn added that one man in the state columbus farmer james wilke received a distress call headed out on his tractor and died when a bridge collapsed according to cnn affiliate kmtv a close family friend posted on social medium about his last moment it is no surprise to anyone that knew james that when he got the phone call to assist emergency responder his answer would be yes jodi l hefti wrote on facebook with the guidance of emergency responder james drove his tractor over the shell creek bridge on the monestary road and the bridge gave out james and the tractor went down into the flood water below some  member of a platte valley rescue team which wa assisting resident around king lake were stranded until nebraska national guard troop rescued them with a black hawk helicopter at least four nebraska state highway were washed out or damaged usa today wrote altogether the paper reported disaster declaration had been in effect in  city and  of nebraska  county two additional people are missing and around  had to take refuge in temporary shelter while flood warning and advisory remained in effect on saturday in part of the eastern nebraska iowa and southern wisconsin according to the national weather service weather prediction center much of the worst is over except along area adjacent to the missouri and mississippi river and their tributary numerous location in those region will continue to have major to historic flooding for at least into early next week thanks to heavy rainfall earlier this week falling on frozen ground and a deep snow pack that lead to intense and quick melting the center wrote cnn usa today

tractor and died when a bridge collapsed according to cnn affiliate kmtv a close family friend posted on social medium about his last moment it is no surprise to anyone that knew james that when he got the phone call to assist emergency responder his answer would be yes jodi l hefti wrote on facebook with the guidance of emergency responder james drove his tractor over the shell creek bridge on the monestary road and the bridge gave out james and the tractor went down into the flood water below some  member of a platte valley rescue team which wa assisting resident around king lake were stranded until nebraska national guard troop rescued them with a black hawk helicopter at least four nebraska state highway were washed out or damaged usa today wrote altogether the paper reported disaster declaration had been in effect in  city and  of nebraska  county two additional people are missing and around  had to take refuge in temporary shelter while flood warning and advisory remained in effect on saturday in part of the eastern nebraska iowa and southern wisconsin according to the national weather service weather prediction center much of the worst is over except along area adjacent to the missouri and mississippi river and their tributary numerous location in those region will continue to have major to historic flooding for at least into early next week thanks to heavy rainfall earlier this week falling on frozen ground and a deep snow pack that lead to intense and quick melting the center wrote cnn usa today
column8: tornado chaser face storm a lawsuit hit close to home

column2: california continues to take stock of it unprecedented conflagration between the camp fire in the north which on it own is the deadliest and most destructive fire in california history and the woolsey fire in the south  life have been lost so far with hundred more still missing a firefighter keep battling the blaze a new menace is emerging debris flow the rain are coming to california a soon a tuesday night and the fire have primed the soil for another disaster that can claim yet more life the coastal town of montecito in southern california learned this lesson le than a year ago last december the massive thomas fire burned through the hill right up to the edge of town thanks to the community comprehensive fire preparedness plan only  home were lost but a month later the scorched hill outside of town let loose a storm driven debris flow that enveloped the town killing  the problem is a fundamental change to the soil itself when a wildfire burn vegetation it release organic compound these compound are heated in the fire volatilize and then re condense on soil particle say brian ebel a hydrologist with the usgs this soil normally absorbs water but the organic compound turn it hydrophobic literally meaning fear of water it is not an understatement you can pour a bottle of water on this burned soil and itll bead right off a if the dirt were polished marble the water will pool up and sit there and it can take more than an hour for it to penetrate fire scorched soil say ebel problem number two vegetation anchor the soil when fire burn it away the soil loosens you can think of vegetation a a protective blanket say jason kean a hydrologist at the usgs without it sediment ha nothing to hold it in place before there s even rain debris can roll down the hill and accumulate in channel now hydrologist and meteorologist are keeping a close eye on community that butt up against these latest fire where the condition are set for catastrophic debris flow when the rain come once it start raining hard on a burn area the thing can get generated really fast like five minute say kean the debris flow can carry boulder and tree along with mud making it more dangerous than a regular flood or a dry landslide when you mobilize themkeep them mobile with this muddy matrix in between themthey can go  kilometer say kean the video below show just how easily the flow toss boulder around boulder can also act like a moving dam retarding the flow so you get this surging behavior where these thing are holding back a whole bunch of flow behind it add kean it really make the flow depth increase several time what you d get in a water only flood the montecito debris flow got to be  foot deep at point lodging boulder in tree human are powerless to stop itsandbags just become more debris for the flow but it can be predicted giving resident a chance to evacuate the work begin a soon a a wildfire smoke clear enough for satellite to get a good look at how badly area have burned this information is relayed to scientist on the ground who enter those burned region a soon a it safe the greatest risk of debris flow is in the zone that burned the most intensely and scientist spend two or three day wandering the fire perimeter taking soil sample that involves testing the hydrophobicity of the soil the water repellency say eric huff staff chief of cal fire forest practice program and actually getting down on hand and knee and looking at what that surface soil layer is showing whether or not organic matter ha been completely burned off kean and his colleague then compare this data to their understanding of where debris flow have let loose in the area historically building a map that capture the probability and potential volume of a debris flow they also identify value at riskhuman life and structure that may be in danger with all this data in mind they can calculate how much rain you would need to potentially let loose a debris flow for different region of the map often half an inch of rain in an hour is enough to kick one off or a little a five minute of heavy rain it s kind of a run of the mill storm say kean it s heavy rain but it s not particularly exceptional so the national weather service carefully watch storm a they head into california unfortunately with climate change california may see fewer yet more intense storm going forward a the rain approach the coast official can send out wireless alert like you would get for an amber alert a well a warning on tv and radio which brings u back to the montecito disaster forecaster saw the storm coming predicting it would drop an inch and a half of rain an hour what we saw in reality that night wa a  minute heavy rain that moved through that area say eric boldt a warning coordination meteorologist at the national weather service it wa closer to six and a half inch per hour and there s no computer model that exist today that can predict that type of rate official had put voluntary evacuation order in place but not everyone heeded the advice this wa just after the thomas fire after all they had just been evacuated for two or three week over the holiday season say boldt they were just getting comfortable back in their home and they didn t want to leave again if you havent cleared out in time and the flow come the recommendation is to shelter in placemoving to the upper story of your house for instance out on the street is exactly where you don t want to be a the flow follows those path we ve even seen people if they were able to get up on their countertop in their kitchen the mud came up to about that level say boldt it s a different way of thinking about the impact because it s not the same a a flash flood with a flash flood you can see a river swelling and move to higher ground flee up a hill just before a debris flow though and that ground could kill you the debris flow risk can persist for up to five year after a wildfire so resident whose home narrowly survived a wildfire may not realize theyre in danger of the surrounding hill for longer than a year but the danger is most certainly there it a brutal consideration for those trying to recover from the camp and woolsey fire but it also an extremely important one a menace begets another menace more great wired story
column8: rare tornado touch down in seattle suburb  damaging several home

column2: cnn after the deadly flooding of  howard county executive allan kittleman said ellicott city wa reduced to a war zone and likened it to the scene of disaster movie set on monday kittleman said the flooding of  wa much nastier authority were still in the assessment stage on a soggy memorial day trying to determine exactly how much worse particularly worrying kittleman said is a  to  foot wide hole just north of main street where the ground appears to have buckled under the weight of the flooding there are a lot of people whose life are going to be devastated again and they ve been working so hard to come back and we just need to be there for them and to tell them all of our resource are there to help them kittleman said i can t imagine what they re going through i couldn t imagine what they went through two year ago and now it s even worse the first concern is people emergency responder conducted  rescue monday morning a they continued their search for a missing man identified a eddison hermond sarah lopez wa at a restaurant attending a birthday party with hermond when the flooding began she told cnn hermond left to help a woman rescue her cat from a pet store witness returned and said hermond slipped into the river and wa carried away said lopez whose husband met hermond  year ago in the u air force a rescuer continue searching for hermond there were no report of death or major injury a of early monday kittleman said the  flood killed two people when floodwaters swept away their vehicle gas and electricity have been shut down on main street where water ran through building a if it were a tributary of the nearby patapsco river which swelled to record level during sunday s storm the river is a major waterway that feed into the chesapeake bay baltimore gas amp electric said it will need to survey the damage to it infrastructure before providing a timeline for restoring service flooding claimed the old courthouse kittleman said and there are home on the west end of downtown whose foundation and basement are gone a lot of the business the first floor are gone like they were two year ago he said maryland gov larry hogan declared a state of emergency sunday in howard county marked by quaint shop in the bottom floor of brick stone slab and siding clad building the historic downtown is a major draw in this community of about   people located about  mile west of baltimore main street also known a frederick road wa transformed into a waterway over the weekend a brown water sluiced through town destroying shop and upending car in some area the water rose above the building first floor to understand what authority were surveying monday it s perhaps helpful to understand what happened fewer than two year ago after  inch of rain fell on the flood prone community in about two hour resident say the flooding came from nowhere in  in addition to the two people killed more than two dozen building were heavily damaged or destroyed resident formed human chain to pluck their neighbor from the rushing water kittleman said at the time that it wa the worst devastation in howard county in  year but the town rallied around the slogan ellicott city strong and got to the arduous work of putting their community back together again when the rain came sunday many resident remained in the throe of recovery the county wa working on stormwater retention pond and preparing to install additional piping money from a federal emergency management agency grant had just arrived and wa slated for repair and construction kittleman said there are thing that we are doing it just can t be done in le than two year he said after the flood in  and working on the recovery there you can t get thing done in a year or two it just can t happen and you saw we get the money from fema two year later that s how it work more than  inch in  hour the river rose   foot in two hour sunday afternoon to   foot a record from the previous high of   foot the national weather service which issued a flash flood warning for southeastern howard county through early monday reported that part of the greater baltimore area got isolated rainfall of more than  inch three to  inch wa common throughout the metro area in part of ellicott more than  inch fell between  a m and  p m sunday the weather service said the eastern portion of the community saw more than  inch in that timespan while the southwestern side of town received more than  inch of the wet stuff there are possibility that another inch could fall the nw said and though that doesn t sound like much rain it mean trouble for the already saturated ground and burgeoning river aside from the patapsco river there are four other smaller waterway running through and around the ellicott the howard county department of fire and rescue service urged resident to evacuate downtown or move to higher ground while rescue team fanned out through the area they re being asked to stay away from main street until authority can ensure building are safe to enter the roger carter community center is open for those who need a place to shelter gov hogan toured the area sunday with kittleman he lamented the destruction noting that just two week earlier he had visited the historic downtown and spoken with business owner about rebuilding effort the place looked terrific he said it s just devastating because people have their life tied up in this and went through a heck of a lot and came back and now they re starting all over again kittleman expressed confidence monday that ellicott could make another comeback this is where we re one howard again and we ll be one ellicott city he said we will be stronger in the future we really will folk this is not a place that give in we didn t give in in  we re not going to give in in  asked what he d say to downtown business owner who have their doubt about reopening after being hammered twice in  month kittleman said he see their side of thing i can totally understand what they re saying if i wa in their shoe i d probably be reassessing that myself cnn s paul p murphy lindy royce emanuella grinberg and janet digiacomo contributed to this report

column2: resident should not return to their home without an escort for safety reason the police department posted on facebook john g ducey the mayor added that they re not going to be moving back anytime quickly this is the exact opposite of anywhere that flooded during sandy mr ducey said this is the northwest portion of town it never flooded before i never even got a complaint about water in the road some in new jersey blamed the scale of the flooding on climate change and politics jeff tittel director of the new jersey sierra club said that change to waterway protection had left the state more vulnerable we continue to see more and more flood event across our state affecting home and community and putting our waterway at risk mr tittel said more development creates more impervious surface and destroys floodplain and wetland he added this all contributes to increased flooding and storm water runoff further putting community at risk

column2: image copyright reuters in the wake of devastating flood in the southern indian state of kerala local volunteer played an integral part clearing the mud and debris bbc tamil s pramila krishnan spoke to one woman who spent week helping clean up her city on  august sandhini gopakumar a  year old housewife returned to her home in the flood ravaged city of cochin with her husband and two child they had been forced to spend five day in three different emergency relief camp on my way back home i saw the bloated body of cattle floating in stagnant water recall sandhini how were we going to clean this up i thought how many day would we need the flood were the worst to hit kerala in a century hundred were killed and more than a million displaced like sandhini and her family many took shelter in relief camp spread across the state by the end of the month flood water began to recede and kerala started to limp back to normal but even a the danger from flood water faded a new challenge loomed large home were muddied and wrecked sewer had overflowed and rubbish filled the street large part of city and village had become unliveable image copyright sharique ahmad sandhini remembers her heart sinking at the sight of garbage piled up in paravur her neighbourhood in cochin when she entered her house she found herself knee deep in mud and surrounded by the unbearable stench of sewage and rotting food it gave me a terrible headache she say it took her two whole day to clean the small two bedroom house nearly everything the family owned from the furniture to kitchen utensil wa beyond repair she say she kept thinking of the thousand of family across kerala who were also helpless in the face of the destruction wrought by the flood i called up other member from kudumbashree and we started cleaning public place kudumbashree is a unique initiative by the kerala government to fight poverty and empower woman set up in  it comprises only female volunteer kudumba in the local malayalam language mean family and shree mean woman sandhini and her fellow member volunteered for hour every day to clean up their neighbourhood and town my team of  might have been small in number but we were strong in our resolve to deliver and deliver fast sandhini say with a touch of pride image copyright getty image armed with mask and glove they got to work at the local government school they put the soaked furniture out to dry and rid the classroom of slush and worm she say it wa disheartening to listen to school official tell them how many computer had been damaged and how many book and school record had been destroyed at the government run day care centre they disinfected the floor multiple time because large patch of fungi had spread in many of the centre and they dug pit for stored food that had begun to decompose now every time i pas by the teacher thanks me for our help sandhini say with a smile over a period of two week they cleared debris segregated waste and sold wrecked furniture and other item to scrap shop they swept road mopped floor and scrubbed the inside of school and hospital i couldn t afford to donate a lot of money so i gave my time and labour instead sandhini say image copyright sharique ahmad the woman exchanged the sari they usually wore in favour of salwar kameez a popular indian outfit in which a long tunic is paired with pleated trouser the trouser allowed them to move more freely helping them wade through deep puddle and navigate other danger like the snake scorpion and various kind of insect the flood had brought into people s home wherever we went local helped u sandhini say men lifted heavy bin picked broken glass and helped catch snake the health centre she say wa the worst place to clean the smell from the broken septic tank and the overflowing toilet wa revolting image copyright afp getty image caption the kerala chief minister ha said the state ha never seen anything like this before some volunteer fell ill which triggered panic a they feared they had leptospirosis or rat fever this happens when rat drown in flood water which contaminates it further allowing the bacteria to spread the disease claimed  life in kerala in two day i also had fever for a few day but that wa expected we were tired and needed to rest say sandhini throughout she had stayed in relief camp or at the home of friend and relative depending on where her cleaning drive took her next we had access to safe food and water because people were generous she say when she finally went home after two week she say everyone recognised her i wa a known face in my neighbourhood the smile they give me is a symbol of kudumbashree s success

column2: with the prospect of several hour of potent wave inciting onshore wind from the season s first nor easter a coastal flood warning wa in effect saturday for the new jersey shore a flood advisory wa posted for philadelphia and the region s power company were on alert for potential power outage the national weather service on friday also posted a wind advisory for the shore until  a m saturday saying wind could gust to  mph and whip up wave of  to  foot gust of up to  mph were possible north of atlantic city the critical time for coastal flooding would be the first high tide which occurs at   a m saturday said weather service meteorologist lee robertson astronomical tide would be a bit higher than usual given that while the moon will be waning it still will be nearly full the weather service said that widespread flooding of roadway is expected with many road becoming impassable but after mid morning saturday the flood threat at least wa expected to ebb the storm will be a quick mover and saturday night s high tide is actually lower than the morning one robertson said meanwhile utility company said crew were on standby in case of power outage given the powerful wind and heavy rain with  to  inch expected plus because of the late leaf fall tree still are laden with surprisingly green leaf and soil remain wet from week of heavy rain that could make tree vulnerable to gust we are ready to respond said frank tedesco spokesperson for atlantic city electric co philadelphia international airport is advising traveler to check with their airline for potential flight delay the storm is going to get an additional charge from strong wind in the upper atmosphere the weather service office in mount holly said in it friday morning discussion rain is forecast to continue well into the afternoon saturday but should be over by nightfall the storm s origin were in the gulf of mexico and the weather prediction center said that before it left the texas coast for the atlantic it got a shot of juice from the remnant of hurricane willa nor easter in october aren t uncommon on average they have occurred about a once a year according to analysis by the northeast regional climate center in autumn the temperature contrast that generate organized storm are sharper than they are in spring or summer when rain tend to be showery

column2: thunderstorm on earth can be terrifying thing but from space those same event take on a beautiful even ghostly edge a new time lapse video from the geostationary lightning mapper glm onboard the go  weather satellite which launched to space on march   show flash of lightning above north and south america zooming in on a line of storm moving east across the central u s see also satellite capture stunning swirl at bottom of globe note the mapper doe more than just take pretty picture of what s happening back on earth the mapper observes lightning in the western hemisphere giving forecaster an indication of when a storm is forming intensifying and becoming more dangerous rapid increase of lightning are a signal that a storm may strengthen quickly and could produce severe weather the national oceanic and atmospheric administration noaa said in a statement during heavy rain glm data can show when thunderstorm are stalled or if they are gathering strength when combined with radar and other satellite data glm data will help forecaster anticipate severe weather and issue flood and flash flood warning sooner go  isn t the only satellite keeping an eye on lightning on earth the go  satellite also watch out for large thunderstorm rolling across the u s on behalf of weather forecaster and scientist on the ground and astronaut and cosmonaut on the international space station are able to see thunderstorm from  mile above the planet s surface over the year the space station s crew member have taken gorgeous time lapse video of thunder storm swirling below them astronaut have also captured rare type of lightning from orbit snapping photo and video of red sprite a phenomenon associated with intense thunderstorm that s best seen from space

column2: mr cobb also predicted a quick end to the investigation i d be embarrassed if this is still haunting the white house by thanksgiving and worse if it s still haunting him by year end mr cobb wa quoted a saying but mr dowd s personal relationship mr mueller never developed and he began clashing with the special counsel s office over whether mr trump would be interviewed mr dowd ha since said that he belief mr mueller snookered the trump team into cooperating in march mr dowd resigned telling associate that he disagreed with the president s desire to sit for an interview with mr mueller one form of cooperation he opposed and leaving mr sekulow with the task of rebuilding the legal team from scratch and without knowing many of the detail of the case because mr trump and his adviser had concluded that the only real threat to him wa impeachment mr giuliani wa brought in to lead the effort to undermine mr mueller s credibility with the public while the husband and wife legal team of jane and marty raskin former federal prosecutor based in florida wa hired to deal directly with mr mueller s office to deal with the investigation of mr cohen in new york mr trump hired joanna c hendon and with mr flood brought on to replace mr cobb who had also departed a new more aggressive team had taken shape but if the policy of cooperation had ended the turmoil among the lawyer had not ten day after the time reported that mr mcgahn had cooperated extensively with mr mueller mr trump tweeted that mr mcgahn would be leaving the white house in the fall that came a a surprise to mr mcgahn who had not discussed his departure with mr trump since earlier this year since then mr trump ha had discussion with mr flood about replacing mr mcgahn but mr flood is hesitant in part because that could pull him away from one of the main reason he initially joined the white house to represent another president in impeachment proceeding

column2: michael bociurkiw is a global affair analyst at work on his first nonfiction book on screen and social medium addiction the opinion expressed in this commentary are his view more opinion on cnn cnn about  million american live in area that have a chance of flooding and the number exposed to serious flooding is a much a   time higher than previous estimate time is clearly not on our side sea level are rising faster than predicted and homeowner in particularly vulnerable area such a south florida could see their property literally under water within their lifetime relative sea level there are roughly four inch higher now than in  various projection including by the army corp of engineer see rise in south florida of  inch by  and between  to  foot by  what s more rare event are going to become more common in the future strictly due to sea level rise william sweet an oceanographer at the national oceanic and atmospheric administration noaa told the guardian and so it would make some sense that a official tally the damage from hurricane florence in the carolina with  dead and insured loss estimated at   billion coastal homeowner and business might conduct their own tally of the cost of continuing to live in place vulnerable to flooding and high wind yet national and local leader appear to be sleepwalking toward climate catastrophe based on my own exchange over the year with municipal mayor from both inland and coastal jurisdiction my sense is that few view it a a top priority especially those in place such a south florida where the property tax base is the main source of income rather than curbing building in vulnerable area or returning flood prone area to nature jurisdiction such a miami beach have opted to spend million on flood abatement project and for their part financial market deflect reality climate change is a very slow moving disaster that may last decade before it ha any effect on the market wall street investor michael popow told me in the meantime it is another negative in the macro economic environment which will sooner than later cause the market to crash but this disaster is not so slow moving monster storm are coming faster and with more ferocity last year wa the f irst time in over a decade t hat four hurricane made u landfall in one season and a growing number of coastal dweller have now lived through multiple storm with some not even fully recovered from the last one by one estimate from seattle based zillow research based on current projection by noaa of ocean level rising six foot by  almost  million property or roughly  of u housing stock worth   billion could be under water in a little over  year close to half of that loss in value would occur in florida alone where  in  property worth a total of   billion are threatened a zillow point out given the insatiable appetite for waterfront property these number could be on the conservative side if development is allowed to continue in vulnerable area in fact sea level rise is already swamping coastal property value research b y the first street foundation ha tabulated a home value loss of    billion across eight coastal u state since  ironic is it not that some of the most coveted and expensive property in the u is also becoming the most vulnerable and is on a depreciation cycle in my frequent trip to south florida i encounter more and more people who are contemplating moving away from the waterfront especially in flood prone miami beach where even on clear day during high tide and even with billion spent on flood alleviation measure resident can encounter so called blue sky flooding according to one study such high tide flooding there ha increased by more than  in the last  year in short if you re a young to middle aged homeowner near water in south florida there is a chance that your property will be under water by the time you are a senior or more likely when the time come to sign the title over to little jane or johnny john hilliard s approach towards rising sea level is probably typical of many of those who reside on the venetian island the elevation of his new waterfront home in miami beach is at about nine foot above sea level that s reasonably high he told me i do see larger rain event due to the greater water holding ability of a warmer atmosphere but that rain should run off my island into the sea instead of flooding and staying after  we will be wishing we took this issue seriously a the loss of property will be enormous what will be the trigger to cause mass panic or a collapse of the waterfront property bubble the former mayor of coral gable james cason offer a stark scenario when water level in that tony community rise to the point where the mast of sailboat are unable to pas under it main bridge that is when people will suddenly see their property value go down because they can no longer get a boat out so that will be one of the first indicator of sea level rise and a wake up call for people of course outward migration from place like coral gable will translate into a slimmer property tax ledger for the seaside town which in turn creates challenge for such municipality to provide essential service and municipal bond already in a precarious state could sink even further when they are issued by jurisdiction known to have massive flooding problem while it would take a lot for city like miami beach to be abandoned rising tide and more frequent monster storm are becoming like the ravaging forest fire in california a new normal one study predicts there will be a many a  million climate refugee in america by the end of the century with the hardest hit county being miami dade even with inaction by a white house that prefers to ignore or deny climate change withdrawing from the paris climate agreement and activating rollback on the clean power plan there are localized measure that could defer a crash of the u coastal property bubble due to rising sea level mayor need to step up to the plate and use the tool and policy at their disposal one which ha already been implemented in many developing country in the wake of the  indian ocean tsunami is to return vulnerable area to nature that happened in the u in flood prone mastic beach new york after superstorm sandy where damaged home were bought back and the land transformed into wetland sea wall and strict building code can force people to build away from vulnerable area part of the solution is being smart about where we continue to develop said steven mcalpine an analyst with first street waiting to see what happens from this slow moving disaster is not an option once donald trump his supporter in the fossil fuel industry and others accept what is happening it s going to be too late and too expensive for a fix

column2: the flood guard protects car from debris strong wind and from floating away in a severe storm it work by enclosing the entire vehicle in a bag following is a transcript of the video this waterproof cover protects your car in a flood it s called the flood guard it claim to protect your car from floating away or being damaged by debris it wa inspired by waterproof bag used at the beach here s how it work  lay the bag down on a flat surface  hold the bag open  slowly drive or push your car into the bag  turn off your car and exit  zip the bag up  fold the zippered edge toward the car  connect the rear of the bag to the front using the strap  attach the padding  secure at least two strap to a post tree or fixed structure this will keep your car from floating away now your car is ready for water after finding success with the flood guard securo inc made an updated version the new version take only one person to set up it can be set up in minute and it s lighter than the original the shape allows one person to roll the bag over the car the flood guard could save you from buying a new car half a million car were reported a flooded from hurricane harvey flood guard start at

column2: cnn south carolina national guardsman allowed deputy to drive around a barricade blocking a flooded road in the aftermath of hurricane florence moment before two mental health patient drowned inside the vehicle authority say two deputy escaped when high water swept away their vehicle on september  but they could not pull out the patient on board the horry county sheriff s office said horry county spokeswoman brooke holden revealed on thursday that guardsman had waved the jail van around a barricade near the little pee dee river in south carolina the river wa over it flood stage at the time it s unclear why the guardsman allowed the jail van to pas lt col cindi king the south carolina national guard s director of public affair declined to comment citing an ongoing investigation by the south carolina law enforcement division the sheriff s deputy who drove the prison van stephen flood and joshua bishop are on administrative leave with pay holden said the victim were identified a windy newton  of shallotte north carolina and nicolette green  of myrtle beach the deputy were transporting the woman from conway near the coast to darlington about  mile northwest harrowing police scanner audio provides detail of the effort to save the woman who could be heard talking a rescuer scrambled to save them the officer report they got out the van is submerged and they cannot get their inmate out an unidentified person say later someone else report we have the two deputy that are out of the van and are secure on the boat the two inmate are in the back of the van are still in the van and they re talking and they re working on getting them out now the woman were seat belted in the back of the van horry county chief deputy tom fox said rescue team were able to save the deputy from the van s roof but they could not pull the vehicle from the water because it wa too dangerous the sheriff s office said the woman s body were recovered by diver the following day and taken to medical university of south carolina for autopsy official said cnn s dave alsup eliott mclaughlin and amanda watt contributed to this report

column2: gatineau que jean peloquin still hadn t finished renovating his house from the last flood in  when the river swept in and dumped more than a metre of water in his basement the repair which include building a new front porch and installing a waterproof foundation were interrupted by another season of spring flooding we haven t finished with the first flood and we re already into the second peloquin said wednesday peloquin s usually idyllic street in rigaud  km west of montreal wa more suited to the duck and muskrat that swam freely in the water that filled the neighbourhood but despite another flood coming so soon peloquin said he s not ready to think about leaving the big blue house by the water i have no desire to move yet he said but a moment later he added but everything ha a price a they grapple with their second bout of major spring flooding in three year some quebecers may soon have to contemplate what previously must have seemed unthinkable leaving their home quebec s public security department said a of  p m wednesday about   home across the province were flooded and  people have been forced to leave authority said rain forecast for the coming day and melting snow could further raise the water level in the region between gatineau and montreal premier francois legault ha warned the province cannot waste taxpayer money on compensating people for flood damage only to see the same property flooded again two or three year later a major flooding becomes more frequent he said starting this year quebec will cap compensation at    and once that is spent up to    thereafter for people to abandon their home if they face future flooding on peloquin s street some of the house sat in a metre of water others were protected by sandbag wall one resident had turned his home into a mini fortress with an elaborate wall of board and tarp that encircled deep pile of loose sand the  year old said area resident are used to some annual flooding although not to these level we accept the risk because it is worth it to live so close to nature so for now he s not looking at moving it would take a much better offer to convince him to move from paradise another resident jacques gagnon said he wa too busy dealing with flooding to think about the future no decision ha been made he said carole lague who also life on the street said she belief the frequent flooding show the need for long term planning i think we need to have collective intelligence and come up with good solution because this is a situation that will happen time and again she said a she trudged through knee high water she said she and her husband weren t thinking about moving noting they aren t eligible for compensation since it s a secondary residence on wednesday prime minister justin trudeau warned that city across canada will experience more frequent flooding because of climate change and government need to adapt to this new reality we re going to see more and more of these extreme weather event more regularly he said during a visit to an evacuation centre in the city of gatineau it mean we have to think about adaptation mitigation and how we are going to move forward together will amos the liberal mp for the gatineau area said the flooding show a national discussion is needed on how to deal with rural climate related event rural community continue to be challenged in their response to climate related disaster whether it is flood fire or otherwise he said fifty km east of rigaud on ile mercier a small island whose only bridge back to montreal ha been closed due to flooding resident sonia brown appeared ready to consider moving on after her home wa flooded in  she inquired about moving but said she wa told she could get much more compensation if she rebuilt which she said didn t make sense to her for now brown s newly renovated home is still dry but if it flood she said she ll look at the government s offer how many time can you live through this anxiety she said on tuesday my heart pressure i feel it i don t sleep i m not eating psychologically it s not healthy with file from kristy kirkup

column2: ready or not g data is at your doorstep samsung and verizon made that fact crystal clear last wednesday verizon lit up it g network claiming it to be the world s first two day later the largest phone maker on the planet began selling it first g device the galaxy s g in it home country of south korea these two event prove g is off to a very real if slow start i tested verizon s day old g network in chicago one of it two launch city some result were encouraging but mostly my experience revealed how far verizon ha to go to make it newborn network stable enough to support phone like the moto z with a g moto mod and the galaxy s g when that device come to the u read also verizon get sassy over g data speed then smack talk at amp t and t mobile samsung s exact u launch date is unconfirmed but the s g is rumored to go on preorder sale april  with a may  launch it ll come exclusively to verizon before heading to at amp t sprint and t mobile it s entirely possible that samsung is deliberately holding back the s g launch until verizon s new g network becomes a little more stable and perhaps more widespread right now it s available only in chicago and minneapolis and in mere downtown hotspot at that but verizon say it g service will come to  city by the end of  neither samsung nor verizon immediately responded to a request for comment on my theory i did get a chance to go hand on with the galaxy s g in february a little larger than the galaxy s plus it s a kind of an s plus plus the s g ha a   inch screen a total of six camera and qualcomm s snapdragon  chipset it s absolutely a premium phone though we ll need to see how some of it feature like it depth sensing front and rear camera will work on the phone day to day i did get an early demo of portrait video which give the background a blurred bokeh effect but it did need a little work to keep a moving subject separated from the background samsung also showed off a live demo of manipulating player in a baseball game being streamed over g you could actually rotate them to take a look that s not something a g phone can do speed will come at a cost samsung and verizon haven t announced pricing for the galaxy s g but we do know it ll cost more than the   galaxy s plus my educated guess put it at   or   all in verizon s g service also cost   more per month on top of your regular data plan at a time when phone cost are rising the advent of g is one more burden or barrier for people on a budget trying to keep up with the time while we know cost will come down at least some after the new technology settle in that could still be year away verizon and motorola both point to price a a main reason you might want the moto z and g mod with the total cost of ownership under   with both element currently on sale and   at full retail price motorola s option may be the only midprice g choice until other phonemakers ramp up their own portfolio read meet the g phone headed your way you can actually swivel this player on the galaxy s g to catch a different angle andrew hoyle cnet samsung get another chance for samsung the galaxy s g is another opportunity to turn a profit and keep it spot at the top samsung s felt the chill of a slowing smartphone market expecting revenue far below this same time last year despite strong galaxy s plus preorders it could be that customer are waiting for g and foldable phone to debut before making the decision to upgrade to a flat g phone on that note samsung s foldable galaxy fold arrives april  for g network with a g variation coming out sometime after that said cnet doesn t recommend rushing out to buy a first wave g phone verizon s shaky g start is one deterrent higher price for both the phone and g data service are another but there s one more good reason to wait too and that s a new chip that can make g phone slimmer and more efficient those device will be ready by the end of the year so while g is ready for you you might not quite be ready for it originally published april  at   p m pt

column2: washington reuters the federal emergency management agency fema said on friday it will resume issuing new flood insurance policy during the partial u s government shutdown reversing a decision announced two day ago fema which oversees the national flood insurance program said it wa rescinding guidance issued on wednesday that it would not be able to sell new policy during the shutdown unless congress pass legislation reauthorizing the program a of this evening all nfip insurer have been directed to resume normal operation immediately and advised that the program will be considered operational since december   without interruption fema said on it website the national association of realtor estimated the decision not to issue new policy could have disrupted up to   home sale each month the flood insurance program insures about  million home and business the federal government ha been partially shut down since dec  because of an impasse over president donald trump s demand for  billion in taxpayer funding for a proposed border wall reporting by eric beech editing by g crosse
