column2: in the wake of wednesday s parkland florida school shooting which resulted in  death troll and bot tracking site reported an immediate uptick in related tweet from political propaganda bot and russia linked twitter account hamilton  a website created by alliance for securing democracy track twitter activity from account it ha identified a linked to russian influence campaign on robhat lab botcheck me a website created by two berkeley student to track  political propaganda bot all of the top two word phrase used in the last  hour excluding president trump s name are related to the tragedy school shooting gun control high school florida school the top hashtags from the last  hour include parkland guncontrol and guncontrolnow while robhat lab track general political bot hamilton  focus specifically on those linked to the russian government according to the group s data the top link shared by russia linked account in the last  hour is a  politifact article that look critically at a statistic cited by pro gun control group everytown for gun safety twitter account tracked by the group have used the old link to try to debunk today s stats about the frequency of school shooting another top link shared by the network cover the deranged instagram account of the shooter showing image of him holding gun and knife wearing army hat and a screenshot of a google search of the phrase allahu akbar characterizing shooter a deranged lone wolf with potential terrorist connection is a popular strategy of pro gun group because of the implication that new gun law could not have prevented their action meanwhile some account with large bot following are already spreading misinformation about the shooter s tie to far left group antifa even though the associated press reported that he wa a member of a local white nationalist group the twitter account educationlibs which robhat lab show is one among the top account tweeted at by bot is among the prominent disseminator of that idea

column2: earlier this year amazon facial recognition tech rekognitionwhich can scan photo and video and match them against database of facesfaced a flood of criticism from amazon employee shareholder and civil right activist who argued that it use by government agency wa unethical or even dangerous that backlash wa spurred by an aclu report showing how amazon wa working with law enforcement to market it surveillance techand now new document provide more insight into how amazon is giving this controversial tool to police on friday buzzfeed news published document obtained through a public record request further detailing the relationship between amazon and the orlando police department which participated in a pilot program of rekognitions real time facial recognition software in june the police department announced that it initial contract with amazon had expired but in july the city said that it will continue testing rekognition according to buzzfeed amazon provided the city of orlando with ten of thousand of dollar of technology for free this support a washington post report that found oregon washington countywhose police also piloted rekognition paid only  to   a month for the service thats around how much it cost for a netflix subscription additionally the new document reveal that amazon required orlando to sign a nondisclosure agreement nda that would keep detail about the pilot under wrap the aclu previously discovered washington county similarly signed an nda with amazon nondisclosure agreement are par for the course for tech company and amazon claim that so is affording people with free pilot of their service providing customer with an opportunity to test technology with free credit is a common practice in the industry and something we offer to many of our customer with various aws service an amazon web service spokesperson told gizmodo in a statement talking to organization about product and new feature under a non disclosure agreement is also something we do frequently with many of our customer for the purpose of protecting intellectual property and competitive information we continue to support our customer in the responsible use of the technology which includes providing publicly available best practice and documentation a well a ongoing guidance from our machine learning expert all of which is standard for customer engagement perhaps the most interesting information in the new document however is how orlando official struggled to make amazon technology work it seems law enforcement team have been given this widely criticized technology with littleif anytraining sgt eduardo bernal of the orlando police department told buzzfeed that amazon didnt provide any in person instruction on how to use rekognition including on what photo they can upload to the database to create it list of suspected criminal email included in the document suggest that the pilot program wa far from flawless with internal and public communication about it riddled with slip ups and confusion from the very beginning a february email show a city official complaining about the late delivery of amazon tech once it wa set up the problem apparently continued the stream keep stopping seems like this happens daily a march email from an orlando official read i started  or  stream the other day and a you said now only  is still up i thought you were working on a script to automatically restart them if there were issue it unsurprising the program hasnt worked all of it kink out yet we saw the troubling implication of the system flaw in july when the aclu of northern california revealed that rekognition incorrectly flagged  member of congress a people suspected of crime of the  misidentified member  were people of color whats more the error rate for non white member of congress wa  percent compared to five percent for congress a whole the test cost just    thats a crucial driving factor behind demand for amazon to cancel it facial recognition contract with law enforcement officialsthe technology is currently flawed biased and in the wrong hand a powerful tool for discrimination currently orlando say it will only test the software by matching face against photo of volunteer police officer but it easy to imagine more dire consequence if use of this technology is expanded any company in this space that willingly hand this software over to a government be it america or another nation is willfully endangering people life brian brackeen ceo of the face recognition and ai startup kairos wrote in an op ed in june we need movement from the top of every single company in this space to put a stop to these kind of sale buzzfeed

column2: the crypto crash that began two day ago accelerated yesterday and today with essentially all top  coin down anywhere between   percent the total market capitalization of all cryptocurrencies is hovering around   billion down  percent from   billion just  hour ago yesterday bitcoin wa just a few dollar away from dropping below    but it bounced back around  k a  drop from two day before but bitcoin is now trading below    on most major exchange right now in the past  hour eth is down   percent to around   ripple is down   percent to   and so on unlike some crash where we see value flood from one cryptocurrency into another this sell off wa trader exiting into fiat interestingly tether is the sole token in the top  that s not down over the past seven day and that s because the price typically rise slightly above  when there is a demand to cash out into the stabilized token per usual there s no real rhyme or reason to this selloff two day ago we reported on rumor that some asia country were moving to regulate the cryptocurrency trading and mining industry but there hasn t really been any concrete news on this front yet regardless of the reason some in the cryptocurrency community are happy that the market is seeing at least some degree of a correction a it keep reality in check and is generally better for the long term prospect of the industry note the author own a small amount of cryptocurrency including eth and btc featured image bryce durbin
column8: after a natural disaster  is it better to rebuild or retreat

column2: new research connects a powerful volcanic eruption and a medieval poem that conjured memory of the dreaded event to iceland s conversion to christianity at the turn of the th century iceland s settler formally replaced odin thor and freya with jesus mary and joseph a new paper published in climatic change suggests memory of the eldgj lava flood the largest volcanic eruption to hit iceland in the past   year convinced icelander to turn away from their norse god and embrace christianity this conclusion reached by scientist from the university of cambridge wa made possible by establishing a firm date for the eruption and a reinterpretation of a grim poem called vlusp meaning the prophecy of the seeress prior to the new study scientist knew about the terrible eldgj lava flood but they couldn t figure out when it actually happened estimate placed the eruption anywhere from  through to  with a best guess at  based on scattered evidence to finally get it right a research team led by clive oppenheimer collected data from ice core and tree ring showing that the eruption started in the spring of  and continued until autumn  indeed the eldgj lava flood a it name and duration suggests wasn t any ordinary eruption it happened in the southern region of iceland along a  km long  mile fissure linked to the katla volcano the eruption threw massive amount of lava onto the land while spewing sulphurous gas into the atmosphere an estimated  cubic kilometer of magma poured from the crack needle to say the eruption had an impact on iceland s inhabitant who began to settle the island around  this place the eruption squarely within the experience of the first two or three generation of iceland s settler said oppenheimer in a statement some of the first wave of migrant to iceland brought over a child may well have witnessed the eruption the settler likely abandoned much of the island or relocated elsewhere a famine wa probably severe but no text survived to tell u exactly what happened but that s where the poem could help the researcher claim a certain reading of vlusp dated to around  seems to paint an apocalyptic scene of the condition both during and after the eruption and even the onset of a cold volcanic winter which wa felt around the globe the wolf is filled with the life blood of doomed men reddens the power dwelling with ruddy gore the sun beam turn black the following summer weather all woeful do you know yet or what the sun start to turn black land sink into sea the bright star scatter from the sky steam spurt up with what nourishes life flame fly high against heaven itself the poem also predicts the end of iceland s norse god and the rise of a new singular deity could this be construed a the conversion of iceland to christianity the researcher think it s a distinct possibility with a firm date for the eruption many entry in medieval chronicle snap into place a likely consequence sighting in europe of an extraordinary atmospheric haze severe winter and cold summer poor harvest and food shortage said oppenheimer but most striking is the almost eyewitness style in which the eruption is depicted in volusp the poem s interpretation a a prophecy of the end of the pagan god and their replacement by the one singular god suggests that memory of this terrible volcanic eruption were purposefully provoked to stimulate the christianisation of iceland that account of a severe volcanic eruption one still seared in memory were used to fuel theological debate and proselytize icelander in the th century is not a outlandish a it may appear the argument may have sounded quite compelling and the new religion may have offered some solace and reassurance oppenheimer and his colleague present a good case but like anything there s likely more to it than a scary poem the reason for iceland s conversion to christianity are complex and multifaceted the story of a horrible volcano quite possibly being among the many reason why the norse god were abandoned climatic change
column8: disastrous  atlantic hurricane season end  with hard hit area still reeling

column2: climate lawsuit have been piling up on the coast but a pioneering duo of colorado county and the city of boulder have filed the first landlocked lawsuit against big oil earlier this week suing exxon and tar sand producer suncor energy it represents a new front in the legal war that s pitting community stuck paying for the cost of climate change against the company that caused it and it could spread to neighboring state in flyover country yes sea level rise will be important elise jones a commissioner in boulder county who is part of the new suit told earther middle america is being hit by climate change too we thought it wa important that we tell that story the story is one of both big present impact visible in the wildfire scarred hill and flood scoured waterway and small one tucked away in the excel spreadsheet about the cost of road paving culvert and air conditioner for school in our eye it s a pretty simple issue of property right david bookbinder a lawyer with the libertarian niskanen center who is consulting on the case told earther we have local community faced with tremendously escalating cost of dealing with climate change it s not some future hypothetical it s been happening for year it s happening for today and quite literally local taxpayer are getting stuck with the bill boulder county for instance is still recovering from a   year rainfall event in  that sent murky torrent of water streaming down canyon tearing out road and bridge and inundating the city of boulder middle america is being hit by climate change too the county blew through it   million in reserve cash shortly after the disaster to make up for the shortfall it asked resident to approve a five year sale tax hike it also relied on federal fund and public tax money to help with cleanup and recovery and jones told earther recovery still isn t over i wa a brand new commissioner when the flood hit and i remember somebody saying it wa going to take at least five year to rebuild and i thought they were crazy she said but it s going to take a full decade to recover from that one incident research ha shown climate change increased the intensity of the rainfall event by about  percent the rise in extreme precipitation event portends an even more challenging and potentially costlier future good news oil company are woke to the reality of climate change there s just one small hitch read more read a county commissioned report show that even without climate shock like the  flood or a  wildfire that wa colorado s most destructive at the time the cost of adaptation will be steep peering into those excel sheet and then overlaying the climate impact of more heat wildfire and increased risk of drought between the deluge revealed the county could be stuck with a bill of up to   million in adaptation cost if we do nothing to curb carbon emission boulder is a comparatively wealthy county with a solid tax base of   but jones said the burden of adaptation is too much to handle which is why they re suing oil company we can t afford it and it s not fair she said if that s true for boulder county then it s even more so for san miguel county which is also part of the suit the county is located in southwest colorado and home to spectacular peak straight off the coors label seriously a well a sprawling farm land it tax base is smaller than boulder s but a with so many county in the west the infrastructure need are the same san miguel county ha a population of le than   bookbinder said they have a many road a boulder county and they re  th of the size they re in a box they have to spend money and there s no one handing out hundred of million for upkeep the lawsuit against exxon and suncor is one way to find fund oil company have known for decade about the impact of climate change all while spending million to sow doubt publicly exxon s knowledge wa exposed in groundbreaking reporting from by insideclimate news in  and since then other domino have fallen those report have opened oil company to a growing host of lawsuit by local government seeking damage and criminal investigation by attorney general in massachusetts new york and elsewhere suncor wa named in the colorado lawsuit because it worked in the state and produce the dirtiest oil on the planet in the form of albertan tar sand the idea that the fossil fuel industry would say yep our product are causing this we re going make more of them including product that are more carbon intensive seems absurd bookbinder said talk about giving the finger to local government it will likely take year for all these suit to wend their way through federal and state court whether they result in payouts or settlement is still very much unknown but amy markwell a lawyer for san miguel county told earther the defendant argument aren t that hard to follow climate change can be a fairly complicated issue but this lawsuit we re trying to keep it pretty simple she said your neighbor doe something that damage you or your property you can go to your local courthouse and seek local damage payment this is in essence the same argument that coastal community are making the new colorado case show the damage landlocked county face will be different but no le severe and that big oil can expect more legal challenger from all corner to come looking for a just settlement

column2: the problem started in  when the hassell law group represented ava bird in a personal injury case the two side offer differing reason a to why but regardless the firm decided to drop bird s case she then allegedly wrote a negative review on yelp giving the firm one star and encouraging others to stay away from hassell law group dawn hassell the firm s owner and bird s former attorney asked bird to take down the review calling it slander and warning that she would seek legal action for defamation bird declined to take down the review and in  hassell filed a lawsuit against bird bird didn t appear before the court so by default a ruling wa issued in hassell s favor bird wa later ordered to take down any defamatory review she posted on yelp about hassell and the hassell law group a well a pay     in damage but yelp which wa not involved in the case wa also ordered to take down bird s review it filed a motion to vacate the order arguing that because it wasn t given the opportunity to be heard in the case it due process right were violated additionally it noted that it wa protected by section  of the communication decency act the court denied yelp s motion and when the company appealed the court of appeal agreed with the lower court s ruling but yelp kept going taking the case to the california supreme court which in a   decision ruled that yelp wa indeed protected by section  and should not be required to take down bird s review with this decision online publisher in california can be assured that they cannot be lawfully forced to remove third party speech through enterprising abuse of the legal system and those of u that use such platform to express ourselves cannot be easily silenced through such tactic either yelp said in a statement a number of group including the aclu and eff a well a company like facebook reddit snap and twitter filed amicus brief in support of yelp s position expressing concern that the initial ruling would unleash precisely the flood of litigation section  is intended to avoid yelp said the case threatened the right of online platform that allow people to freely share their thought and the billion of people that do so section  already took a hit this year with the passing of fosta hassell s attorney monique olivier said that the decision stand a an invitation to spread falsehood on the internet without consequence the associated press report that hassell is considering an appeal to the supreme court

column2: you scroll through your friend s instagram feed and see the most beautiful setting and think i want to go there and so you do according to travel photographer brent knepper you are part of the problem in the online article instagram is loving nature to death knepper say that thanks to the photo sharing app some of the best kept secret of the natural world are drawing big crowd and literally altering the landscape knepper tell npr s lulu garcia navarro about some of the idyllic location that are seemingly being ruined because of exposure on instagram interview highlight there s nothing wrong with seeing a cool space on the internet and deciding to go there it s just maybe don t start fire there and clean up your poop brent knepper travel photographer on horseshoe bend in northern arizona horseshoe bend is this beautiful spot  mile up the colorado river from the grand canyon it s in the glen canyon national recreation area and the bend is very unique a far a waterway travel down there it make a complete  degree turn in a canyon   foot deep from the viewing point at the top you get this amazing view of this horseshoe shape hence the name it s a rugged remote spot and it s a very lovely place a long a you re willing to share it with a crowd i ran the number after doing a little bit of research and the number do check out on instagram horseshoe bend s popularity in it hashtag or in it geotag is normally  time a popular a anything else in that area on why some visitor and construction are the problem well popularity is very important the outdoor world need more visitor and more accessibility the difficulty with managing that side of it is that construction effect can have averse condition applied to the natural area if you start doing different building it s not that all visitor are a problem of course it s just some place tend to have people who neglect responsibility of their visitorship on other space that have changed in my article that i wrote for the outline i illustrate two other place that have also changed a a result of overwhelming popularity specifically on instagram a smaller one in colorado is conundrum hot spring after it became a spot to easily find on social medium the amount of visitorship went up really high and the problem since this is a very remote location where people hang around for a long time in the hot spring is that they ran out of place to go to the bathroom a a result conundrum hot spring had to be shut down for a little bit while park ranger were up there with shovel to relieve that issue bathroom were not built they literally had to shovel up everyone s waste and pack it out for them on vance creek bridge vance creek bridge is probably the most famous spot within the instagram niche it is the second tallest bridge in the u s it s privately owned and is about a two hour drive outside seattle it location wa revealed in  on instagram and since then visitorship ha just exploded the railing company that owns the bridge ha tried to slow down the amount of people visiting it by putting up a fence and then excavating the whole area around the bridge before it drop down over  foot towards the river they haven t been successful with that and a a result of vandalism graffiti and a couple of unresolved campfire that caught the bridge on fire they re just going to tear it down now on why people visit these place there s definitely a community aspect of it there s nothing wrong with seeing a cool space on the internet and deciding to go there it s just maybe don t start fire there and clean up your poop npr s digital news intern jose olivares produced this story for digital

column2: today s addition of   new seed to the svalbard global seed vault brings the total number of crop stored at the arctic facility to over one million it s an important milestone but to keep the vault running and to protect it from the effect of climate change the norwegian government is going to have to spend upwards of   million in upgrade the estonian onion potato black eyed pea bambara groundnut and hunter barley used to brew irish beer are among the   deposit made today at svalbard that brings the total number of seed deposited at the facility to a whopping    according to the bbc the doomsday vault a it s been dubbed opened exactly ten year ago today and it s there on svalbard island halfway between the mainland of norway and the north pole to protect the world s seed in the event of cataclysmic climate change mega drought nuclear war or whichever apocalypse inducing event we might be able to think of only one of the vault s three chamber are full but that s not stopping the norwegian government from contemplating some much needed upgrade there are still well over a million unique variety of crop that still need to be stored at the site a year ago a flood at the vault s entrance prompted a re evaluation of the facility s ability to fend off the effect of climate change thankfully the flood didn t damage the facility following a feasibility study commissioned by it ministry of agriculture and food the norwegian government is proposing a startup grant of  million nok    million to improve performance and extend the long term viability of the vault even though it s located in the arctic circle svalbard s temperature is expected to increase from an average  degree f   c to  degree f   c and rainfall is expected to increase by  percent by the year  ironically the facility designed to safeguard seed in the event of climate change is being threatened by climate change the main principle for construction in permafrost area is to avoid the warming and thawing of permafrost writes statsbygg the state owned management company that conducted the feasibility study for building that are particularly sensitive to damage or where long life is desired artificial cooling of the ground will be required climate change will lead to increased ground temperature le permafrost poorer carrying capacity among other problem to prepare the vault for the coming effect of climate change and to ensure that it will continue to offer the world s gene bank a secure storage space in the future the facility will be equipped with new refrigeration unit a concrete access tunnel a service building to house emergency power and new electrical equipment waterproof wall have already been fitted to prevent flooding the arctic svalbard seed vault is designed to safeguard the seed of   plant in the event of read more read three year ago the syrian civil war prompted the first documented withdrawal of seed from the vault so while the svalbard seed vault may seem like something we ll need for the future the facility ha already proven it worth government of norway statsbygg bbc

column2: if houston s record deluge during hurricane harvey highlighted the danger of unchecked sprawling development then tulsa another conservative city built on oil is a showcase for the opposite for decade it ha planned carefully and imposed wide ranging regulation that aim to prevent the kind of devastating flood that used to make national headline here other city are taking note a expanding development and a warming climate threaten to make flooding worse on a recent afternoon bill robison park his city issued car in front of a modest beige ranch house in east tulsa to carry out a key part of the city s program that s the one i haven t been able to talk to yet he say robison is lead engineer for tulsa s storm water program and this is one of  home the city is currently trying to buy and tear down over the last three decade tulsa ha cleared nearly   building from flood prone area typically after people are flooded two or three time they re ready to sell out bill robison typically after people are flooded two or three time they re ready to sell out say robison sure enough the woman who answer the door tell him the house flooded not long ago in fact it s flooded repeatedly in recent year and changed hand a number of time she s open to a buyout the great drainage war tulsa is surprisingly vulnerable to flooding from the arkansas river and a spiderweb of  creek in the s and s the city wa hit by a string of damaging flood activist and the public stormed city hall but builder and property developer fought plan to address the flooding local medium dubbed the dispute the great drainage war then in  another flood disaster dumped more than a foot of rain leaving  people dead and hundred injured it galvanized the city that and a change of administration allowed one of the nation s most aggressive flood control plan to move ahead tulsa s program is one of the few that account for urban growth the city ha built a network of drainage system and it s created green space that double a flood basin when needed bill robison pull his car over and point one out you can see there s a frisbee golf course here walking trail and just a nice open area he say tulsa s flood control plan includes multi use drainage basin like the athletic field at will rogers high school it double a a detention pond for overflowing storm water joe wertz stateimpact oklahoma tulsa also enacted strict rule on where and how home and building are constructed rule that go far beyond national standard ron flanagan who helped write the flood control plan say it can be tough mandating something that add cost for developer elected official are very sensitive to the development community s want and desire and need he say to help pay for the program the city added a fee to utility bill which wa and remains unpopular but having a strict program also mean resident get big discount on flood insurance if you don t have the local people on board you haven t got a program flanagan say the federal government can t enforce everything and they have minimum standard today tulsa s flooding problem are much smaller and official say the prevention program ha saved life and million of dollar other city routinely reach out for advice even the state department brings international group to see the flood plan in action still flanagan worry the longer tulsa go without a catastrophic flood he say the easier it is to forget why the city needed to change it way

column2: cnn desert aren t supposed to get much rain but tropical storm rosa is flipping the script rosa is forecast to make landfall early tuesday with more than  million people under a flash flood watch in the southwest cnn meteorologist michael guy said it ll drench baja california with  to  inch of rain with some spot getting up to  inch the national hurricane center said a it move northeast rosa will also dump  to  inch of rain on much of arizona with up to  inch in the mountain a flash flood watch is in effect for part of arizona until wednesday a the storm s remnant move across the state the national weather service said these rainfall amount may produce life threatening flash flooding the national hurricane center said dangerous debris flow and landslide are also possible in mountainous terrain historically it s unusual for the u southwest to get pummeled by a hurricane or tropical storm but these event have begun to increase in recent year cnn meteorologist gene norman said research indicates that global warming contributes to tropical storm getting more intense bigger and longer lasting thereby increasing their potential for damage said kevin trenberth senior scientist at the national center for atmospheric research while there might not be a direct link between global warming and the recent increase of severe storm in the u southwest it is possible that this could be a side effect of climate change norman said warmer ocean are allowing eastern pacific storm to reach higher latitude he said this wa not the case earlier it wa quite rare for an eastern pacific storm to even reach baja california and this is now becoming more common rosa wa about  mile  kilometer north of punta eugenia mexico late monday night with maximum sustained wind of  mph  km h cnn s brandon miller and judson jones contributed to this report

to  inch  to  cm of rain in north carolina bringing rainfall total in some inland area to  to  inch according to the national hurricane center the most rain so far from florence wa   inch  cm in to get out of their home by sunday afternoon because of the flood risk if you are refusing to leave during this mandatory evacuation you need to do thing like notify your legal next of kin because the and south carolina and surrounding state down from a peak of nearly  million in new bern about  mile northeast of wilmington at the confluence of two river florence overwhelmed the town of   and left the downtown area under water it wa pitch black and i wa just scared out of my mind said tracy singleton who with her family later fled her home near new bern a authority rescued people by boat and even airlifted  stranded people in north carolina there were also report of looting five people were arrested for breaking into a dollar general store said the police department in wilmington which ha woman died in south carolina when her car hit a fallen tree catastrophic storm this is still a catastrophic life threatening storm said zack taylor a meteorologist with the national weather service s weather prediction center it ha already dumped  to  inch of rain on part of the carolina with more to come he said and many of the river will see prolonged flooding some not cresting for a few day many road were closed and authority warned of landslide tornado and flash flood with dam and bridge in peril a river and creek swelled the flooding could taint waterway with murky coal ash and toxic federal funding available in some affected county trump who plan to visit the region this week and he tweeted his deepest sympathy and warmth to the family and friend of those who died a the united column2: forecaster downgraded alberto to a still dangerous depression monday evening warning heavy rain and an accompanying flood threat would continue in the aftermath of the storm s landfall in the florida panhandle the memorial day strike on the gulf coast by the first named storm of the  atlantic hurricane season drove holiday beachgoers away from roiling dangerous surf what had sprung up from the gulf of mexico a a subtropical storm wa now a vast soggy system trekking inland a it flung rain heavy at time all around the southeast forecaster warned that heavy downpour from the weakening system could raise the potential for life threatening flash flood in coming hour or day across north florida much of alabama and large area of georgia and eventually into tennessee and the carolina the national hurricane center in miami said the depression wa centered at  p m monday about  mile west northwest of dothan alabama it top sustained wind had dropped nearly in half to about  mph what remains of alberto wa crawling northward at about  mph subtropical storm alberto is approaching the florida panhandle and is expected to make landfall sometime monday it had maximum sustained wind of  mph early monday and can create dangerous wave for people not in it path authority did not immediately attribute any death or injury directly to alberto but in north carolina a television news anchor and a photojournalist were killed monday when a tree that had been uprooted from rain soaked ground toppled on their suv a they reported on severe weather on the fringe of the huge system that wa hundred of mile from alberto s center and more rain is on the way between four and eight inch of rain could soak the florida panhandle alabama and western georgia before the storm move on isolated deluge of  inch also are possible in spot a the system head toward the tennessee valley on tuesday and later this week into the ohio valley and great lake region earlier monday alberto rolled up big wave and tide along beach of the northern gulf coast lifeguard posted red flag along the white sand of pensacola beach where swimming and wading were banned a alberto disrupted long holiday weekend plan for million the storm also forced some memorial day tribute to be cancelled across florida s panhandle safety wa the priority but the decision wa still a heartbreaker said tom rice a  year old army veteran who had helped with planning for a ceremony at beal memorial cemetery in fort walton beach some straggler still made their way through the rain to pay tribute at the cemetery s veteran tribute tower however rice said american flag had been placed saturday on the graf of all   veteran buried in the cemetery we got the flag out rice told the northwest florida daily news a wind whipped a massive u s flag flying at half staff that s what s important along the florida panhandle tourist vowed alberto wouldn t dampen their fun jason powell sought to keep his child entertained with movie and tv adding he hoped the sun would come out again after alberto blew over so far we ve seen a lot of wind and the ocean is really high covering up the entire beach powell remarked janet rhumes said her group of friend from kansa had been planning their memorial day weekend on navarre beach since october they stocked up on grocery and settled in for card game we ve never seen one before and we re here celebrating a friend s th birthday rhumes told the daily news so how often can you say you rode a storm out a alberto s weakening center head inland it is being deprived of the warm water that fuel tropical weather system a a subtropical storm alberto had a le defined and cooler center than a tropical storm and it strongest wind were found farther from it center some of the rain band spread hundred of mile away from the center elsewhere the north carolina highway patrol said a large tree toppled on a news television vehicle monday near tryon north carolina wyff tv of greenville south carolina said a news anchor mike mccormick and photojournalist aaron smeltzer with that station were both killed mccormick and smeltzer had just interviewed tryon fire chief geoffrey tennant a they covered storm in north carolina ten minute later we get the call and it wa them tennant said at a news conference his voice cracking tennant did not directly blame the up to  inch of rain that fell monday from the fringe of alberto for the death he said the root of a large tree that toppled on the vehicle came loose from ground saturated by a week s worth of earlier rain the men died instantly their tv vehicle s engine still running tennant said

column2: a former thailand navy seal ha died while working to save  boy and their coach from the submerged tham luang cave complex the new york time report the death come a a heavy blow to the rescue mission a monsoon rain threaten further flooding and a oxygen level inside the chamber have started to drop around   am local time this morning saman gunan a  year old retired thai navy seal wa on his way out of the cave system after delivering extra oxygen canister along the route to the trapped boy and their coach when he ran out of oxygen and lost consciousness his partner who wa unable to revive him brought his body back to the mouth of the cave his job wa to deliver oxygen passakorn boonyaluck the deputy governor of the chiang rai region told reporter he did not have enough on his way back saman who had left the thai navy returned to help with the rescue mission in respect for his effort the thai king said he ll sponsor the funeral it s doubtful the boy will be told about the diver s death a the news would likely damage their morale even further and at a time when they need to build both their physical and psychological health i can guarantee that we will not panic we will not stop our mission we will not let the sacrifice of our friend go to waste rear admiral arpakorn yukongkaew told reporter this morning but even though we have lost one man we still have faith to carry out our work he said adding that we are trained to expect risk at anytime it s part of the job the diver s death underscore the danger of a rescue attempt a round trip to the boy take  hour six of which en route to the chamber are against the current visibility is practically nil and some passageway are mere crawlspace the  soccer player and their coach have been trapped in the tham luang cave complex for nearly two week they were discovered by expert diver on july  about   mile  km from the mouth of the cave the wild boar team entered the cave when it wa dry but flood water trapped them inside heavy monsoon rain are expected to resume on sunday presenting a challenge for rescue worker who are desperately trying to pump water out of the cave oxygen level within the chamber are another concern the demand for oxygen ha increased owing to the presence of the support team member who are currently attending to the boy the oxygen level in the chamber is now at  percent down from the usual  percent the bbc report oxygen canister are being delivered to the chamber along with food and medical supply rescuer are currently working to connect a three mile  km cable to the chamber to supply oxygen along with a fiber optic cable for communication a plan to leave the boy in the cave until the monsoon season end which won t happen for another four month is appearing le feasible with each passing day and hour a rescue attempt through the submerged passage seems inevitable at first we thought the child could stay for a long time said apakorn but now thing have changed we have a limited time the expected rain will likely replenish the cave with water but a the monsoon season progress there s a heightened chance that sinkhole and stream will flood the cramped chamber to complicate matter the boy have never used scuba gear and some don t know how to swim sadly the death of saman gunan show how perilous the situation really is even for experienced navy seal diver bbc new york time deutsche welle

column2: people look at car and home engulfed in floodwaters on february   in san jose california getty image in california earthquake are common and most resident understand the risk of powerful reverberation destroying their home and street but according to a new book from la s most famous seismologist lucy jones the state face an even bigger threat a megaflood that would pummel inland california jones book the big one how natural disaster have shaped u and what we can do about them look at the history of the world s biggest earthquake flood tsunami hurricane and volcanic eruption a well a disaster we could experience in coming year one nightmare scenario investigated by the u geological survey dubbed arkstorm would bring a series of heavy rain in a short timespan to california the state could suffer extreme rainfall that overwhelms flood control system force   million people to evacuate inundates  of california s land and cause   billion in damage bringing a much a  time the water flowing out of the mississippi river s mouth an arkstorm could devastate several area in california including silicon valley according to jones and the usgs a major flood like this could strike in any future winter california ha also seen an arkstorm before california ha a history of monster storm grand avenue in buena park california during the flood of  photo courtesy orange county archive eighty year ago during one of the driest march through february period ever recorded in the region an epic series of storm caused mudflows that damaged and destroyed hundred of home in southern california a the los angeles time note rain fell a fast a two inch an hour inundating railroad bridge and road throughout the san fernando valley at least  people died nearly a century earlier the great flood of  submerged most of the central valley and los angeles basin every major city in the region flooded and downtown sacramento wa only accessible by boat one third of california s taxable land wa destroyed rendering the state bankrupt the flood also killed just over  of the state s population these two storm produced precipitation that exceeded level that many place in the u experience once every  to   year on average they did serve a wake up call for california however local official responded by building dam and making river deeper to mitigate future flooding following the  flood and after the great flood of  california temporarily moved it capital to san francisco but jones writes that california s modern day flood control system aren t equipped to handle another storm of that magnitude a cal fire firefighter look at a flooded section of highway  after a mudslide on january   in montecito california getty image how to make california more resilient to mass flood in the last chapter of jones book she lay out way that california city can prepare for the next big storm for example la could invest more heavily in solar energy or rechargeable groundwater basin which would both help the city mitigate climate change in the longterm and reduce reliance on power line and old aqueduct during a storm in the meantime another resource for la resident is the community emergency response training program which allows neighborhood to design their disaster response block by block california is not equipped to handle mass flooding california s flood control system need massive overhaul according to the usgs it existing levee aren t designed to withstand an arkstorm which could cause a flood  mile long and  or more mile wide the agency s report also includes terrifying map of hypothetical flooding that would happen during an arkstorm a seen below it would plunge much of sacramento northern orange county and stockton underwater hypothetical flooding in an arkstorm event in sacramento usgs hypothetical flooding in an arkstorm event in stockton usgs other california city that could see extreme flooding in coming year include area in and around silicon valley among them santa clara mountain view cupertino san jose palo alto menlo park foster city san mateo burlingame fremont and newark state and local agency allocate   million annually toward maintaining   mile of levee in the central valley but michael mierzwa the lead flood management planner for the california department of water resource told the la time they should be spending   million per year to meet current federal standard just last year the lake oroville dam north of sacramento buckled after a series of torrential winter storm the structure crumbled on one side spilling a massive amount of water onto the dam s wall if the state hadn t unplugged the dam in time it wall would ve likely eroded and unleashed all that water onto the surrounding community california flood protection is not designed for an arkstorm like event the usgs writes

column2: image copyright nasa noaa the past year ha been a busy one for hurricane there were  named storm in   hurricane and six major hurricane category  or higher an above average year in each respect the  hurricane formed consecutively without weaker tropical storm interrupting the sequence the only other time this ha been recorded wa in  are these storm getting worse and doe climate change have anything to do with it a year of record this atlantic hurricane season ha been particularly bad there wa harvey which pummelled the united state in august it brought the largest amount of rain on record from any tropical system  mm it caused the sort of flooding you d expect to see once every  year causing  bn of damage to houston texas ironically this wa the third such one every  year flood houston had suffered in three year image copyright getty image image caption usually hurricane might last a day or two but the torrential rain from harvey lasted a week september brought irma which devastated caribbean community it wa the joint second strongest atlantic hurricane ever with sustained wind of mph those wind were sustained for  hour longer than any tropical system on record anywhere in the world next came hurricane maria another category  hurricane with sustained wind of mph which destroyed puerto rico s power grid finally hurricane ophelia span past portugal and spain the farthest east any major atlantic hurricane ha ever gone image copyright getty image image caption ophelia carried saharan dust a far north a london darkening the sky in the middle of the day despite this  wasn t the worst year in some key respect it didn t produce the strongest storm that wa hurricane allen in  with sustained wind of mph nor did it have the greatest number of storm that wa  which saw an incredible  named storm including seven major hurricane one of them wa the infamous hurricane katrina but  wa probably the costliest estimate for the cost of the hurricane season vary and continue to be revised ranging up to  bn by comparison  racked up  bn in damage according to the national hurricane center about  bn today adjusted for inflation image copyright getty image image caption harvey s persistent rain caused catastrophic flooding in part of texas it ha certainly been a bad year but over time are hurricane getting worse there have been  of the strongest category  hurricane since  eleven of these have occurred in the past  year we know that hurricane are powered by warm sea and over the past  year global average sea temperature have risen by about c but when you look at the total strength of storm in each year since record began some year are more fearsome than others meteorologist use something called accumulated cyclone energy ace to calculate the total wind power of all the storm in any given year a you can see from the following chart there s no clear upward trend why not even though sea are getting warmer other factor can prevent hurricane forming in particular year saharan dust can interfere with hurricane formation a can the close proximity of african storm to the equator but one of the great weather irony is that hurricane hate strong wind strong wind in the atlantic interfere with the circulation of air through a developing storm this stop the storm growing into a hurricane during a phenomenon called el nio the pacific ocean near the equator get warmer than usual this affect global wind pattern leading to stronger wind in the atlantic that mean el nio year tend to be quiet year for hurricane but when the pacific is cooler known a la nia the reverse is true making it easier for hurricane to form and  is a la nia year in fact the total storm strength in la nia year ha been rising decade by decade land drainage high wind are just part of the story climate change affect hurricane season in other way too rainfall during hurricane can be devastating hurricane harvey would have brought severe flooding to houston regardless of climate change but it is reasonable to assume that harvey brought more rain than it would have done  year ago global air temperature have also increased by about c in the past  year and warmer air hold more water that s likely to be behind the increasing frequency of extreme rainfall event seen in the u in recent decade image copyright epa image caption extreme rainfall event are becoming more common in the u according to data from the epa but the location of housing compounded the damage houston s population ha more than doubled since  to more than two million people housing development are expanding into more marginal poorly drained land this put more people in harm s way climate change is also causing sea to rise melting glacier and land based ice sheet contribute to higher sea level image copyright getty image image caption melting glacier are causing sea level to rise also warmer water occupies a larger volume so a sea warm up sea level rise in the u the largest sea level rise is around the coast of the gulf of mexico about  mm each year at eugene island louisiana all of this is increasing vulnerability to flooding when hurricane and their associated storm surge reach land a warmer world is bringing u a greater number of hurricane and a greater risk of a hurricane becoming the most powerful category  there s an increased risk of flood damage whether related to climate change rising sea level or more people moving into flood prone area what do you want bbc reality check to investigate get in touch read more from reality check follow u on twitter

column2: instagram is widening the scope of it feed and officially opening up it follow feature to your interest by allowing user to follow hashtags that s right you ve been blessed and now you can give that topic a follow too see also splitting instagram direct into it own messaging app might be a big mistake no longer will you be forced to manually search through the platform s public post for some extra fitspo encouragement before a workout or when you want to while away your day dreaming about living that vanlife starting now user will be able to add hashtags related to their favorite subject to their follow list alongside the brand instacelebs and friend that already flood network with content once you follow a topic like slime in the example below the top public post and story bearing the tag will fall into your feed automatically image instagram you can also unfollow hashtags just like other account so you won t be stuck with annoying post using tag for extra impact long after a trend ha faded into obscurity thank goodness instagram first teased the feature in a test last month but that wa only rolled out to a small number of user the functionality is now available to all user worldwide giving everyone on the network a chance to discover something new every time they scroll through their feed

column2: image copyrightafpimage caption a man injured in the cyclone in zimbabwe is carried away from a helicopter cyclone idai which struck the coastline of mozambique on  march ha caused devastation and heavy loss of life the un say   million people in mozambique lived in the path of the cyclone with a further   people affected in malawi and many thousand more in zimbabwe so how common is extreme weather in southern africa and were these country sufficiently prepared tropical cyclone in this part of the indian ocean are not that rare most form in the central indian ocean sufficiently far enough off the coast for some preparation to be made cyclone idai wa unusual in that it formed in the mozambique channel close to the coastline giving government and aid agency le time to issue warning and make plan the cyclone wa by no stretch of the imagination the most powerful but what made it so devastating wa where and how it hit said clare nullis spokeswoman for the world meteorological organization the ocean floor along the coast by mozambique is conducive to give storm surge which reached roughly  m to m in the coastal city of beira which is absolutely huge the low lying coastal area of central mozambique are highly vulnerable to natural disaster but the budget for preparing and responding to them is very small last year the government received support from international donor for a disaster fund of   m  m for  and  this contingency plan is the main source of funding for any disaster response and is intended specifically for search and rescue within the first  hour for a major disaster such a cyclone idai most of the fund for recovery and reconstruction are raised after a disaster ha struck and even without this latest emergency mozambique wa facing economic strain a a result of a controversial loan deal in  which resulted in a suspension of some international donor aid to the government medium captionaerial footage showing the disaster in mozambique how much warning the meteorological office of mozambique inam issued weather alert a the storm developed three day before the cyclone struck the government raised the alert to the highest possible level telling people to evacuate threatened area some people were moved out by boat beforehand but many didn t respond to warning or weren t aware of them these public alert were made in a timely fashion but it s always down to actor along the chain to decide how to act on this type of information say joao de lima rego an adviser at deltares a research organisation focusing on coastal region and river basin that ha helped develop a forecasting system in mozambique a part of the forward planning for severe weather safe zone had been created in rural area for evacuation above the flood plain on this occasion however the flooding wa far more severe than anticipated image copyrightafpimage caption a local sport park provides some high ground above the flood water in the town of buzi preparation in urban area the port city of beira with a population of half a million had introduced measure to strengthen resilience to cyclone and flooding preparedness ha focused on drainage system say dinis juizo associate professor of hydrology at the university of eduardo mondlane in maputo drainage canal and flood control protection such a a large water basin have also been introduced however much of the population of beira outside the city centre live in informal housing often made of material unable to withstand severe weather the level of investment ha not been high enough for an event of this scale say dinis juizo image copyrightgetty imagesimage caption aid agency have faced challenge in getting resource to flood hit area of mozambique malawi and zimbabwe the storm that eventually became cyclone idai had caused death in malawi to the north of mozambique in early march people in lowland area were warned but because warning about flooding and rainfall are an annual occurrence during the rainy season many people were reluctant to move and didn t anticipate the extent to which the country would suffer in zimbabwe there were also warning about the approaching storm but zimbabwe s minister of defence oppah muchinguri ha said her government failed to anticipate it strength by the time the storm reached zimbabwe it had weakened considerably and wa no longer a tropical cyclone nevertheless it had a severe impact on the eastern region of the country what do you want bbc reality check to investigate get in touch read more from reality check follow u on twitter

column2: when an iceberg break off from a glacier it can drift for thousand of mile traveling freely across the open ocean but last week an iceberg s journey wa interrupted when it got stuck on a shallow part of the seafloor along greenland s western coast in other word the iceberg wa grounded and it had lodged itself right beside the small island village of innaarsuit such grounded iceberg are actually pretty common say fiamma straneo who ha traveled about  time to greenland s ice sheet for her work at the scripps institute of oceanography what s unique about the iceberg by innaarsuit which ha a population of le than  is both it size and it proximity to the village a grounded iceberg experience ocean water pushing at it in one direction and the seafloor pushing in another a tug of war that make it easy for limb to break off with a splash that can rock boat or flood coast the iceberg might even do an entire somersault in the water across the world from the canadian arctic to patagonia in argentina that shedding is both a tourist attraction and an issue of concern the larger the iceberg the larger the wave it cause if it break apart and the innaarsuit iceberg rise about  foot above the water according to a danish meteorologist quoted by the danish broadcaster dr the iceberg that felled the titanic is thought to have risen a mere  to  foot above water what happens with a grounded iceberg is almost luck of the draw say margaret lindeman a phd student also studying the greenland ice sheet through scripps perhaps only a small chunk of ice will fall off the iceberg maybe a little piece will break off the bottom allowing the iceberg to lift off the seafloor and drift away or maybe the whole canyon of ice will implode causing the sort of flooding feared by villager in innaarsuit dozen of them evacuated on friday from their lower lying home greenland s steep rocky western coastline is often treated to a procession of iceberg drifting through the water the number of which ha increased since the s likely due to ocean warming many village are perched on flatter area atop cliff out of the flood zone but there are still fishing boat marina and boat fuel station at the edge of the water all this infrastructure get damaged from time to time by grounded iceberg straneo say even if the village itself doe not need to be evacuated the disintegrating iceberg also pose a problem for scientist when straneo and lindeman collect ocean measurement off their boat they never get too close to the iceberg there s too great a chance that a piece will break off and smash the boat or that the iceberg will capsize so instead they send a remote controlled robot resembling a bright yellow kayak through the icy water to collect data on temperature and salinity for others the splash of the iceberg are a spectacle illulisat is a village and unesco world heritage site further south from innaarsuit on greenland s western coast close by a cliff of ice routinely shed chunk into the water generating dramatic wave that tourist boat travel to see it s the job of the boat captain to carefully time the tourist exit onto shore even so sometimes a piece of iceberg fall off a they disembark and passenger get doused a they scramble off the boat back in innaarsuit the danish broadcaster dr reported that the iceberg wa blown by wind a few hundred meter away from the island over the weekend today some evacuee were given the all clear to return home but the home and street within  meter from the coast are still off limit along with a convenience store fish factory and power plant a innaarsuit s villager settle back in they ll be keeping a close eye on the iceberg s next great migration more great wired story

and banking foreign minister javad zarif ha accused u sanction reimposed after president donald trump withdrew from the iran nuclear deal last year of impeding aid effort to affected area saying that it ha caused a shortage of rescue helicopter this isn t just economic warfare it s economic terrorism mr zarif tweeted on april  the government ha maintained that people especially farmer will be deforestation ha been one of the major cause of flooding in recent year in the country according to iran s natural resource and forestry organization widespread and unregulated deforestation ha column2: white house chief economic adviser larry kudlow speaks during a meeting between president donald trump and governor and lawmaker at the white house in april  evan vucci ap house republican confronted two of president trump s top economic adviser on trade on thursday while also breathing a sigh of relief after the administration s decision to begin easing tension with europe a day earlier the rose garden announcement on wednesday with trump and european commission president jean claude juncker in which both side said progress wa made toward retreating from a trade war went a long way in buying the trump administration time to prove it plan is working republican in congress have grown increasingly impatient a the president ha enacted hard line trade policy targeting import from mexico canada the european union and china to name a few trump s a great negotiator he did a good job said rep roger williams r texas about the move to soften the administration s stance on some good but williams personifies the bind many republican find themselves in he s a pro trump lawmaker but he s also a car dealer and the auto industry is losing sleep over trump s steel and aluminum tariff and the potential the administration ha raised for more auto related tariff williams relayed his concern to larry kudlow the director of the national economic council and peter navarro one of president trump s top trade adviser when the two adviser met with house republican thursday morning to debrief the lawmaker on the eu deal and american trade policy going forward rep roger williams r texas wa one of many republican lawmaker to raise concern about the trump administration s trade policy on thursday jacquelyn martin ap my message wa they need to be very careful with tariff on domestic content williams said car dealer are already beginning to cancel order with the manufacturer because they re fearful of tariff that can convert to le job and job layoff a flood of lawmaker expressed similar trade policy concern to kudlow and navarro in the meeting said rep bill huizenga r mich i wa making sure they heard the message that this is not just uncomfortable but it s painful and damaging huizenga said my constituent are being potentially put out of a job but huizenga also said it would be hard not to characterize trump s wednesday announcement a a win trump said he and juncker agreed that the eu would buy u s soybean and that the eu would become a massive buyer of u s liquefied natural gas juncker declared he had the intention to make a deal today and we made a deal today trump said the two ally will also work to resolve tariff on steel and aluminum and work towards zero tariff zero non tariff barrier and zero subsidy on non auto industrial good let me not just curse the darkness i m glad there wa a candle lit yesterday with the european union rep huizenga said it s progress to have the temperature lowered with our european trading partner and ally is smart navarro met with republican on the house way and mean committee wednesday afternoon a well early in the week the trump administration came under fire after announcing a   billion subsidy program for farmer especially soybean farmer hurt by it own trade policy it wa unclear how much wednesday s announcement that the eu would begin buying american soybean would affect american farmer a much of the hurt ha actually come from tariff on china we shouldn t have a policy that creates economic distress and then implement fdr style new deal era program to remedy problem of our own creation said rep andy barr r ky his state ha also been affected by retaliatory tariff from the eu on bourbon and barr said he didn t feel satisfied by the amount of specificity in thursday s briefing on whether that would also be resolved soon

column2: ellicott city md s main street wa turned into a raging river on sunday in a catastrophe that followed another flash flood in  the water wrecked storefront and left car strewn amid debris on monday katherine frey the washington post getty image fast moving flood water caused mayhem in ellicott city md on sunday triggering an emergency declaration and urgent message for resident to seek higher ground one man remains missing a crew work to clear the area howard county police say eddison hermond  of severn md is unaccounted for they re asking the public to help find him washington area radio news outlet wtop describes hermond a an air force veteran and a member of the national guard a friend of hermond s told wtop that the veteran had been in a restaurant in downtown ellicott city on sunday witness said he wa swept away after trying to help people swiftwater rescue team searched for hermond last night both on foot and in all terrain vehicle but the search wa suspended and resumed on monday according to the arbutus volunteer fire department founded in  ellicott city s main street and downtown have been designated a historic district the same area suffered massive flooding in  when the city barely avoided having to tear down any building in a long and expensive rebuilding effort in that catastrophe in july of  two people died in what wa called a once in a   year event but in  it ha happened again devastating an area that due to it valley setting had endured other flood in the past missing person alert in ellicott city this is eddison hermond he wa swept away in the ellicott city flooding yesterday around pm trying to help people and hasn t been seen or heard from since if you have any news please contact me ellicottcityflood pic twitter com moxxjmsjj kenneth josepha kdogcony may   rain storm have been seen growing more intense in recent year but part of the difference at least one expert say also lie in how the area s land surface ha changed discussing ellicott city after the  flash flood jeffrey b halverson a geography professor at the university of maryland baltimore county told member station wamu it s heavily paved there s lot of narrow street that act a very rapid conduit of water so the flood wa a much about the nature of the underlying land surface a it wa the large amount of rain falling from the sky intense flooding hit the town s main street in at least two wave on sunday shoving car down the street and bursting through storefront including at several building where people found themselves suddenly trapped in store and restaurant image and video from the scene are striking showing fast moving water rising nearly a high a the bottom edge of the street stop sign and obliterating anything in the torrent s path one day after the flooding hit people are reaching out to help the howard county government say anyone who want to volunteer can register at it website but that for now the downtown area remains off limit the visit ellicott city organization say a local non profit called the ellicott city partnership is taking donation to help the community recover from the flood a it did in  on monday condition had dried out enough that salvage crew could begin towing vehicle that had been caught in the disaster

column2: with a giant nor easter slamming into the mid atlantic and northeast forecaster are using warning with dire language to inform coastal resident of massachusetts that this storm will not be an ordinary event in fact record coastal flooding is anticipated in boston and other part of eastern massachusetts which is leading the national weather service to come out with statement that it rarely if ever issue see also intense nor easter may demolish coastal flood record knock out power to million the coastal flooding is the result of a long fetch of easterly wind reaching hurricane force  mile per hour pointed squarely at the north south coast of eastern massachusetts the combination of astronomical high tide astorm surge of  to  foot storm surge and wave of up to  foot just just offshore is already inundating the coastline with water level well above normal tide level according to the national weather service nw at high tide on friday morning the water in boston harbor reached   foot which wa the third highest water level on record and the worst of this storm is yet to come for the high tide on friday night the nw is forecasting a record water level will be set in boston of between   and   foot beating the old record set just two month ago the long lasting flooding and battering wave ha prompted unusually drastic language in the nw warning emphasis ours damage to some shoreline structure may occur there will likely be widespread inundation of coastal road and basement with life threatening inundation depth above  or more foot possible in some location some neighborhood may be cut off for an extended time this is a dangerous storm and evacuation of some neighborhood may be necessary another major impact from the storm will likely be beach erosion prompting this warning from the nw very severe to extreme erosion is likely and may compromise protective dune seawall and other structure this storm may be capable of producing one or more new inlet in other word this storm could simply smash through existing land to create new island the nw s coastal flood threat and inundation map show where the worst flooding is expected along the massachusetts coast with water level of nearly  foot expected in location like gloucester harbor revere scituate and boston the coastal flooding could break record all along massachusetts coast including the boston area record that were just set in early january thanks to the bomb cyclone that whipped through the area there s a major difference between that storm and this one even though both are intensifying rapidly enough to be called meteorological bomb unlike with the bomb cyclone which moved through quickly a high pressure area over greenland also known a a greenland block will keep the current storm system pinned in place for day this mean the storm will last through several high tide cycle along the north atlantic coast making damage more likely numerous report of road closure a coastal flooding begin now at this point we want to focus on hunkering down and taking action here are some safety rule concerning coastal flooding please stay away from the shoreline don t go out on any rock along the beach pic twitter com motxkvwto nw boston nwsboston march   image were already rolling in friday morning from along the coast showing high water level with more high tide column2: dubai london reuters oil s price rally this year to it highest since may  may seem a source of glee for opec but some in the producer group fear the gain could prompt shale company to crank open their spigot and flood the market benchmark brent crude rose further above   a barrel on tuesday supported by oil output cut led by the organization of the petroleum exporting country and ally including russia that are due to run until the end of  the surge come a a welcome boost for the revenue of oil producing nation many still reeling from a price collapse that started in mid  when crude began to fall steeply from above   per barrel due to oversupply some in opec are worried a prolonged rally could stimulate more u s shale oil output however creating more oversupply that could weigh on price and market share we all are excited about the rally and want to see if it will be sustainable during the year a it will certainly whet the appetite of shale producer an official from an opec country said the oil minister of iran opec s third largest producer said on tuesday that the organization s member were not keen on increased price a such gain would encourage more shale production opec ha no formal target for oil price however saudi arabia opec s top producer want to see crude above   to boost the valuation of it national oil company aramco before an initial public offering of share this year and to reduce the gap in it state budget saudi source have said opec source say saudi arabia ha become a strong advocate of higher price a shift from a more moderate stance in the past and saudi official have downplayed the threat of a boost in shale production even so u s production is expected soon to rise above  million barrel per day close to saudi level due largely to soaring output from shale drillers government data show eia m opec official also think the  rally ha been mainly driven by unrest in iran rather than a tighter balance between supply and demand giving rise to concern it may not last oil price rose because of the political situation in iran an opec source said there is a worry now that this would be followed by a sharp decline in price a third opec source said market fundamental did not justify the price rally it is only politics that is changing the mood the push in price will mean the peak is near and hence price will give up some of the gain while opec source say oil market fundamental remain strong on the back of the supply cut others are worried that economic growth in consuming country could slow and higher price might encourage some producer to pump above their output target reporting by rania el gamal and alex lawler editing by dale hudson

condition massachusetts ha been walloped with the combination of astronomical high tide and strong onshore wind up to  mph the resulting coastal flooding reached record level in boston with severe flooding reported all along the coast see also a bomb cyclone explained flood water took over sidewalk and street trapped car and shut down subway station the severity of the flood which exceeded the region s benchmark storm of the blizzard of  wa caused by a combination of high astronomical tide from monday s supermoon the timing of the storm that brought the strongest wind onto the coast at high tide and a rising sea level over the past few decade perfect storm of ingredient for a major coastal flood  supermoon monday high astro tide  worst of the storm hitting at high tide  ice hunk chucked ashore from recent arctic cold  some sea level rise since  also help eric fisher ericfisher january   the blizzard of  get some competition in february of a winter storm struck new england that set record and killed  people much like that benchmark storm this year s bomb cyclone s high tide and fierce wind meant a lot of flooding in boston back in  wave reached higher than  foot thursday s image of seawall being breached and water pouring into street were eerily reminiscent of the major blizzard  year ago currently in the midst of one of the worst coastal flood in generation topping water level from the blizzard  with just one tide cycle and a fast moving storm that is surreal http t co njxeaouvx eric fisher ericfisher january   wow boston harbor tide level up to   foot which tie the this year the goal is to expand image recognition so that it s not just identifying the object in the photo but also it aesthetic quality eyeem s co founder and chief product officer lorenz aschoff described eyeem vision a an extension of the photography marketplace s broader mission to address the content crisis namely the fact that when eyeem wa founded in  aschoff felt that there wa a massive flood of image that had completely destroyed the visual aesthetic of the web eyeem aim to fix that by helping brand find beautiful photograph and aschoff said eyeem vision ha been trained to identify many of the visual element that make for a good photograph it is in his word technology that understands in general beauty at the same time he acknowledged what i think is beautiful might be different from what you think is beautiful plus individual brand are going to have their own specific standard and guideline that go beyond beauty so each customer can upload photo that train eyeem vision to identify photo that match their own aesthetic aschoff said eyeem s analysis is looking at around half a million different factor one of the way eyeem is actually deploying the technology is by launching a new mission dashboard brand use mission to crowdsource campaign photo from the eyeem community and the new dashboard allows them to track how their mission is going how many photographer are participating how many photo have been uploaded and so on eyeem say that the average mission result in more than   photo which why it s important to use eyeem vision to surface the photo that best example bcg s   consultant can now search for image to use in their presentation and marketing material and eyeem will only show the image that are a good fit with the bcg brand and while this is le
